The animation is stunning.
In a summer drenched in CGI-effect extravaganzas, it's easy to forgive The Bourne Supremacy its occasional transparent plot device.
Fright Night dances on a tightwire between satire and terror, glittered by special effects and a with-it nonchalance.

The special effects are competent. The acting is good, and I enjoyed Robert Preston's fast-talking The Music Man reprise and the gentle wit of Dan O'Herlihy's extraterrestrial. But the final spark was missing.
Turbo won't set the world of animation on fire, but it's a fun movie.
[Turbo] is a victim of bad timing, uninspired animation and voice talents that range from perfect to perfectly awful.
The film looks great (which is barely even worth mentioning in reviews of CGI movies anymore), but it has problems under the hood.
Good animation + strong voice talent make this a solid family entertainment film.
Perfectly predictable but endlessly entertaining and boasting amazing animation, Turbo is yet another zero to hero st

The latest DreamWorks animation epic Turbo offers gorgeous imagery (duh), a nifty star vocal cast, some sweet gags and a plot that, even by these proudly fantasy-heavy standards, is pretty damn silly. But anyway...
A perfectly enjoyable and often funny animation film with a stellar cast behind it, but the predictable storyline and underwhelming 3D effects are a little disappointing.
A perfectly enjoyable and often funny animation film with a stellar cast behind it, but the predictable storyline and underwhelming 3D effects are a little disappointing.
Turbo is a very cute movie with lots of great animation and elements that the kids are going to love. It's just a bit hard to swallow.
The outcome is as predictable as the premise is outrageous in this crowd-pleasing 3D animated comedy.
What was in the water when the folks at DreamWorks Animation decided to make a 3-D digital feature about a snail who wants to race in the Indy 500?
Continues the DreamWorks Animation move into A-list animated features.
The many special effects -- some retouched on film by hand -- are quaint by today's digital standards, but that only makes them all the more fun.
Remains memorable for its tension, its special effects and the talkie debut of Claude Rains.
The special effects hold up surprisingly well, and the story is as compelling as ever.
The success of this superb adaptation of HG Wells's novel is down to John P Fulton and John J Mescall's pioneering special effects and the eerie atmosphere conjured up by horror maestro James Whale.
Chris Columbus protg Raja Gosnell directs the film as if it were Britney Spears' worst CGI nightmare.
It might not be 1970s animation, but everything else about it is straight from the Saturday morning cartoons - a retread story, bad writing, and the same old silliness.

The obnoxious special effects, the obligatory outbursts of flatulence and the incessant, so-five-minutes-ago pop music on the soundtrack overwhelm what is left of the scruffy, dopey old Hanna-Barbera charm.
The acting is stiff, the story lacks all trace of wit, the sets look like they were borrowed from Gilligan's Island -- and the CGI Scooby might well be the worst special-effects creation of the year.

There are, in short, no human relationships aboard Deepstar Six, just frequent frantic cries of "Mayday!" and special effects that bubble and gurgle a lot but never produce a single quiver of genuine terror. Facebook Twitter Email Print Save
Everything about this movie feels so 10 years ago - so behind the times - even in terms of the animation.
The blend of live action and animation is competently done, but the subtly mean-spirited screenplay has more sour meows than hearty laughs.
Only very small children still easily impressed by interaction of human actors and CGI quadrupeds will be amused by Garfield: The Movie.
The CGI is well-done, but Garfield's presence among the otherwise live cast is a constant distraction.
I know, I know, I'm really on the warpath about CGI creations lately.
Better than it has any right to be, thanks to impressive CGI work, some good gags and a note-perfect purrformance by Bill Murray.
This is mediocre moviemaking, not even Bill Murray can save a weak script and weaker special effects.
The story is bland and workmanlike--week-old catnip that's lost its bite. What saves it is the animation, which is set amid a live-action world and which is extremely well done.
The comic-strip cat comes to the big screen thanks to some pretty nifty computer animation and -- in a really inspired move -- the voice of Bill Murray

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review_content: Stunning CGI as expected, but story-wise, Lewis Carroll and L. Frank Baum have little to worry about.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review_content: Not only does Jackson establish himself as the Cecil B. DeMille of epic CGI battle scenes, but he's now the Ingmar Bergman of modern cinematic technology

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review_content: For the most part, it's business as usual. In other words, brisk plotting, no-frills acting, outstanding special effects, and unusually effective pacing.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review_content: Jackson ... is at his best when coordinating enormous numbers of people and impressive special effects into a cohesive and stunning whole.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review_content: The most impressive new element in this installment is the completely CGI-created Gollum...he turns in the best performance.
You'd have to have X-ray vision to find a semblance of a plot here, yet you'd have to be blind to overlook the cheapness of the special effects and the ineptitude of the direction.
You'd have to have X-ray vision to find a semblance of a plot here, yet you'd have to be blind to overlook the cheapness of the special effects and the ineptitude of the direction.
Mere words cannot describe how awesomely gnarly Piranha 3D is, how hugely entertaining, and how urgently you must get yourself to the theatre to see it. Like, now.
Aja serves up the tongue-in-cheek thrills, CGI-enhanced gore and gratuitous nudity with such unabashed relish that this may prove to be the summer's break-out horror hit.
Keep a protective hand poised above the 3D specs.
Piranha 3D is not for everyone. But if you're thinking about seeing a film called Piranha 3D, chances are you'll be delighted with it. Watch this sick filth now.
Aside from the 3D gimmick, there's not much on offer here that the low-budget original didn't include, with plenty of comical gore, snappy thrills and in-joke references.
Piranha 3D proves a worthy heir to its brazen exploitation-cinema forefathers.
The new Piranha 3D lived down to my absolute lowest expectations and I say that with nothing but gleeful affection.
Though it's campy and gory, but for all its hype, it's best to save your money rather than spring the dough for special effects that aren't that spectacular -- or even eye-popping.
Guilty pleasures belong to August, 3D belongs in the grindhouse... and when the authorities tell you to get the hell out of the water, you really, really should.
Forget about 'Avatar'... Kelly Brook is the reason 3D was created.
Piranha 3D goes for the jugular. And generally misses, but generally in an amusing way.
Brilliantly cast, gleefully gory and featuring more nudity than is probably strictly necessary, this is a hugely enjoyable creature feature with terrific 3D effects.
Making a great B movie requires more than just fake blood and breasts, something the minds behind Piranha 3D already know.
Piranha 3D is nothing less than the Avatar of B movie schlockfests.
Take a look at the Piranha 3D poster or watch the trailer online. You'll know by the end if you want to see it and if you do, then you'll have a blast.
Piranha 3D ends the summer on a note of shamelessly entertaining B movie bottomfeeding.
As far as cheesy, sexist and violent B-movies go, Piranha 3D is a blast.

Many new 3D films aren't designed for the medium, but Piranha 3D is ideal: an exploitation movie with lashings of blood, bouncing bare breasts, and masticated body parts being thrown around, all fake as hell and often funny.
A movie fueled by the wet dreams and rage fantasies of a thousand pubescent boys. Perfectly attuned to its audience -- 3D boobs, gore and dodgy science abound.

Neither gore enthusiasts nor boobie fans will be disappointed. Piranha 3D knows what it is and embraces it, from stupid disobedience to kids in peril to sexy exploitative silliness, with a remarkable level of humor and competence.
Piranha 3D gets honestly earned points for the creative energy it sustains in the arena of creatively gory dispatches, non-torture porn division.
The best example of the level of art that Piranha 3D aspires to comes when a guy gets his dick chomped off and it gracefully floats down towards you in 3D.
Piranha 3D is more funny than disgusting, even when screen fills with half-nude swimmers, bobbing like human dumplings in a roiling vat of borscht. This isn't just sick, it's clas-sick!

Filled with recognisable faces, packed with excessive blood and gore and jokes as corny as they are hilarious, Piranha 3D is, if nothing else, the most honest and unpretentious piece of filmmaking of 2010.
"Piranha" makes the best use of 3D technology in movie history.
The new Total Recall is a series of set pieces whose CGI environments trump narrative logic.
Formerly a fun, dumb, R-rated, Arnold Schwarzenegger movie, this is now a PG-13, CGI Cheese Whiz exercise in remaking a famous-title with a second-tier cast.
Considering what a commanding majority of the film's running time is made up of large-scale action scenes and chases in CGI environments, it's disastrous that only one of them is any good.
An all-out barrage of special effects that borders on a bludgeoning.
Directorial brio and eye-popping special effects hold our interest when there is nothing on screen to fire our little grey cells.
Visually, the 2012 remake is better than the original, with interesting set and background designs, decent enough futuristic vehicles, and superb special effects. The plot is another story.
This Disneyfied version of The Incredible Shrinking Man isn't so bad -- it at least features some reasonable special effects.
Though it relies on special effects, this cutie-pie caper never loses sight of the protagonists amid the bigger-than-life Cheerios and 40-foot blades of grass.
The special effects are all there, nicely in place, and the production values are sound, but the movie is dead in the water.
The special effects have moved on a bit since the 1950s, but this is old-fashioned Disney fun.
Using as many practical effects as possible, as well as the special effects of the day, director Joe Johnston's vision holds up incredibly well years later.
An oddly compelling stop action animation film with puppets which provides a glimpse into the meaning of life in the adventures of a group of urban dwellers.

Intriguing as a flawed experiment in animation, "nine dollars ninety-nine" suffers from a lack of thematic continuity that leaves the audience wanting both more and less--more story and less metaphor.
Animation is so often used for frivolous flights of fancy that it's something of a shock to see it employed in the service of a tale that emphasizes human foible and mortality.
Stop-action animation of painted sculptures creates beautiful, full-bodied characters with bemused sophistication and tender charm, where the odd becomes sweetly normal.
Utilizes stop-motion animation to explore semi-fantastical ideas that couldn't otherwise be touched on in live-action.
A charming, poetic and at times surreal stop-motion animation co-written with Etgar Keret and based on the Israeli writer's short stories.
It isn't always clear if the animation is integral to the movie or merely a way of sprucing up its more familiar tales of melancholy and yearning.
It has been a good year for animation that pushes thematic and visual boundaries.
Playful, light-hearted and fun, with an impressive cast of Aussie stars and some fine stop-motion animation. As it stands, at 74 minutes, it's not quite as smart (or rewarding) as one would hope.
Not for all tastes due to its arthouse nature, this animation transcends into beautiful magical realism with a spectacular Australian voice cast.
Eagle vs Shark has its own distinctive style, partly thanks to whimsical little interludes of animation, but mainly because it ties blithe absurdity to a rock bed of emotional truth.
A high point in the renaissance of Disney animation.
The special effects are extraordinary, along with the topsy-turvy sets, augmenting a nerve-wracking plot of distressing exploration, frazzled nerves, and creeping death.

movie_name: Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives
review_content: Upscaled in special effects, but still suffering from the same bland character and story treatment. [Full review in Spanish].

... a maddeningly entertaining piece of pulp fiction, a solid B-movie artfully distressed for the sort of middlebrow audience that might dismiss Dredd 3D as a cinematized first person shooter game. Which means that film critics like me will love it.
With the human actors marking time at best (and that best is rare), Cats & Dogs becomes a series of expensive special effects in search of a scenario worth the price tag.
Consistently amusing and sometimes hilarious, Cats & Dogs uses animatronics and computer animation, much like Babe, to pull off a convincing illusion of animals talking, playing and waging war.
So advanced are the special effects techniques that the filmmakers even combine animated faces with real animal bodies, with such uncanny skill that after awhile you give up trying to find the seams.
The story barely matters, and it smartly takes a backseat to the picture's surprisingly well-done special effects.
an enjoyable movie that uses special effects with some interesting twists
It's vision of suburban living is about as artificial and narrow-minded as the original NES Paperboy game it seemingly evokes during its opening CGI sequence
A shrill and silly farce in which a CGI marsupial seems more lifelike than most of its flesh-and-blood co-stars.
The tykes might laugh in the right places, but this is still horribly formulaic, the humor's dopey and the CGI-animated kangaroo outacts the real people.
State-of-the-art 3D effects add a welcome dose of visual freshness to the fourth installment of this video game-based franchise.
State-of-the-art 3D effects add a welcome dose of visual freshness to the fourth installment of this video game-based franchise.
While the movie itself is no great shakes, the 3D is awesomely fun.
Would this movie have been made if not for the 3D Gimmick? Milla Jovovich commands the screen and makes all the RE films a fun ride. If you hate the series, this won't change your mind.
While the movie itself is no great shakes, the 3D is awesomely fun.
Would this movie have been made if not for the 3D Gimmick? Milla Jovovich commands the screen and makes all the RE films a fun ride. If you hate the series, this won't change your mind.
Yes, the 3D is immersive... but there's nothing to be immersed in here but the blood, bullets, and globs of brainmatter flying around.
Yes, the 3D is immersive... but there's nothing to be immersed in here but the blood, bullets, and globs of brainmatter flying around.
Your level of enjoyment of this depends on how much you like Andersons slo-mo decapitations and other forms of gory special effects.
Your level of enjoyment of this depends on how much you like Andersons slo-mo decapitations and other forms of gory special effects.
Inventive ideas, dazzling 3D and spectacular production design elevate this fourth in the franchise to a juicy bite above the average zombie movie.
Inventive ideas, dazzling 3D and spectacular production design elevate this fourth in the franchise to a juicy bite above the average zombie movie.

True to series form, plot is nearly indiscernible, but this fourth installment in the sci-fi/horror/action franchise created by writer-director Paul W.S. Anderson is the sleekest so far, thanks to 3D and star Milla Jovovich's body-hugging catsuit.

True to series form, plot is nearly indiscernible, but this fourth installment in the sci-fi/horror/action franchise created by writer-director Paul W.S. Anderson is the sleekest so far, thanks to 3D and star Milla Jovovich's body-hugging catsuit.
Resident Evil: Afterlife sees Anderson returning to cinematic dreck with a stunningly tedious exercise in 3-D CGI wankery.
Resident Evil: Afterlife sees Anderson returning to cinematic dreck with a stunningly tedious exercise in 3-D CGI wankery.

Resident Evil: Afterlife recycles nearly every horror convention. The plot is not original and the 3D is quite bad. And since we've literally seen all this before, it's only occasionally entertaining, and rarely interesting.

Resident Evil: Afterlife recycles nearly every horror convention. The plot is not original and the 3D is quite bad. And since we've literally seen all this before, it's only occasionally entertaining, and rarely interesting.
Don't get me wrong, the acting isn't great, the plot simple and the constant 3D effect attempts are annoying as hell, but... it was still... alright, I guess?
Don't get me wrong, the acting isn't great, the plot simple and the constant 3D effect attempts are annoying as hell, but... it was still... alright, I guess?

Kids 8 and older may laugh now and again at this ill-conceived animated comic fable about barnyard animals who party like frat boys when the farmer isn't looking, but it surely doesn't earn the laughs through good storytelling or beautiful animation.
If the humor is smart and effective, the animation is lackluster and uneven -- the pixel pushers at Pixar have spoiled us.
This is the most dubious animation since Robert Zemeckis's creepy The Polar Express, only uglier, lazier, and with a more indisputable racist streak.
The CG animation looks like rubbery plastic instead of animals, and much of it is spent on jokes related to derrieres and hindquarters.
never really amazing enough to separate it from the rest of the herd of great animation that we've seen this summer.
...has energy to spare but a flimsy and only mildly amusing script that doesn't allow it to stand out from the current glut of kid-friendly CGI competitors.
This could be the film that snaps everyone's patience with Hollywood animations which have a Dell computer chip where their heart should be.

The animation is perfectly colorful and the voice actors earn their paychecks, but it's blatantly obvious that this thing started production without a screenplay -- and hit the screens without a plot.
A re-hash of tired cliches and CGI effects.
The special effects are funnier than, I suspect, they were intended to be.
It's filled with technology, special effects and action. But it just doesn't make any sense.
The more CGI and Real-D 3D and shaky cams have taken over modern action filmmaking, the more I have craved a solid, low-key suspense film like this one. (Parental Review also Available)
The more CGI and Real-D 3D and shaky cams have taken over modern action filmmaking, the more I have craved a solid, low-key suspense film like this one. (Parental Review also Available)

Although it may lack the heart-tugging appeal of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, the consensus among animation fans is that 1940's Pinocchio remains the most perfect animated feature Walt Disney produced.
Pinocchio is the greatest, most terrifying film in the Walt Disney Animation Studios canon.

With its marvelous mixture of an engaging story, beautiful animation, loveable characters, and unforgettable music, Pinocchio remains a grand adventure that both kids and adults can still enjoy today.
The animation is, of course, superb, finely detailed and masterful in execution -- the Monstro whale sequence a standout.
On the technical front, the animation is nothing short of masterful, using elaborate perspective shots that would be unique even in live-action filmmaking.

Alice in Wonderland has its moments of delight, humor and bedazzlement. But it also becomes more ordinary as it goes along, building to a generic battle climax similar to any number of others in CGI-heavy movies of the past few years.
A fantastical romp that proves every bit as transporting as that movie about the blue people of Pandora, his Alice is more than just a gorgeous 3D sight to behold.
Tim Burton tosses $150 million down the rabbit hole with this gorgeously rendered -- but utterly disposable -- CGI epic.
It's a shame Burton gets his Lewis Carroll mixed up with his Tolkien and CS Lewis. Still, the film's 3D visuals are fun to look at.
Alice in Wonderland is a well-paced, beautifully crafted visual spectacle that makes good use of 3D for a cracking cinematic experience.
It looks like a CGI head trip gone postapocalyptic. In the film's rather humdrum 3-D, the place doesn't dazzle -- it droops.
Clearly Burton's visual aplomb and ease with special effects mesh with Carroll's imagination.

The movie's strengths are the costumes, the makeup, the production design, the special effects, the vocal work and a terrific musical score by Danny Elfman that has a quality of magic and wonderment missing from the screenplay.
...the visuals are overwhelming, the direction to most of the cast seems to be to chew the scenery, and we're back to a movie being released in 3D for no discernible reason.
Impressive eye-candy, elaborate and gorgeously detailed in wall-to-wall CGI (the 3-D seems rather half-hearted though; this is one that won't suffer much in regular old 2-D).

Burton, once a master of CGI, has gradually become its servant, or at least has allowed the studio to. The madcap ringmaster of Gothic phantasmagoria does not exert his individual stamp on a book one might have thought he was born to film.

CGI has not been good to Tim Burton. The ability to see every unrestrained nuance of his vision fulfilled has robbed his films of the creative zest and inventive verve which marked his earlier classics.
These aren't actors working in front of blue screens with obvious effects dubbed in later. You really are in Wonderland. Real life and CGI are seamless.
The movie feels wrong. I liked the individual pieces but it never works as a whole. It's too much like Burton's other work and the 3D was awful.
First-rate fantasy....made even better with digital 3D technology. Tim Burton can be hit or miss. This one's a hit. Paul Chambers, CNN.
For all of the wild, 3D effects, eccentric characters and sly nods to its source material, the highlights ... are the performances of his two favorite actors--Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter.
There are no dinosaurs, starships, monsters or special effects involved. Just two humans pressed too close to one another, locked in a fight for survival. What could be more frightening?

After a summer of crashes, bangs, endless chase scenes and special effects that belittle the actors standing in front of them, what a pleasure to see characters in a thriller doing what people like themselves possibly could do.
There are no dinosaurs, starships, monsters or special effects involved. Just two humans pressed too close to one another, locked in a fight for survival. What could be more frightening?

After a summer of crashes, bangs, endless chase scenes and special effects that belittle the actors standing in front of them, what a pleasure to see characters in a thriller doing what people like themselves possibly could do.
A smart script - that sees kids asking why they can't find Santa's North Pole home on Google Earth - wrapped up in some nifty 3D visuals make this a highly enjoyable early Christmas present.
Let all your Christmases come at once with this brilliantly funny, inspired animation from the makers of Wallace & Gromit and Chicken Run
Deftly blends the sophisticated sensibility of Aardman with the slick spectacle of American animation.

The animation itself is beautiful and delightfully detailed, and the 3D is of the rare breed that makes the supposed "gimmick" look to have real value, the bow on top of the already lovely present that is Arthur Christmas.

The animation itself is beautiful and delightfully detailed, and the 3D is of the rare breed that makes the supposed "gimmick" look to have real value, the bow on top of the already lovely present that is Arthur Christmas.

"Arthur Christmas" is imaginatively crafted and its computer animation is divine. With its wide-ranging international locations and and seasonal color scheme, watching the film once doesn't quite seem like enough.
Not a bad little Christmas fable. The Aardman Animation wit is in full-effect anytime Bill Nighy's great Grandsanta is onscreen.
This animated feature from Aardman and Sony Pictures Animation is a feel-good family film with spunk and originality, the kind that has not been seen since the first of The Santa Clause franchise.
An utterly charming Christmas yarn which seems destined to become a holiday staple thanks to its wonderfully detailed animation, abundance of gags and brilliantly drawn characters.
Excellent vocal performances and impeccable 3-D CG animation... [Full review in Spanish]

movie_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1
review_content: The Twilight Saga hasn't matured along with its heroine. In fact, the latest movie regresses a bit, delivering more filler, less feeling and crummier CGI than last year's Eclipse.

movie_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1
review_content: Considering that this is the book where Stephanie Meyers's sexual repression finally lets rip in a totally weird tale ...the movie adaptation is often akin to watching paint dry with lousy CGI effects and a thoroughly insipid musical score.

movie_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1
review_content: The dialogue is, of course, ridiculous and the acting ranges from stiff to mopey. But moments that should be pulsating with tension are usually hilarious because the special effects are still just so distractingly cheesy.

movie_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1
review_content: Stretches a 50-minute story into almost two hours of lustful glances, bitter recriminations and CGI-heavy battles between bloodsuckers and their werewolf rivals, all underscored with a soundtrack of angst-ridden rock and pop.

movie_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1
review_content: A wolf council with dubbed growls may be the most ludicrous scene of the year, but a rumble with chic vampires punching CGI werewolves comes close.
More like a paper dragon in a parade, Mothra is simply lovely. In none of its forms does it even try to look 'real', which sets it against a whole tradition of Western special effects.
Yet another lesson to Hollywood that a fright film need not be awash in blood and elaborate special effects.
Yet another lesson to Hollywood that a fright film need not be awash in blood and elaborate special effects.

Tries to be a back-to-basics thriller without the special effects, buckets of blood and evil dolls that talk. Unfortunately, the filmmakers forgot to replace the horror-film formula with a plot that makes sense.

Tries to be a back-to-basics thriller without the special effects, buckets of blood and evil dolls that talk. Unfortunately, the filmmakers forgot to replace the horror-film formula with a plot that makes sense.
Captivating special effects.
Captivating special effects.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Any stragglers still unconvinced that animation can be an exciting medium for both adults and kids will run out of arguments in the face of Persepolis.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: A fresh, moving, out-of-the-gate masterpiece -- a work of animation that manages to be artistically brilliant, politically rich, morally engaging and emotionally overwhelming.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: As a portrait of young female consciousness caught in a historical thrust of political and cultural turmoil, this original French animation, based on popular Iranian source material, is by turns funny, exuberant, dark and troubling.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: By turns lyrical, serious, funny and acerbic, Persepolis raises the bar for animation and illustrates the true power of storytelling in illuminating the world and its conflicts.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: An exhilarating reminder of what animation can do that other media can't.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Persepolis is a small landmark in feature animation.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The film is extraordinary, expanding the forms of memoir and of animation, told with enormous insight into the most intimate moments of adolescent longing and the most complex aspects of political upheaval.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The black-and-white animation won't dazzle your eyes, but everything else about Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud's adaptation of Satrapi's graphic comic book series Persepolis will hold you in its thrall.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: ...a magical animation, one that presents a universal coming of age story within exotic locales with the simplicity and whimsy of folk art.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Done primarily in simple black and white animation Persepolis's elegance lay in this simplicity combined with the deft complexity of [Marjane] Satrapi's very moving story.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: There is no question that the animation style of this French production is unlike anything we've ever seen before...

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The characters are so rich and so human that they transcend the simple animation.The vocal performances also help give the film universal appeal.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: There is nary a hint of CGI or any other computer-aided special effects --- which makes its impact all the more remarkable.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: There is nary a hint of CGI or any other computer-aided special effects --- which makes its impact all the more remarkable.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Persepolis is a true original in the eclectic world of animation, one that's full of fascinating contradictions.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: [Marjane] Satrapi and [Vincent] Paronnaud wed the graphic novel to animation in Persepolis, and it's the kind of blessed marriage through which both partners grow up.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: With poignancy, humor and evocative animation, Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, who co-wrote and co-directed, detail a coming of age that coincided with the deterioration of a nation.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Has more intelligence than the usual animation.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The predominantly black-and-white animation is used to amusing effect as Satrapi gently pokes fun at her youthful exuberance and innocence, making serious political points easy to swallow. The lack of sense of direction is the film's only let-down.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The monochrome animation is stark and beautiful, and Marjane's an appealing narrator. Often hilarious, sometimes tragic, this may be low-tech, but it's high-class.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: With deceptively simple, mostly black and white animation, the filmmakers take us through a life story that is anything but simple

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The animation absolutely won me over--Satrapi's art style is simple, engaging, and cool all at once.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: The film's nuanced view of social issues is complemented by lovely black-and-white animation work that blends Islamic motifs into a sort of Yellow Submarine-ish world.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Animation has never been a more sophisticated tool for storytelling, and Persepolis takes the form in a daring direction.

genres: ['Biography', 'World cinema', 'Film adaptation', 'Biopic [feature]', 'Animation', 'Period piece', 'Coming of age', 'Comedy', 'War film', 'Drama', 'Biographical film']
review_content: Persepolis, despite its inventive and pleasing animation, drags on dully.

movie_name: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys
review_content: Though certainly original in form, Altar Boys requires a taste for Swamp Thing-type animation, doubled with a deafening score.

movie_name: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys
review_content: Foster and newcomer Hirsch are the best things in Dangerous Lives, a touching but odd mix of live action and animation.

movie_name: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys
review_content: Although hindered a bit by the animation and familiar subject matter, it still resonates because of such strong performances.

movie_name: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys
review_content: A quirky coming of age tale with the original touch of comic-book animation to reflect the thoughts of a 14-year-old lad.

movie_name: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys
review_content: While McFarlane's animation lifts the film firmly above the level of other coming-of-age films ... it's also so jarring that it's hard to get back into the boys' story.
[The film] squanders a promising premise and a lot of cool special effects on a story that gets more ridiculous and less involving with each passing minute.

Crap. No script, no acting, no sex, and no talent. Disney animation has more sex. Grey is shot hidden in the dark and behind sofas. She's an emotional bore & spends 77 minutes putting her hair in a bun.
It's great to see a high-tech thriller that thrills because of its actors, not its special effects.
This is another fantastic version of Diana's origin and is full of badass Amazons and incredible animation.
This movie presented a radical melange of genuine horror and self-aware comic touches, not to mention the fabulous Rick Baker special effects.
Some of the special effects are a little creaky now, but the snap of Landis's editing and the razor's-edge balance of horror and comedy are still fresh.
A film that, despite 35 years of evolution in special effects, do not surpass the carnal naturalness of this one. [Full review in Spanish]
Aside from the special effects, this film is a fun time at the movies, but not as memorable as other horror classics.
Demonstrates the way CGI- driven bot cinema can fruitfully coexist with father-and-son bonding cinema to create charming entertainment - part warm hugs and part cold clang.
Demonstrates the way CGI- driven bot cinema can fruitfully coexist with father-and-son bonding cinema to create charming entertainment - part warm hugs and part cold clang.
The reason we ARE here to see "Real Steel" is the rockin' robots. The deft use of CGI, motion capture and animatronics makes the action look real and believable (in a bombastic Hollywood way).
The reason we ARE here to see "Real Steel" is the rockin' robots. The deft use of CGI, motion capture and animatronics makes the action look real and believable (in a bombastic Hollywood way).

A heavily clichéd but nonetheless enjoyably feel-good drama that pushes all the right buttons, thanks to a decent script, some impressive special effects and winning performances from Hugh Jackman and newcomer Dakota Goyo.

A heavily clichéd but nonetheless enjoyably feel-good drama that pushes all the right buttons, thanks to a decent script, some impressive special effects and winning performances from Hugh Jackman and newcomer Dakota Goyo.
There are no big surprises in this movie, other than the fact that it's done with conviction, skill and special effects that are all the more spectacular for being presented in a matter-of-fact way.
Featuring sharp performances from its cast (both human and metal) and some outstanding special effects, "Real Steel" is best described as "Rocky" meets "The Iron Giant."
There are no big surprises in this movie, other than the fact that it's done with conviction, skill and special effects that are all the more spectacular for being presented in a matter-of-fact way.
Featuring sharp performances from its cast (both human and metal) and some outstanding special effects, "Real Steel" is best described as "Rocky" meets "The Iron Giant."
The script doesn't do enough with the father-son element to keep us involved, and the CGI robot fights aren't sufficiently exciting to make us care about the rest
The script doesn't do enough with the father-son element to keep us involved, and the CGI robot fights aren't sufficiently exciting to make us care about the rest
The visual effects are a slick combination of real robots and CGI, and -- especially on the new Blu-Ray release -- the result is gloriously seamless.
The visual effects are a slick combination of real robots and CGI, and -- especially on the new Blu-Ray release -- the result is gloriously seamless.
Real Steel offers plenty of fun and engaging moments -- of both the human character drama and giant CGI robot battle variety.
Real Steel offers plenty of fun and engaging moments -- of both the human character drama and giant CGI robot battle variety.
Real Steel envisions a future where boxing has evolved into giant fighting robots. Great special effects and cool fight choreography makes this a must-see.
Real Steel envisions a future where boxing has evolved into giant fighting robots. Great special effects and cool fight choreography makes this a must-see.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: Despite the skill and spectacle of the special effects, the prosaic storytelling is never interesting as cinema.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: Newell expertly makes the smallest moment of adolescent longing as vivid and meaningful as the WOW-worthy special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: It's the first Potter movie in which the student characters and their emotional situation is the equal of the special effects, the elaborate settings and the gallery of brilliant British actors in supporting roles.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: Though the special effects in this film are often breathtaking, the real drama is here is exactly where it should be: in a young man's frightened but resolute eyes.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: The actors play second fiddle to the special effects, and that's not how I like my Harry Potter movies.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: The special effects blend impeccably with a robust, forward-driving sense of action.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: While a must-see for rabid fans, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire will impress nondevotees only with its seamless special effects and captivating action sequences.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: The special effects are first rate but I think it's always going to be about the characters. And they're great characters.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: A huge cast, plenty of special effects and Harry gets a battering -- pretty much as you'd expect.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: Kloves has streamlined J. K. Rowling's 700-+-page opus into cinematic fighting form. And the special effects, which threatened to overwhelm the first two movies, are seamlessly integrated.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is mostly satisfying, simply because such technical precision and meaningful special effects are rare in fantasy films today.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
review_content: With its grand special effects, many small moments of charm, and continuing development of the characters, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire takes us into a world that, evil or not, makes us reluctant to leave.

An extraordinary example of both art-historical interpretation and CGI as passport to unknown lands, The Mill and the Cross... is a moving-image tribute to the still image, with its ability to "wrestle the senseless moment to the ground."
This futuristic science fiction is based on a Philip K. Dick short story, and features award-winning special effects.
Total Recall is fine entertainment, complete with breathtaking action sequences and special effects that impress even in these computer-generated times.
It's a blockbuster from another era, when a big idea, rather than a pair of 3D goggles, gave the film its extra dimension.
Verhoeven's version of Philip Dick's story is vigorous, exciting, and inventive sci-fi thriller, combining pulp savviness, ultra-graphic violence, and Oscar-winning special effects.
Total Recall is slick, sly and subversive, and if some of the special effects have aged somewhat, that only adds to the charm.

Arnold Schwarzenegger brings an effective blend of machismo and innocence to his role. Too bad director Paul Verhoeven lets brainless violence and tricky special effects swamp the cleverness of the tale itself.
Watch as millions of dollars are hurled at us in the form of bad special effects and an impenetrable labyrinth of a story that I cannot imagine a single soul caring about.

While parts of Moonraker are rather silly, solid special effects, well-executed action sequences, and a strict reliance upon the 'Bond Formula' keep this film among Moore's better entries as the British superspy.
The combined impact of Angelina Jolie, lots of action and computer animation doesn't make up for a convoluted and dull storyline, ponderous dialogue and weak antagonists.
A series of spectacular set pieces filled with eye-popping special effects, although [director Simon]West does fall back on his trademarked overuse of sound.
Plot and performances are buried beneath special effects in 'Tomb Raider.'
Huge ghostly fun, and a fine achievement from the early days of CGI.
Full of special effects, but still strangely 'indie', the movie has a unique sensibility ...
At times the relentless special effects and tangled plotting veer towards visual and narrative overkill, but the final tonal swerve is shocking and effective.
There's something about this type of animation that adds another dimension entirely to the exploration of images and memory, it's very haunting.
The state-of-the-art animation is spellbinding and worthy of big screen viewing. But it's a harrowing, heavy-going work that will leave you as shell-shocked as its soldiers.

The animation serves as a distancing device akin to the way that Folman's mind used concealment to shield him from horrific traumas, a canny marriage of thematic and aesthetic concerns that nonetheless can't cover up the unsubtle redundancy of his story.
Waltz with Bashir represents another honorable stride toward this gestating breakthrough in adult animation, though I'm as disappointed as I am pleased to call it 'honorable.'
It's undeniably distinctive, and anyone interested in the unconventional end of animation should take a look.

Painting each frame of Waltz With Bashir took almost four years and many doubted it could be done. But there is no question that the result is one of the most resonant films of its year from any source, and quite probably a landmark in animation.
Powerfully proves that animation can be an original vehicle for adult catharsis when reality merges with lingering nightmares. Vivid search for answers about genocide.
Animation turns out to be the perfect medium to show this ... It's an outstanding marriage of form and content.
Waltz With Bashir will stretch your ideas about the possibilities of films to confront history truthfully, and in particular, animation as a way to tell a serious story.

Folman is an Israeli documentarian who has not worked in animation. Now he uses it as the best way to reconstruct memories, fantasies, hallucinations, possibilities, past and present. This film would be nearly impossible to make any other way.
A transcendent shattering of what viewers should expect from traditional animation or the standard documentary film. Ari Folman's dream-like journey into his own memory is a must-see.
As much as the film is about war, it's also about the mutability and self-distortion of memory, and that makes animation the ideal medium to paint battle as the surreal experience it is.
A unique, Oscar-nominated 'animated documentary' that uses graphic-novel-style animation to deal with the Israeli army's participation in the Lebanon war of 1982.
Documentary and animation might not seem to fit together, but in Waltz With Bashir's blur of memory, nightmare and fact, they mesh perfectly.
Animation may be the ideal medium for replicating dreams, and in this unsettling feature by Ari Folman it also proves well suited to autobiography.

Ari Folman, who wrote and directed Waltz with Bashir, creates an intriguing film. He uses unique animation which features muted, ochre imagery. It's like a nightmare from which you awake. But you stay unsettled for a long time.
The Oscar-nominated "Waltz With Bashir," by Israeli filmmaker Ari Folman, is a dream-like movie, told in unique animation, about the horrors of war.

The look of Waltz with Bashir is what is most arresting. It's a deep, multi-plane style of animation that incorporates photo-real settings, realistic renderings of the people and under-animated movement, especially of faces.
Waltz with Bashir uses vivid, hand-drawn animation to bring to life interviews Folman conducted with friends who were involved in the Lebanese war in the early 1980s.
Folman's use of animation permits an audience to engage with the events, such as they are recalled, in a way that the simple testimony of those involved could not achieve.
The flatness of the Flash animation keeps visual bombast to a minimum, even during surreal interludes.
As hypnotic as the animation is, it distracts from the film's clear problems.
The special effects are stunning, as is Jon Voight's memorable performance as the sneering, evil adventurer, whose obsessive calling has transgressed from the priesthood to anaconda hunting.
Luis Llosa's Anaconda is great "B" movie trash, complete with bad special effects and cheesy monsters.

review_content: I Am Legend feels like a work in progress, the sort of movie you can bet will get the director's cut treatment when it's released on DVD. In the meantime, we have a film that doesn't make sense and boasts dire special effects.

review_content: So often, sci-fi is overproduced, but I Am Legend doesn't look like a CGI extravaganza. It looks like an edgy suspense movie shot on the fly in New York City after the fall. And because of that, it's all the more effective.

review_content: The monsters are routine CGI creations, crudely animated and unconvincing. In a film of such visual majesty and surprisingly weighty drama, they present an unfortunate and needless distraction.
Shyamalan manages to spend very little time and effort on special effects and boring explanations -- and plenty of time on pure terror.

While the story may make this Kon's least inspired film, the animation is his most inspired.
Soulless characters in remarkably flat animation talking epistemological gobbledegook among watered-down psychedelia.
Paprika expands your notion of what animation can achieve. You wake from it as if from a dream: spooked, provoked and exhilarated.
Fiercely provocative, Paprika shames Hollywood's use of animation as a kiddie pacifier.

We're so used to current cautious commercial formulas, it comes as an enjoyable shock to see something like Satoshi Kon's Japanese film, Paprika, which reminds us that with animation, almost anything you can imagine can be represented.
The mostly 2-D animation is top-notch quality, and it is a fascinating idea.
The animation shows brilliant imagination by the filmmakers.
Yes, Paprika is a masterpiece. The animation medium lends itself so perfectly to dream capers that it's no wonder Kon's final film is regarded a perfect marriage of form and subject.

Its Inception-inspiring premise of a young woman who can expertly dive into other people's dreams fully exploits the fluid, plastic capacities of animation to realise an ever-shifting, unstable world ruled by arbitrariness and id
This is what animation is meant to be.
Like in each of these films, the best part are the special effects. [Full Review in Spanish]
Not as frightening as Alien, not as thrilling as Aliens, but a 3D sci-fi blockbuster that's easily the saga's most spectacular entry.
Not as frightening as Alien, not as thrilling as Aliens, but a 3D sci-fi blockbuster that's easily the saga's most spectacular entry.
On a visual level, Prometheus truly delivers upon all expectations, with superb creature design and some of the best 3D production work since Avatar.
Beneath the hype and promises, however, it's almost a letdown that the actual film is merely very good: a better-than-average 3D big-budget space tale.

Beneath the hype and promises, however, it's almost a letdown that the actual film is merely very good: a better-than-average 3D big-budget space tale.
The paranoia becomes palpable, and a lot of its impact comes from how dramatic and dazzlingly seamless the special effects are.

The film is utterly gorgeous to look at. Every exterior and interior shot looks like a painting, rendered in thick, velvety strokes. The CGI is entirely seamless, and, indeed, minimal considering the subject matter.
A more elegant and thoughtful sci-fi film than we've gotten in many a year. The 3D is truly immersive, the scares well-earned, and the performances top-notch.

"Prometheus" damn near lives up to the unsustainable hype, at least at the level of cinematography, production design, special effects and pure wow factor.

Prometheus is more interested in piling on big questions than in answering them. It's deep without being particularly smart, although the dazzling design and special effects keep you from noticing that basic flaw until at least an hour in.

Any lack in originality is handsomely compensated by the plethora of 3D visual treats courtesy of a crackerjack technical crew that creates an eerie interplanetary moonscape that's as epic as it is requisitely foreboding.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: This is animation as it had never before been experienced.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: Most remarkable in Snow White's romps through the forest with her pack of animal pals, Disney's brilliant cell animation has rarely been equaled.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: ...the animation itself is top-notch, and in a number of darker sequences (Snow White's terrified entry into the forest, for example), Disney's adoption of Expressionist visual devices makes for genuinely powerful drama.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: It luxuriates in the art of animation, watching the various animals race through the woods, or watching Snow White running scared from an array of imaginary horrors.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs may not be the best example of a Disney classic, thanks mainly to its lightly-plotted story, but with great animation, memorable characters, and beautiful music, it still remains one of their most endearing films.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: The animation is spectacular, the songs are catchy, the dwarfs are delightful, and the movie is revolutionary in that it was the first full-length animated feature. But let's face it: Snow White has to be the most passive heroine in film history.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: First, the animation for the most part is beautiful and still looks great.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: Snow White and the Seven Dwarves is undeniably a watershed in animation and a truly classic film. How he adapted the story is a topic that has been critiqued and debated with almost as much passion as the original folktale.

movie_name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
review_content: The film may not possess the emotional impact of Disney's later animated classics, but it's nevertheless a fascinating historical milestone in animation.

[Screenwriter Don] Payne crafts a couple of witty gags about how emasculating it is to date a superwoman, but most of the gags recycle the same tired old romantic comedy schtick, with special effects.

The split in My Super Ex-Girlfriend is an ugly one, separating the high-flying opening hour from its eventual crash-landing. For the underhanded villains, look no further than Reitman, writer Don Payne and a slew of superfluous special effects.
[Tarentino]'s back in high style, drawing on such sources as martial arts movies and Japanese animation to create a vivid world all his own.

movie_name: Journey to the Center of the Earth
review_content: A guilty pleasure adventure with OK special effects, but more kiddie than adult oriented.

movie_name: Journey to the Center of the Earth
review_content: By standards of the time, the special effects of Hollywood's first (but not the only) version of Jules Verne's sci-fi classic were good and nominated for Oscars; they lost out to Ben-Hur, which swept all the awards.

Making a smooth transtition from animation to live-action, Bird has directed a fast-moving, largely enagaging, well acted (especially by Renner) actioner, which is the fourth and most entertaining of the franchise.
While Brad Bird's direction is not nearly as fleet as his CV in animation would lead one to hope, it's not without its pleasures either.
I don't think I've seen a more fun straight-up action movie in ages... Director Brad Bird [has made] an astonishingly confident and distinctive leap from animation to live action...
Brad Bird's first foray outside of the world of animation is pretty much great, certainly in the top tier of 2011's 'splodey action pictures.

Better than the tower climb is the scene in which Hunt infiltrates the Kremlin with, essentially, a high-tech magic trick; the playfulness of the effect demonstrates the usefulness of Bird's background in the astonish-the-audience culture of animation.
Snagging Oscar-winning animation director Brad Bird to fill the director's chair proves to be an inspired choice--and, upon thought, a bit of a no-brainer.
While the third film made it all dark and personal, this film, thanks to some incredible special effects sequences in Dubai, elevated the series to new heights of epicness.
This is a film with its head in the clouds, its feet on the ground and -- just often enough -- its heart on its sleeve, in which space-age special effects take second place to family emotions.
The special effects and gadgetry start to detract from a human story that is only vaguely hinted at.
Save your money and time. If it weren't for the special effects blowing up the budget, this would have been just perfect as a Lifetime movie.

The special effects are quite chintzy, Sam Peckinpah casts barely a shadow of humanity - and then there's the teeming flock of birds. This is Cheez Whiz that barely cuts it as a cult staple.

Entertaining horror anthology with strong performances, decent special effects and a handful of nice ideas, though some of the stories work better than others and the film is let down by a weak linking segment.

Although special effects and careful editing pitch in, the wild-kingdom authenticity on display is an astonishing achievement.
Forget about all those fake CGI critters that have become the norm as of late ... Annaud's approach is so retro that it's practically progressive.
A really big budget movie full of action and special effects, all to make really immature jokes. I totally support that and I enjoy the exercise. It could be funnier but it's consistently pleasant.
None of this is very funny, and most of it is pretty ugly - the last half-hour or so is a paroxysm of bad special effects, amputated limbs and a severed sexual organ.

Who would have thought that a nonfiction film about spelling bees, for God's sake, would be more mesmerizing than expensive fictional flicks with oodles and oodles of production values and special effects?

Snyder, making a killer feature debut, trades homemade cheesiness for knowing style, revels in the sophistication of modern special effects, and stomps off with the best remake -- er, 're-envisioning' -- of a horror classic in memory.
The acting is better than necessary, the special effects are savage and persuasive, and the undercranked action scenes are enjoyably frenetic.

Ditching the cheeky, self-aware wink that helped to excuse the concept's inherent corniness, the movie attempts to look polished and 'cool,' but the been-there animation can't compete with the then-cutting-edge puppetry of the 1990 live-action movie.
The story's nothing special, but the movie is vigorously directed, with a camera that moves at a decidedly un-turtle-like pace. And the animation is unusually handsome.
...a burly, brawny redo, like a kiddie cartoon on CGI steroids. (Isn't TMNT what Barry Bonds was accused of using?)
A film that looks like a too-long episode of a Saturday morning cartoon with a health CGI budget.
Shedding the confines of the original 1990s live-action versions, the new TMNT runs free with crisp, malleable animation and kick-ass action.
The film suffers from serious animation overkill: too much high-octane action, too many combatants, not enough of the hand-to-hand combat that made the Turtles unique in the first place.
TMNT offers some real thrills. The computer animation gives the turtles relatively believable expressions, movements, musculature and (green) skin tones.

Might have some momentary curiosity value, like eating a sugary cereal you haven't had since third grade. Unfortunately, the movie isn't witty or imaginative or even particularly exciting, and the flat, grungy-looking animation is barely up to video-game.
The voice cast is fine, the animation is professionally done, and the script is relatively intelligent.

Cat People, director Paul Schrader's remake of a 1942 B-movie, combines explicit sex, graphic violence, special effects and the supernatural and somehow falls flat.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: [A] sharp and thrilling adventure combining 21st century animation technology with a refreshingly retro story of heroes and villains, and giant creatures that haunt the skies and seas.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: Combining atmospheric CGI backgrounds with superbly hand-drawn figures, the animation in this Arabian Nights-meets-Damon & Pythius tale is breath-taking. It's a free-wheeling, fun-filled, eye-popping summer adventure.
