movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: Apparently Dreamworks would rather put no muscle behind its finest traditional animation outing yet, a film with beautiful animation and a robust spirit.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: Apparently Dreamworks would rather put no muscle behind its finest traditional animation outing yet, a film with beautiful animation and a robust spirit.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: Dreamworks animation has a lot to live up to after Shrek, but this wacky and high-spirited version of the Sinbad legend really isn't too bad.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: Dreamworks animation has a lot to live up to after Shrek, but this wacky and high-spirited version of the Sinbad legend really isn't too bad.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: ... entertains and fully exploits all the accomplishments DreamWorks' animation department has made to this point... "Sinbad" stands as an accomplishment all on its own.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: ... entertains and fully exploits all the accomplishments DreamWorks' animation department has made to this point... "Sinbad" stands as an accomplishment all on its own.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: As routine as many live-action adventure films, right down to the competent but fairly undistinguished art and animation.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: As routine as many live-action adventure films, right down to the competent but fairly undistinguished art and animation.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: If the animation under the direction of Tim Johnson and Patrick Gilmore wasn't so compelling, you could just close your eyes and listen.

movie_name: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas
review_content: If the animation under the direction of Tim Johnson and Patrick Gilmore wasn't so compelling, you could just close your eyes and listen.
it has truly awe-inspiring stunts and special effects and many of its suspense sequences will leave you with your heart in your mouth.
Its special effects and scenery tower over its dialogue, its plotting and its character development, which are near rock bottom.

Producer Joe Pasternak is not Arthur Freed and director George Sidney is not Minnelli, but this fun and inventive musical, which blends live action and animation, has some good musical numbers, sung by Sinatra and Gene Kelly (who also choreographed).

Blood and Chocolate raises questions about the individual versus the group and tradition versus progress but...is more interested in flaunting the film's lame special effects than mining its thematic potential.

You could almost overlook the chemistry vacuum between Bruckner and Dancy, but the shots of actors leaping and morphing into wolves are so cheesy that they make the bargain-basement special effects in Teen Wolf look Oscar worthy in comparison.
Cheap special effects and banal dialogue rule.
No doubt, Finding Nemo marks yet another huge advance in the world of animation. The technical term for these advances, in layman's language, is "Holy mackerel!"
Further proof that the folks at Pixar are ceaselessly, unflaggingly more clever and imaginative than anyone else working in big-budget feature animation.
Pixar heads under the sea and finds subject matter that couldn't be more perfectly suited to its vivid style of computer animation.
Pixar's employees, masters of computer-generated animation, capture the look of the ocean like no artists before.
Proves that even when Pixar is not at the top of its game, it still produces better animation than some of its competitors on their best days.
It's full of bright visuals, inventive animation and enough cute characters to fill, well, an ocean.
There's nothing fishy about its success. It's got intriguing anthropomorphic characters, a compelling story and Pixar's fanciful computer-generated animation. It's fun, bubbly, fantastic. Sea it!
With its phenomenal animation and heart-warming story, Finding Nemo is a resounding hit with this daddy-daughter combo.
As notable for its well-crafted story as it is for its breathtaking animation.
Strikes the perfect balance between the charm and childlike innocence of Disney animation and the cutting-edge humor and hipness of the old Warner Brothers cartoons.
As with all of Pixar's earlier efforts, the animation in this movie is superb. They just keep getting better.
The plot is delightful, the animation spectacular ... the colors gorgeous, the message positive and the score by Thomas Newman fitting.
I challenge any adult to ignore the artistry of the amazing opaque jellyfish floating through the ocean. The animation is incredible.
Proof that Pixar is the Babe Ruth of animation. Still batting a thousand.
. . . the computer animation reimaginings of the undersea orgies of color orchestrated by nature are mind-blowing.
Pixar respects both kids and parents-which cannot be said for certain big green ogres of animation.
The latest feature from Pixar Animation is another splendid, eye-filling installment in the studio's unbroken string of classics.
The animation team gives weight and depth to the sea itself, filling it with specks of life and creating a sense of movement with currents and bubbles.
Although Finding Nemo reaches a new watermark in animation, it doesn't have the endearing characters or driving plot of Toy Story and Monsters, Inc. But then, classics are tough acts to follow.
Like Toy Story, A Bug's Life, and Monster's Inc., it features amazing animation, great characters, sharp wit, smart humor, and a story both timeless and timely.
It's the brilliant animation and witty script that lift this film from retread material to sublime entertainment for kids and - equally - their parents.
The best father-son story in all of Hollywood animation, and maybe animation generally...exploits the potential of computer animation like no film before it and few films after it.
'... excellent storytelling with superb, eye-popping animation...'
Fantastic animation, a great cast, and hilarious laughs make Finding Nemo a must see movie for the summer.
Tremendously well-made, marshaling the techniques of live-action filmmaking better than any CGI feature up to that point ever had.
If the Pixar vault was on fire and they could only save one film, it'd be this eminently re-watchable modern fairy tale...Looks all the more stunning with this state-of-the-art 3D retro-fit.

[VIDEO ESSAY] Disney/Pixar's 3D upgrade of its classic animated children's movie - using the expensive Xpand 3D format - has the duel effect of darkening the film's vibrant colors while adding considerable depth to the screen.
Sea-worthy w/enhanced visual lure and rich, humorous characters set in a double narrative; this 3D revisit allows us to fall overboard all over again.
If ever there was a film that wasn't broke, this is it. So naturally they converted it into 3D for a special re-release this weekend. (Stupid irony.)
The 3D gives the images a little more depth but they already had heft and weight. The 3D is a money-making gimmick, nothing more.
Finding Nemo 3D is a quality post-conversion experience that successfully enhances the 2003 film's original standout visuals.
Re-releasing Nemo in 3D gives a whole new generation the chance to enjoy it in cinemas for the first time - as well as adding extra depth to the wonderful scenes from the ocean deep.
The animation is so sleek and the action so perfectly paced that even the sharpest viewer could be forgiven for overlooking some unimportant lapses in internal logic.
Pixar's fourth feature for Disney is yet another miracle of computer animation, an instant classic, but with less of the surface brightness of Toy Story or Monsters, Inc.
The latest flood of wizardry from Pixar, whose productions, from Toy Story onward, have lent an indispensable vigor and wit to the sagging art of mainstream animation.
It looks great, of course: All the Pixar movies do. But the genius of those other movies lay in their actual stories -- stories as inspired as the animation.
Visually, Finding Nemo is spectacular. The animators render theses scenes with exquisite detail and vibrant color, reaching beyond mere CGI-wizardry to artistry.
The animation in Finding Nemo is quite breathtaking and this movie, created by Pixar, the same outfit that made Toy Story, looks like The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau.
while it touts its technological influence, Tron is actually more instructive a model for the special effects extravaganzas that continue to litter the multiplex.
Tron looks almost as startling as it did when I was much shorter, largely because the designs by Moebius and Syd Mead complemented the austere style of early CGI.
The special effects are dated, but at the time they were awesome.
Aside from CGI sequences, there's nothing compelling here.
The movie's innovative digital special effects were jaw-dropping at the time and still seem pretty cool. But somehow the plot congeals early into an old-time medieval epic and gets pretty dull.
Tron didn't just come up with a new special effects, it came up with new things to use those new kinds of special effects on.
For most people, TRON's importance is as a historical footnote. It's the Model T of our CGI age. But the film's fans are passionate ones.
There's an undeniable cart-before-the-horse aspect to Tron...but Lisberger's film will always stand as a touchstone in the development of CGI as a storytelling tool... [Blu-ray]
While its visual effects have aged laughably poorly, the movie can be quite lovely to look at, particularly since its CGI isn't trying to represent anything more realistic than 1982-era CGI.
This was the rebirth of Disney in the modern era and due to superb songs, enduring humour and a touching plot it remains an animation classic.
Its exuberance and humor made animation hip again.
A marvel of skillful animation, witty songwriting and smart planning.
The Little Mermaid revitalized the notion of what can be achieved with pen and ink, and once again put Disney in an unreachable top spot as the undisputed king of animation studios.
The hand-drawn animation is terrific, and the soundtrack, which includes Part of Your World, Under the Sea and Kiss the Girl, is among Disney's best.
Relying on a simple, recognized tale, great songs and marvellous animation, it turned its fortunes around.

Within the apparently necessary aesthetic and ideological limitations (such as making the hero and heroine Americans surrounded by foreign servants a la Pinocchio), the animation manages to be fairly energetic.
The long-awaited proof that Disney animation could, in fact, return almost the quality and beauty of its Golden Age.
The latest Disney offering looks back to the studio's unrivaled heritage. It has the look of classic animation. More important, it has the skill required to make it work.
While hand-drawn animation may be a thing of the past, The Little Mermaid beautifully holds up some thirty years later.
Reign of Fire is more than competent, with the action and the special effects, and even shows flashes of humor. The movie is not, alas, so diligent about making sure its story makes sense.
Reign of Fire is more than competent, with the action and the special effects, and even shows flashes of humor. The movie is not, alas, so diligent about making sure its story makes sense.
The film is all special effects and testosteronic bellowing by Matthew McConaughey and Christian Bale.
The film is all special effects and testosteronic bellowing by Matthew McConaughey and Christian Bale.
Peaks early with a vertiginous dogfight; thereafter, spotty CGI and a bamboozling plot conspire toward a colossal anticlimax.
Peaks early with a vertiginous dogfight; thereafter, spotty CGI and a bamboozling plot conspire toward a colossal anticlimax.
There's the bad CGI, the choppy pacing, the comically intense acting, the repetition, the dullness and mostly the idiot plot.
There's the bad CGI, the choppy pacing, the comically intense acting, the repetition, the dullness and mostly the idiot plot.
Wouldn't you have thought that a studio about to spend over $90,000,000 on a movie would have begun with a script instead of a few special effects?
Wouldn't you have thought that a studio about to spend over $90,000,000 on a movie would have begun with a script instead of a few special effects?
Reign Of Fire should at least be a marvel of special effects, but alas, even the dragon's not very much fun.
Reign Of Fire should at least be a marvel of special effects, but alas, even the dragon's not very much fun.
Garners so much potential for a large exciting universe, but is just a waste of acting talent, special effects and money
Garners so much potential for a large exciting universe, but is just a waste of acting talent, special effects and money

The characters are sketchy, the plot is full of logical holes and the story is all fight and flight. But despite its flaws, it is enjoyable if you like special effects, warriors and computer-generated dragons.

The characters are sketchy, the plot is full of logical holes and the story is all fight and flight. But despite its flaws, it is enjoyable if you like special effects, warriors and computer-generated dragons.
During the Summer of 3D glasses, "The Kids are All Right" proves that what you really need to create an immersive, real-life film experience is a sharp pencil and some interesting friends.
The CGI wonks here have created a beaut ... Watching him clumsily gallumpf through the tall grass at top speed in search of vittles is worth a few bucks, at least.
The CGI wonks here have created a beaut ... Watching him clumsily gallumpf through the tall grass at top speed in search of vittles is worth a few bucks, at least.
A mountain of bad writing, a confusing plot, atrocious jokes and surprisingly bad special effects.
Wild Wild West is a comedy dead zone. You stare in disbelief as scenes flop and die. The movie is all concept and no content; the elaborate special effects are like watching money burn on the screen.
fun, special effects, and action right up to the climax where "WWW" wanes into a "B+".

Ruled by increasingly ghoulish special effects, it leaves reality so far behind that its storytelling would be arbitrary even by comic-book standards, and its characters share no common ground or emotional connection.
The effects are done well, but we are long past the era in which good special effects alone could carry a movie.
The gimmicky, light-hearted 1960s TV series comes to the screen as an ungainly, clanking, gooey box of eye candy, a vehicle for star Will Smith and special effects supervisor Eric Brevig.

Wild, Wild West poses this not very pressing question: Can a comedy costing something north of $100 million hope to succeed solely on the basis of special effects, cross-dressing and a vertically challenged villain?
Forget all the ruinously expensive special effects. They're not worth a minute of your time, much less two hours of mind-boggling mediocrity.
These actors, alas, are at the service of a submoronic script and special effects that look like a video game writ large.
It is a fairly shallow action movie and it delivers on that level with plenty of action, engaging characters, competent acting, good pacing, good special effects and a solid plot.

Though it features some of the most exquisite animation ever put to film, it falls short of the benchmark set by the peerless triptych of Ratatouille, WALL-E, and Up released at the end of the last decade.

A grizzly bear playing charades is one of the funniest moments in this enchanting 3D Pixar animation set in the rugged Scottish highlands in which myths, traditions and matters of the heart are shaken like a cocktail

A grizzly bear playing charades is one of the funniest moments in this enchanting 3D Pixar animation set in the rugged Scottish highlands in which myths, traditions and matters of the heart are shaken like a cocktail

The animation studio's first film with a female protagonist, a defiant lass who acts as a much-welcome corrective to retrograde Disney heroines of the past and the company's unstoppable pink-princess merchandising.

It wasn't enough that Disney already made a direct-to-video sequel to Brother Bear, but now the company that changed the future of animation has gone hopelessly into the past to deliver a story with even less consequence.
After the successive triumphs of the past decade, it's hard to accept anything less than transcendence from the animation studio.
Although Pixar purists may not approve, Brave is a wonderful family movie and still a great example of what Pixar does best - smart dialogue and amazing animation with lots of heart.
We would expect this kind of overstuffed joyride from Dreamworks Animation or the folks at Fox or even Disney itself. But it's terribly ordinary for Pixar, and ordinary is no longer enough.

If you have kids, you'll want to take them to Brave, and they'll almost certainly have a good time. If you're an animation buff, you may have quibbles with the film, which looks great but isn't up to Pixar's high standards in terms of story.
"Brave" is truly a remarkable adventure in 3-D. The animation is marvelous.
It's disappointing that the team of writers, including Andrews and Chapman, failed to redefine what it means to be a heroine in big-budget animation.
Great CGI animation doesn't compensate for forgettable characters, an uneven tone, and a banal story that fails to pack enough of a comedic, imaginative and emotional punch.
Great CGI animation doesn't compensate for forgettable characters, an uneven tone, and a banal story that fails to pack enough of a comedic, imaginative and emotional punch.

Brave's wonderful animation, hilarious comedy, excellent voice cast and Pixar's first female lead character is compromised by its lack-of-faith decision to switch mid-plot to a tired, silly device that's unworthy of everything that came before it.
Plenty of adventure, laughs and Pixar's quality animation.
A spunky red haired heroine and truly magical animation make this another winner for Pixar
... has the customary supple Pixar animation ... [but] the story lacks punch ...
A charming and vibrant new member of the Disney/Pixar stable. And the heroine's flaming red hair is at last something that makes the fuss over 3D worthwhile.
This is a simpler, more childlike picture than we are used to from the world's leading animation company, but none the worse for that.

The plot - involving a wicked witch, an endangered parent and a race to reverse a spell - is decidedly oxidized. Even the young girl's unruly mane is the color of rust. But the animation is pure state of the art.

The story for this revisionist fairy tale, which promotes contemporary attitudes about parenting and gender equality, is less inspired than usual for Pixar, but the movie upholds the studio's high standard of computer animation.
It practically goes without saying that the animation in Brave is frequently breathtaking.
Really, the lack of creativity from the most imaginative of animation studios is astonishing here.
Still a grand biblical epic that's just a notch below "Ben-Hur" in terms of its performances, narrative drama, and special effects.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The film will no doubt please the fans, with its fantastical 3D special effects and spectacular New Zealand locations, although the storytelling is convoluted and muddled

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The film will no doubt please the fans, with its fantastical 3D special effects and spectacular New Zealand locations, although the storytelling is convoluted and muddled

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: While Dawn Treader is competent enough, with good special effects, it never rises to great heights. There's something a little stolid and bland about it, even when the fantasy elements are at the fore.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: Their mission - for reasons that are not fully explained - is to locate the seven swords of the lost Lords of Narnia, and to use them to save this world from ... something. Uhh, quick a distraction! Look, special effects!

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The special effects can hardly be classified as special (although a post-production conversion to 3D can take some of the blame). The acting of the young, plummy-talking cast is bland and rough editing of key scenes will leave some viewers puzzled.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The special effects can hardly be classified as special (although a post-production conversion to 3D can take some of the blame). The acting of the young, plummy-talking cast is bland and rough editing of key scenes will leave some viewers puzzled.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: Pausing the special effects kills the established oomph, bestowing tedious exposition to actors who aren't skilled enough to make their transformations interesting, led around by an overwhelmed Apted.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The best thing about the film is neither the top-notch CGI nor the shallow moral lessons but the performance of Will Poulter as Lucy and Edmund's insufferable cousin Eustace Scrubb.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The beguiling creature design -- from minotaur to dragon, sea serpent to one-footed dwarf -- and 3D effects heighten the illusion of a storybook coming alive.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: This is designed to keep the children happy over the Christmas period and fans of CS Lewis will enjoy the fact that it's a pretty faithful adaptation. But those wanting something different from the usual CGI extravaganza would do well to look elsewher

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: The cinematography is gorgeous and the fusion of CGI and real characters seamless. Even more outstanding is the script that never stalls and blends characters, plot, and themes in ways that entertain and inspire.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
review_content: Apted's ultimate downfall is the over-utilization of special effects in a film that simply doesn't require them to such excess.
The first computer-animated feature to come from Aardman Animations is filled with exuberant and infectious silliness.

Flushed Away, the new feature from Aardman Animations, revels in its British-ness -- it's full of bone-dry wit, football references, and ribs on the French -- and I was hooked from the first shot of Tower Bridge.
Digital animation has elbowed claymation out of the frame and a certain frenetic coarsening has settled over Aardman's latest.
With Flushed Away, Aardman [Animations] has moved away from a guy and his dog to a girl and her mouse, but they're almost just as fun.
This delightful computer animation is less twee than Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit, with more action and a broader American sensibility.
Flushed Away was made by Aardman Animation, which also did Chicken Run and the Wallace and Gromit films. Flushed Away is not in their rarefied league, but it's pretty clever, anyway.

An adventure that -- in both its breathtaking ingenuity and breathless excitement -- exceeds Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit and Chicken Run, the two previous collaborations between DreamWorks Animation and Aardman Features.
...by every [criterion other than the animation quality], Flushed Away is marvelous, with an unbeatable cast bringing the most to a script that is already hilarious.
Actually, a lot about the film is certified cool, from its whirly animation to the hordes of crunchy pop songs on the soundtrack.

Though Flushed Away duplicates the stop-motion, clay animation look of Aardman's earlier Chicken Run and Wallace & Gromit, it was made using computer software and its liberated action sequences are truly dazzling.

The animation, computer-generated as opposed to Aardman's signature claymation style, pops with clever visual touches, and the voice cast, led by the omnipresent and ever likable Hugh Jackman as Roddy, is first-rate.
A delightfully silly and laugh-out-loud funny animated comedy, Flushed Away bodes happily for future collaborations between DreamWorks Animation and Aardman Features.
Flushed Away is a very fine addition to the animation art form.
Many hands, including many writers, applied themselves to Flushed Away (doesn't that usually require just one hand?). The result is committee animation: cute, fast, uninspired, softly consumable.
Despite the switch from stop-motion to CGI, the hallmarks of a typical Aardman production are intact, right down to the characters' round eyes and prominent teeth.

This melding of claymation and CGI is absolutely perfect, beautifully combining the wonderfully organic feel of Aardman's hand-built sets and lovingly breathed-into-life clay figures with DreamWorks' sleek computer cartoons.

Exciting, adventurous, and flush with visual and verbal gags, Aardman's latest stands out from the many other children's animations released this year because it seems a labour of love rather than a soulless commodity.
Nice action, fun animation, good voice acting, mediocre to dull story. In the end it all balances out.
Jean-Pierre Jeunet represents that select group of filmmakers who treat special effects as their own art.

The Tale of Despereaux looks like it was made about 10 years ago and, at a time when even mediocre animated films can generally boast a stunning look, this movie's uninspired animation is a source of disappointment.
While it meanders on its way to the requisite happy ending, the lush, stylised animation and courtly flourishes would win over anyone.
The animation is striking precisely because it doesn't look like a cartoon... It's a fairy tale world that seems to sprawl beyond the edges of the screen.
It's charming, with gorgeous, painterly animation and a heartfelt story.
I admired the craft more than I loved the results. But The Tales of Despereaux is still better-than-average animation.
While it meanders on its way to the requisite happy ending, the lush, stylised animation and courtly flourishes would win over anyone.
It is all nicely animated, and has a great voice cast, but is not really special or magical enough to really crack the ultra-competitive kiddie animation market.

The Tale of Despereaux's heart is in the right place, but the script is messy and unfocussed, the animation is dull and uninspired, the characters are boring and the film manages to completely waste the talents of its fantastic cast.
The animation quality is first rate.
For animation fans looking for a little more class and a lot less of the commonplace crass, this makes for a decent timepass.
If you're an animation fan, don't wait for the DVD - The Tale Of Despereaux deserves to be seen on the big screen.
Scratch a CGI fairytale and you'll find an allegory about class, particularly if rodents are involved.

Modernizing a 1970s children's TV show known for its cheap special effects offered certain possibilities, but the filmmakers have traded in any kid-friendly elements for bathroom humor of dinosaur-sized proportions.
A soulless special effects flick crossed with a tired gross-out comedy.

The original was unbelievably cheesy in its special effects but more sophisticated in its concepts, employing real science-fiction writers to work up ideas. Will Ferrell and partners have succeeded in reversing those priorities in this spoof.
Land of the Lost has decent special effects but ultimately fails thanks to a poorly written script, a general lack of imagination, a series of painfully unfunny gags.
...a well-made throwback to the days of old, when telling a story was what mattered; not special effects or flashy editing.
Stallone still mumbles the lines, but his timing is pretty good and the jokes are well done. Violent as the film is, the special effects and stunts are impressive, especially the ax fight at the end.
Though the disparate narrative threads are well integrated the film still lags periodically, but its real liability is on the special effects front.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Japanese Movies', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Drama', 'Family Film']
review_content: Its charms hold up exceptionally well, in part because it grows along with its audience. Few stories carry that kind of power, and fewer pieces of animation can bring it so marvelously to life.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Japanese Movies', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Drama', 'Family Film']
review_content: This is a surreal, highly enjoyable tale which mixes fun animation, imagery, and symbols to make a truly unique experience.
Though it never completely catches fire, there's enough earnestness and warmth that makes it a welcome alternative in a family film arena dominated by computer animation and associated toy lines.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
review_content: It is truly strange that a film setting out to be pure entertainment, so full of stars and special effects, should be so mortifyingly dull - although, then again, as Dr Johnson said: "Nothing is more hopeless than a scheme of merriment."

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
review_content: Johnny Depp's alcoholic, asexual, speech-slurring sea captain, flat 3D that darkens the picture considerably, and nonsensical stories are surely passé by now.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
review_content: Watching this film in 3D is like trying to eat your dinner with a sheet of plastic wrap over it.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
review_content: This film, despite its dazzling special effects, is devoid of originality, character and human values. It is the very embodiment of what is wrong with popular entertainment.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
review_content: The action ... ranges from fun swashbuckling, to tedious parrying, to outright terribly edited, CGI funk that completely defies any kind of physical presence.

It looks like most of the money spent in this project went to explosions, which are many and huge, and to acting salaries, at the expense of special effects and the script, which could have used a big upgrade.
Quit it with the CGI blood spurts.

The Expendables is more than just your average action movie; it is the action movie of the year uniting the grittiness and soul of the old genre with the special effects and coolness of the new genre. See it.
A nice looking but heavily formulaic DreamWorks animation entry.

Even though Panda is one of the last animated flicks that Dreamworks won't be making in 3D it's still very easy on the eyes and it should help to keep the studio in competition this summer with the juggernaut that is Pixar.
If the Shaw Brothers had access to CGI and the post-modern voice talent, Kung Fu Panda would have definitely been part of their stable of wuxia epics.

an agreeable enough animation with the kid-worthy message to believe in oneself, but the embarrassment of riches that is its superstar vocal cast provides poor returns...Jackie Chan hired to make monkey noises?
[DreamWorks Animation] has finally found their successor to the "Shrek" mantle in the hapless hero known as Po the Panda.
What helps Kung Fu Panda succeed is not just the classic beauty of the animation but also another way it avoids the Shrek pitfall by steering clear of that series' flat irony and tired snark.

Sticking to a tried-and-true formula (hapless underdog discovers he's the Chosen One) still proves effective when it's done with a snappy pace, eye-popping animation and a cast of game comedic vocal talents headed by Jack Black.

In this summer movie season of old men with whips, gals in stilettos and superheroes a go-go, you may ask: "Where's the cartoon?" (Speed Racer doesn't count.) Indeed, the most highly anticipated animation event of the summer is Kung Fu Panda

Resistance is not just futile but almost seems churlish in the black-and-white face of such cuteness. Along with some terrific voice performances and lovely animation, the adorability quotient of Kung Fu Panda buoys the film.
The animation is dazzling, so lovingly detailed you can make out individual hairs on the titular beastie, and full of bright Chinese images.
DreamWorks Animation's best movie since Shrek.
The animation is consistently sporty and there are some choice comic riffs on martial arts movies.
Kung Fu Panda illustrates the dilemma CGI movies find themselves in: They're suspended on a rickety bridge between product and moviemaking, and the boards of our interest are beginning to rot away.
...use[s] dynamic animation and slapstick humor to compensate for the story's lack of originality.
The movie easily karate chops the weekend competition. A fine, fun film, filled with excellent animation and well-drawn characters.
The open got my interest up because the animation style recalled the Emmy-winning Cartoon Network show Samurai Jack. Unfortunately, when the dream ends, so does the innovative visual style...
By far the most visually appealing film yet released by DreamWorks Animation.
... Dreamworks Animation has finally managed to touch the brass ring of animated storytelling that has been exclusively in Pixar's reach for over a decade.

Filled with abundant slapstick and visual comedy, this family-friendly animation is sure to amuse the youngsters with its roly-poly panda hero antics and inventive effects. ...its predictable and formulaic script is less impressive
This is the finest DreamWorks Animation effort since the first Shrek
This is strictly formulaic animation from DreamWorks, wasting a stellar cast and a marvellously high concept idea.
Despite the traditional animation platitudes, the film is entertaining and well voiced.
Hands down the most visually striking of DreamWorks Animation's releases, this lively CGI comedy is tailor-made for Jack Black.
Hands down the most visually striking of DreamWorks Animation's releases, this lively CGI comedy is tailor-made for Jack Black.

Kung Fu Panda offers little in the way of cartoon novelty. Even the battle scenes, given the recent advances in live-action wirework and blending of stunt performers and special effects, are too little kung fu, too much ho-hum.
...relies on the sounds of its voice cast and the brilliance of its CGI animation to help it succeed.
...relies on the sounds of its voice cast and the brilliance of its CGI animation to help it succeed.
The animation work is dazzling; it's lovingly detailed without being overdone (particularly the opening sequence, which is hand-drawn and looks like prints struck from ancient woodblocks).
Well, for a kiddie animation spectacle I'd give it more than a passing grade.
Good performances, excellent special effects, impeccable animation... [Full review in Spanish]
Good performances, excellent special effects, impeccable animation... [Full review in Spanish]
'Kung Fu Panda' was an evolutionary jump in what the Dreamworks animation had offered until then. [Full Review in Spanish]
Although this movie is old, and was made with minimal effects, it is still creepy - much more so than any contemporary vampire story or overblown CGI ghost tale.
Although this movie is old, and was made with minimal effects, it is still creepy - much more so than any contemporary vampire story or overblown CGI ghost tale.

Faithful in substantial degree not only to the letter but also the spirit of the 1933 classic for RKO, this $22 million-+ version neatly balances superb special effects with solid dramatic credibility.
The special effects are marvelous, the good-humored script is comic-bookish without being excessively campy, and there are two excellent performances
Abundant action scenes that exhilarate the spatial senses and kept the CGI team harnessed to their workstations.
Abundant action scenes that exhilarate the spatial senses and kept the CGI team harnessed to their workstations.

Spider-Man 2 is full of bright colors, emphatic noises and elaborate special effects. That much is to be expected. But its distinguishing features, I'm happy to report, are strong characters and honest feelings.

Spider-Man 2 is full of bright colors, emphatic noises and elaborate special effects. That much is to be expected. But its distinguishing features, I'm happy to report, are strong characters and honest feelings.
Spider-Man 2 has all manner of fancy CGI improvements on its precursor, but in the end it's the old-style action sequences that carry it.
Spidie's new archenemy Doc Ock is the coolest villain created by the DNA (Digital + Natural = an Awesome-effect) melding of actor and CGI wizardry to date! READ ON->

This triumphant sequel to the hard-to-top 2002 original may be the first great comic-book movie in the age of self-help and CGI wizardry, an entertainment in which both the thrills and the therapeutic personal growth are well earned.
The new, improved SM2 has a far smoother narrative line, as well as more amazing special effects, including even more terrific swinging.
A rare sequel that surpasses the original in every way -- in story, in setting, in special effects, in high-energy action and in its surprising depth of emotion.

The digital special effects -- especially those glorious, block-long Tarzan-style web swings up and down the city boulevards are exhilarating and wonderful to watch, even better than they were the first time around.

The digital special effects -- especially those glorious, block-long Tarzan-style web swings up and down the city boulevards are exhilarating and wonderful to watch, even better than they were the first time around.
Dead on in its ability to blend wonderful comedy, mind-blowing action, touching romance, superb special effects, and dazzling set pieces, all while remaining sublimely artistic.
Dead on in its ability to blend wonderful comedy, mind-blowing action, touching romance, superb special effects, and dazzling set pieces, all while remaining sublimely artistic.
By focusing on his characters as much as his special effects, Sam Raimi has made that rare sequel, one that's every bit as good as the original.
By focusing on his characters as much as his special effects, Sam Raimi has made that rare sequel, one that's every bit as good as the original.
The film strikes just the right balance between dizzying aerial action (with special effects and high-flying fisticuffs far more heart-stopping than in the original) and grounded human drama.
The film strikes just the right balance between dizzying aerial action (with special effects and high-flying fisticuffs far more heart-stopping than in the original) and grounded human drama.
For summer popcorn fun, this movie has it all: special effects, romance, action and humor.
For summer popcorn fun, this movie has it all: special effects, romance, action and humor.
Spider-Man 2 is not a great movie. It is, however, a great superhero movie, one of the best ever made. If only its influence could more clearly be felt in the "Avengers" CGI-fests of today.
Spider-Man 2 is not a great movie. It is, however, a great superhero movie, one of the best ever made. If only its influence could more clearly be felt in the "Avengers" CGI-fests of today.
[Combines the] idealism, action-adventure, and the requisite special effects with some of the gentle humor and romance that characterized the original television series.
[Combines the] idealism, action-adventure, and the requisite special effects with some of the gentle humor and romance that characterized the original television series.

The extravagant makeup and special effects are actually unobtrusive because they're demanded by the pleasantly formulaic story, whose conflicts--and broad, innocuous political allegory -- justify the heartwarming resolution.

The extravagant makeup and special effects are actually unobtrusive because they're demanded by the pleasantly formulaic story, whose conflicts--and broad, innocuous political allegory -- justify the heartwarming resolution.
The production values and special effects have improved significantly, giving the proceedings a shine and polish very suiting to these sci-fi adventures.
The production values and special effects have improved significantly, giving the proceedings a shine and polish very suiting to these sci-fi adventures.

The animation shows glossy improvement from the original Madagascar, with nature and the neo-natural animals even more detailed than ever. But the knock on Dreamworks' animation style -- that it's entirely too talky -- rings true here.

You can't fault DreamWorks for including what Disney's animated tales conspicuously leave out -- gags pitched at adults. Plus, the CGI has improved since the first film, with animal fur being ruffled in all the right places.
Looks marvelous--the animation really is superb--but it's not even up to the standard of the initial installment in any other significant respect.
The four-year olds out their will love the funny animals, music and flashy animation. Unfortunately, I am not a four-year old....
Directors Darnell and McGrath's follow-up would undoubtedly have benefited from more innovation or daring, but its vibrant animation and innocuously rollicking comedy remains endearing
Typical tale of self-discovery, punctuated by genuine hilarity and top-flight animation.
A decent-enough sequel that will satisfy fans without unduly bothering Oscar animation voters.
The animation is sharp, and whenever things start to get confusing, a penguin or lemur comes onscreen and does something really funny.
Definitely not a film for the ages, and you might not even remember it by the end of the year, but as it is, it's a reasonably pleasant, amusing and diverting bit of animation.
Animation holds everything together with aplomb, injecting the whirlwind picture with plenty of attitude and jokes.

Can't quite make it to the front of the pride. The animation is fine; a lot of the lines are snappy; there are a few nicely absurd situations. But each main character gets a semi-intriguing subplot that isn't developed, then disappears. The pace hobbles.
Stronger animation and a textured story make this even more entertaining than the original

This crackingly entertaining sequel is great fun, blending beautiful animation with genuinely funny jokes. In truth it tries to pack in a sub-plot too far, but what the heck - this is great entertainment.

The biggest draw here isn't the sub-sitcom schtick but the super-hi-definition CGI panoramas - make sure you see this in Imax, where your eyeballs have enough room to roam over the impressive wide vista bits.
Whatever else I felt about the movie, this is good animation. The colours are extraordinary, the backgrounds stunning.
The animation is as breathtakingly beautiful as before and if anything, the sequel is funnier and sharper than the original thanks to a witty screenplay.
Definitely a step down from the first one, but you should not let that stop you from seeing a film with great humor and animation.
A Disney animation classic for all ages and all times.
Watchmen is a spectacular visual treat, with special effects to match the ambition of the story. It is way too long... but there is no denying it is a seriously cool and bloody superhero epic.
It's the moments when Bayer goes off-book that are most effective, using modern special effects to augment the dreams in ways that weren't possibly back in the day, on a budget.
Underwhelmingly written and overwhelmingly produced, Battleship is a silly, formualic picture dominated by action set-pieces and CGI effects.

Titanic meets The Transformers in a film that suffers from having to hold its heading in the wake of The Avengers. Still, a genius CGI team enables Peter Berg to maintain larger-than-life disaster, epic action and futurism with audacious buoyancy.
Over-the-top sci-fi action with great special effects.
Battleship is an alien invasion flick with too earnest dialogue and ear-splitting explosions. Yet, everything works: the special effects, the performances, the breakneck pace.
A long, vapid and tedious orgasm of CGI effects that will leave you exacerbated.
Terrific! Fantastic special effects highlight this high-tension film of ordinary mortals who can die if things go wrong in a fight to the finish against aliens.
The CGI looks as good as it ought to given the criminally large budget, but the action is perfunctory and unimaginative.
Once the special effects take over, Berg has little room to assert his personality (or tell a story, for that matter), and the movie feels like a chore.
Full of action and good special effects, but cheesy dialogue and a throw away plot eventually sink it.

Very tame but marginally better than the first, with the Daleks unsurprisingly coming to grief after invading a ruined London of the future and robotising the inhabitants. Very variable special effects and often excruciatingly cheapo sets.
For its time, this is an impressive piece of work. Though it looks a bit stagey, the sets, like the script, are well designed to let simple special effects have maximum impact.

This whizzy and outrageously colourful family action romp is a visually breathtaking hybrid of animation and live action. The story may feel about as gripping as a videogame, but the film is pure eye candy.

This whizzy and outrageously colourful family action romp is a visually breathtaking hybrid of animation and live action. The story may feel about as gripping as a videogame, but the film is pure eye candy.
The color is beautiful. That's the only good thing I can say about this film that consists of about 15 minutes of dialogue and 120 minutes of mind-numbing special effects.
The color is beautiful. That's the only good thing I can say about this film that consists of about 15 minutes of dialogue and 120 minutes of mind-numbing special effects.
The actors are lost amidst the orgy of pixels writhing around like the special effects equivalent of a bukkake film
The actors are lost amidst the orgy of pixels writhing around like the special effects equivalent of a bukkake film

Creating visual styles that break boundaries is what the Wachowskis do best; Speed Racer is a thrilling triumph of multi-layered visual storytelling, combining CGI with live action & involving mind boggling race sequences using virtual real-life locations

Creating visual styles that break boundaries is what the Wachowskis do best; Speed Racer is a thrilling triumph of multi-layered visual storytelling, combining CGI with live action & involving mind boggling race sequences using virtual real-life locations

Speed Racer is a masterpiece of its kind, and a definitive benchmark for film not only as a special effects extravaganza but as the moment when the Wachowskis went from wunderkind directors to true auteurs.

Speed Racer is a masterpiece of its kind, and a definitive benchmark for film not only as a special effects extravaganza but as the moment when the Wachowskis went from wunderkind directors to true auteurs.
The brothers swamp the fragile story and characters with such a deluge of CGI tricks and elaborate action sequences that it proves hard to care about the humans on screen.
The brothers swamp the fragile story and characters with such a deluge of CGI tricks and elaborate action sequences that it proves hard to care about the humans on screen.
Brad Pitt, zombies and an all-out assault of chaos, stunts, 3D special effects and a surprisingly good script all resonate in this hero's journey with scale, style and bite
Brad Pitt, zombies and an all-out assault of chaos, stunts, 3D special effects and a surprisingly good script all resonate in this hero's journey with scale, style and bite
Other than the CGI eye candy, which is intense, there is little in the way of layers and complexity to this portrait of pandemonium.
Thrilling special effects and a global scale almost make up for World War Z's perfunctory zombie movie cliches.

One thing Forster's done well is convey the sheer speed in which a major city can be brought down by the undead...Of course, the decision to convert all this to 3D simply means that many of these quick moving action scenes become a chaotic blur...
If it weren't propelled by Brad Pitt's star power, this would be just another apocalyptic, sci-fi zombie thriller with some massive, starkly memorable special effects.
By the end, I was impressed with the epic scale of the story, the expensive special effects and the high production values, but I also had a distinct feeling of 'is that all there is?'
While the 3D effect helped increase the intensity of the film, I can only hope a sequel will fill in some of the story that is dangling in some areas.

Joost and Schulman's analog hack on the expectation of slow-burn scares is fun in short, concentrated bursts. But by the time cut-rate CGI and musty mythology force their way in, it abides by the same rickety revisionism that did in the "Saw" films.
Paranormal Activity 3 delivers, and does it without gore or "look at me!" special effects.
A film without interest, wit, imagination or even entertaining violence and special effects.
A film without interest, wit, imagination or even entertaining violence and special effects.
Cruise and Fanning give Oscar-caliber performances. The special effects are mind-boggling. This is a thoroughly enjoyable film if you forget the silly Hollywood ending.
a roller-coaster of special effects as Ray and his family escape from ever more hair-raising dangers in ever more improbable, but oddly fun ways.
The destruction is so vivid and quick, and the CGI looks so real that somewhere Independence Day is whimpering in the corner.
[O]nce you get over your initial sense of awe at the special effects, you're left with the feeling that you're being hit over the head repeatedly.
An intense sci fi experience that should satisfy viewers who crave both expensive special effects and intimate human drama, assuming that such an audience exists.
Surprisingly dark for a blockbuster and delivers handsomely in terms of thrills and special effects.
This new yarn about survivors of a tunnel collapse shows that it is still possible to deliver heart-stopping action, stunts and special effects without an Uzi in sight.
A combination splatter flick and demon child extravaganza that succeeds in bloody special effects but fails to become an actual movie.

A PlayStation game come to life, XXX is a movie almost exclusively dependent on the special effects department and the charm of its leading man, Vin Diesel. But it's sound and fury signifying nothing.
The animation is grand, and the lovely images may be enough to send really young kids away happy. Their parents might leave feeling they've been taken in by some carny sleight-of-hand, though.
It's a deluxe 3D journey that kids will love and many adults should hail as worth the detour.
A culture change is clearly taking place at DreamWorks Animation. Hallelujah.
The first two Madagascar's were pretty boring and strictly for kids. With great 3D and a little more fun, adults you have permission to like this one.
The kids loved it. The adults loved it. This means it's a sure thing if you're looking for a family movie outing. Go check it out in 3D and everyone should be happy.
A vivacious 3D kaleidoscope of colour, dazzle and show, this third in the franchise simply bursts with joie de vivre, goofy humour and innovative ideas
Dreamworks have outdone themselves with the glorious 3D rendering in Madagascar 3, especially with the circus scenes, accompanied by the modern dance-pop soundtrack.

Easily the best film of the franchise so far, thanks to a witty script, colourful new characters, lively animation, inspired direction and some impressive 3D work, not to mention some exceptional comic timing.

Easily the best film of the franchise so far, thanks to a witty script, colourful new characters, lively animation, inspired direction and some impressive 3D work, not to mention some exceptional comic timing.

"The best of the Madagascar films" might not be the most ringing endorsement ever committed to newsprint, but DreamWorks Animation has finally found the franchise's groove in this pyrotechnic third instalment.
This is animation that never just goes through the motions but glories in its feats and so, almost certainly, will you.
It may lack a little in charm and warmth, but the technical brilliance and decent use of 3D go some way towards compensating for the dimensions that the film otherwise lacks.
The first-class 3D animation is better than the cliche-ridden script.
The first-class 3D animation is better than the cliche-ridden script.
The animation is largely excellent -- particularly in the circus sequences -- and the colorful, vibrant visuals look especially impressive in 3D.

A truly out-there piece of comic animation, the most outlandishly visual film of the year, this 80-minute French treat takes us into a world that can barely be described, a world unlike any we've seen before.
many notable moments of animation excellence
International story of bicycling, rescue, singing, the passage of time and the nature of evil is a fantastic use of animation for grown-up storytelling.
Chomet has made a refreshing film set apart by its humour, unique cultural flavour and quality animation.
Dazzling in the simplest of ways putting Sylvain Chomet at the animation's adult table that still has plenty of room for the kids.
Like a silent film that just happens to be drawn instead of made with real people - it's absolutely mesmerizing to look at this animation.
A strange delight, an original vision that enhances the state of contemporary animation.

Most of the magic of this unusual movie comes from the freshness, imagination and sweet spirit of its animation, which is blissfully its own thing and does not show the influence of any of the reigning forces in the art form.
A strange and wonderful tale that relies on and indulges in the luxuries of hand-drawn animation
A sensational counterpoint to everything animation means as family entertainment in Hollywood.

If you have an open mind, and an appreciation of film animation, you will surely enjoy the film's clever gags, as well as the sensational blending of cel animation and computer-enhanced backgrounds and action.
The Triplets of Belleville proves there's still plenty of life in hand-drawn animation.
Animation was invented so that movies like The Triplets of Belleville could be made.
It's a must-see for animation fans, but others, including youngsters, may just as likely be bored or baffled.
If Walt Disney had gone on a binge of red wine, hallucinatory drugs and absurdist plays, The Triplets of Belleville could have sprouted from his animation empire.

It's impossible to watch this movie without gasping at its graphics, and yet we're so drawn into Chomet's way of seeing that, after a while, his genius erases the distinction between animation and live action.
Chomet made this movie to remind us how imaginative animation can be as an art form.
Beautiful animation, surreal imagery, funny quirky characters and engaging situations make this a gem that should be discovered.
Just when Jeffrey Katzenberg had loudly declared the death of 2-D animation, along came this sly, inventively drawn cartoon that blew the cumbrous studio leviathans out of the water.

A wonderfully weird bit of French animation that amounts to little but a celebration of its creator's bountiful imagination, yet manages to enthrall because writer-director Sylvain Chomet is such a solid visual storyteller.
A shimmering, knowing homage to the beginnings of sound animation.
This is less a reimagining than a reanimation of the long dead corpse of an idea.
With a cheerful disregard for characterization and visual texture, Anderson relies on his cgi-jocks and set dressers to flesh out David Webb Peoples's by-the-numbers script.
Despite being hampered by second-rate special effects and too many action film cliches, Soldier does have its fun parts.
With a cheerful disregard for characterization and visual texture, Anderson relies on his cgi-jocks and set dressers to flesh out David Webb Peoples's by-the-numbers script.
Despite being hampered by second-rate special effects and too many action film cliches, Soldier does have its fun parts.
The quaint, watercolour cell-animation works nicely, and the characters of Roo and Lumpy the baby heffalump are winning and beautifully voiced.
Mediocre songs, so-so animation...but it has Garland and Goulet singing.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi
review_content: Along with some equally captivating special effects and a heavy dose of action, Return of the Jedi is still a solid combination of everything you love about the first two movies.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi
review_content: Along with some equally captivating special effects and a heavy dose of action, Return of the Jedi is still a solid combination of everything you love about the first two movies.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi
review_content: The film has special effects so incredible that it will become the standard by which future efforts are measured, and it leaves the audience cheering and happy.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi
review_content: The film has special effects so incredible that it will become the standard by which future efforts are measured, and it leaves the audience cheering and happy.
When you have such a physically gifted performer as Li on hand, it's too bad that 'special effects' have to be brought in under the mistaken assumption that they'll enhance the proceedings.
When you have such a physically gifted performer as Li on hand, it's too bad that 'special effects' have to be brought in under the mistaken assumption that they'll enhance the proceedings.
Marks a low point in special effects wizard Stan Winston's career...
Forgettable and predictable, but with a good cast and some fun special effects.
From the nondescript voices to routine animation to an over-written story, this movie spends much of its time gasping for air.
Too laid-back to really boogie--as if it prefers sipping pina coladas to catching waves--and not funny enough to compensate for merely average animation.
The faux-documentary angle is pretty nifty. So is the animation.
The animation is fine, the voice work is well-cast and well-directed (with a special nod to the always-wonderful Bridges) and Surf's Up is modestly entertaining.

It has the meticulously hyper-real textures and breathtaking vistas we have come to expect from CGI. But clever use of focus and angles and interaction with the 'documentary' cameramen make it seem more intimate, less like a bunch of pixels.
The originality of the documentary format coupled with the splendid CGI effects qualifies Surf's Up as not just another penguin movie.

Directors Brannon & Buck have a lot of fun with applying animation to the documentary format, creating lots of "accidental" moments in shots and having the characters amusingly play to the unseen-but-heard interview crew.
Surf's Up is so ingenious and fresh, and features such truly awesome CGI, that another summer with penguins is genuinely welcomed.
...surprise, Surf's Up turns out to be a small winner, a cute animal animation that works its surfer world with offbeat humor.
The designers behind Surf's Up give the film a warmth that's often missing from today's computer-dominated animation; the water sequences are especially impressive and beautiful.
Seems like a personal project compromised with the need in the United States for animation to be for children.
Yet another preposterous penguin animation.
The American CGI-animated Surf's Up is a treat.
I'm still waiting for animation to go beyond talking animals and simplistic premises with almost take away value. I guess I'll have to sit on the fence with this one...
Vanessa Redgrave pursuing a poorly CGI-ed butterfly, with this incredibly idiotic look on her face, reminded me of a time I saw a retarded dog chasing a tree.
This will personally go down as the flick that really made me realize how much I hate CGI stunts.
There was a time when car movies used to be about the cars. The star of this picture is a computer, creating CGI car crashes. The picture is a phony.
The soundtrack pounds away as the cars compete in the most unbelievable races with so many quick cuts and CGI that you hardly know who's where in relation to anyone else. But it doesn't matter.
Good action fun, with spectacular stunts and special effects.
Unfocused and underwhelming, X Games 3D is most notable as a missed opportunity.
Has stunning 3D visuals which briefly provide a rush of adrenaline, but it often feels too dull while lacking insight and suspense as well as palpable excitement.
A dirt bike motorcycle enthusiast as well as a 3D aficionado, I had a great time overall, despite the film's imperfections.
...when the term blockbuster too often suggests digital special effects or a place to rent movies, The Great Escape reminds us of the true meaning of the word.

Watching this without having got stoned first is like watching a 3D movie without the special glasses. There are a few moderate laughs (and a nice Jude Law gag) but the full-on gory violence is disconcerting and unfunny.
No message, no car chases and explosions, no 3D - just relaxing entertainment
Despicable Me 2 is a delightful box of 3D delights, with dastardly villains, deliciously vicious beasties AND a genuinely sweet love story.

This sequel perhaps doesn't recapture that feeling of freshness and originality of its predecessor, but there's still an abundance of wit and humour on show to keep this animation ticking over nicely.
Once again, there's nothing here that's particularly original or memorable, but the characters are endearing and the manic animation is relentlessly hilarious.
Co-directors Pierre Coffin and Chris Renaud return for a shot at turning the unlikely "Despicable Me" premise into an animation franchise.
Despicable Me was a disposable piece of silliness designed to delight the younger end of the animation market, so it's no surprise that this sequel offers more of the same.
While Despicable Me 2 isn't the most laugh-out-loud or innovative family film, its stunning animation and amusing hijinks make it worth a watch in between other summer flicks.
The animation is beguiling, particularly when Lucy drives her car into the ocean, transforming it into a submarine that scoots around sharks and fish.
Features daft animation, exuberant vocal performances, and heaps of humor from Gru's caplet-shaped, nonsense-talking Minions.
The animation is great, especially among the minions, whose every action seems to instigate a ripple effect that creates a chain of slapstick laughs.
It's all good fun. If you have kids...they'll squeal. And, even adults will like the minions and the 3D effects.
wonderfully imaginative and fun with a masterful use of 3D and breathtaking precision-timed action sequences that are both exciting and hilarious. And there are minions.
Thanks to a zippy script and bold animation, "Despicable Me 2" has the same charm and wit as the first movie, but now there's a lot less evil.
THIS is what 3D should be.

It's the zany goggle-wearing yellow-hued Minions who provide most of the film's chuckles and who justify the otherwise pointless 3D when they break the fourth wall at the start of the credits with a set of loopy antics.
The beautiful digital animation is state of the art but the story and comedy are utter cliche.
Carrell's almost better this way, with his mugging fully abstracted by animation, whereas we start to miss Wiig's actual face.
It has an incessant narrative rhythm and a fruitful direction, an animation that continues to explore the personal style of its predecessor. [Full Review in Spanish]
wonderful WWII propaganda drama with sincere performances by the cast. Special effects bombing sequence of Tokyo isn't bad either.

It features some of the worst performances ever to besmeer the silver screen. These, coupled with a ridiculous plot, ludicrous special effects and several bizarre deaths make the film pass beyond the realms of 'so bad it's good' into downright hilarity.
CGI-assisted ping pong and lame gags about dead pandas, simpering homos and 'Antiques Roadshow'.

It paints in western shades a science-fiction comedy canvas in which the brilliant leading duo, the imaginative work of the director and the special effects department stand out. [Full Review in Spanish]
Actually better than expected with slash and jab special effects.

In the end, we are left with a dull woman who is surrounded by puppets and voiceless actors covered in prosthetics -- and it's never a good sign when the special effects give more memorable performances than the hero.
An ocean story without much depth. The fun shark tale is secondary to little fish story that won't make any waves. Expressive animation though and Ziggy Marley.
An ocean story without much depth. The fun shark tale is secondary to little fish story that won't make any waves. Expressive animation though and Ziggy Marley.
While it's no Finding Nemo (and isn't trying to be), it's the wackiest, most energetic, and possibly most entertaining effort to date from DreamWorks' CGI animators.
Shark Tale feels borrowed, sampled and dittoed from the collective funniness of the past 10 years in studio-made animation.
Swimming in the lucrative wake of Finding Nemo, DreamWorks's foray into computer-generated underwater animation is a rambunctious, reasonably amusing pop confection.
It does not have as much invigorating freshness as audiences have come to expect in computer animation.
What Shark Tale lacks in originality it makes up for with sassy humor, bright, effective animation and terrific vocal work.
Not even the eye candy animation is all that great. The film has a flat look that matches it comedic tone.
Shark Tale feels like a modest step backwards [for CGI films], a regression not visually but conceptually.
While it's no Finding Nemo (and isn't trying to be), it's the wackiest, most energetic, and possibly most entertaining effort to date from DreamWorks' CGI animators.

Not even the eye candy animation is all that great. The film has a flat look that matches it comedic tone.
Shark Tale feels like a modest step backwards [for CGI films], a regression not visually but conceptually.
Inside this dazzling animation is a dim plot that imagines Goodfellas living in the land of Jaws and being serviced by the dudes at the Car Wash.
Funny, dazzling, fast and frisky, Shark Tale is a sparkling addition to the modern animation canon.
Inside this dazzling animation is a dim plot that imagines Goodfellas living in the land of Jaws and being serviced by the dudes at the Car Wash.
Funny, dazzling, fast and frisky, Shark Tale is a sparkling addition to the modern animation canon.
We needn't look further than 'Shark Tale' to realize the studio that revolutionized the art of CGI animation doesn't own the patent on wit and imagination.

A gorgeous adaptation. Ang Lee's visuals are amazing-and it has some of the best 3D I've ever seen.
It is nothing short of jaw dropping what the audience is treated to on-screen, and the 3D element works well the some of the most incredible images ever seen in movies.
Lee's use of 3D -- the best since Hugo -- proves that while the format is pushed for the money, it's meant for the masters.
From the CGI to the subject matter, the film contains several layers of fiction, but regardless of your level of belief, "Life of Pi" always feels true.
Life of Pi puts 3D in the hands of a worldclass film artist. Ang Lee uses 3D with the delicacy and lyricism of a poet. You don't just watch this movie, you live it.
Full of 3D wonders, but in the end no more than an easygoing, unchallenging adventure movie. Ang Lee is a master whose films can be emotionally powerful; Life of Pi isn't.

It is an incredibly pretty film, and almost all of it was conjured via effects or animation... But the thing about special effects, even beautiful ones, is that they tend to call attention to themselves.

A dazzling digital dreamscape that sets staggering new heights for what can be accomplished with 3D technology.

Ang Lee's Life of Pi is a visual masterpiece, often transcending the boundaries of special effects and what they're capable of, but the film's actual story is hollow.
Some of the most gorgeous 3D images this side of 'Avatar.'
The visuals and special effects are imaginatively exquisite.

Giving Ang Lee access to 3D camera equipment and a modern-day fable like "Life of Pi" is the best idea anyone has had in a long time.

review_content: Depp hijacks -- no, commandeers -- the staginess and special effects, turning Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl into a giddy adventure.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl
review_content: Boasts the season's best production values, first-rate computer-animated special effects and a strong ensemble cast ready to toss your low expectations overboard.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl
review_content: This film has enough wit, action scenes, horror moments, and dazzling special effects and fight scenes that would place it amongst the best Pirate films ever. Not to mention one of funniest performances given by Johnny Depp.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl
review_content: Wonderful swashbuckling adventure that delivers everything you could possibly want from a pirate movie, + a little more besides -- jaw-dropping special effects, a superb script and a show-stealing performance from Johnny Depp.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl
review_content: ...Full of colorful visuals, amazing special effects, and plenty of silly fun for the whole family.

Disney eradicated their hand-drawn animation department for this?
For a movie that's supposed to launch Disney's official CGI era, Chicken Little doesn't stand tall enough.
The title's oddly appropriate, since in an era of animation giants, this movie is small potatoes. Or in keeping with the theme, chicken feed.

The computerized animation hasn't got enough pop, the characters are vapid rather than nonsensical or silly, the musical numbers are awful, and the emotional situation of the plot is handled like a large piece of meat at the end of a hook.

Oddly enough, Walt Disney Pictures breaks through the glass ceiling of modern animation with a tale about the sky falling.
The Disney studio was once the gold standard for feature animation. Now it gives us... the worst cartoon movie of the year.

Disney's first all-CGI effort not made by Pixar, looks cheap, bland, plasticene and often fuzzy.

I have to say that I think the robot effects are better here but maybe since they got rid of Megan Fox the effects team no longer had to spend all that time CGI-ing out her toe thumbs and could spend all their efforts on rendering the robots instead.

the best 3D movie of all time --short as that timespan may be, it's quite something

Another bloated and confusing adventure oozing with disorienting CGI action and one-dimensional characters. This better be the end of the franchise, otherwise Bay owes us all a lifetime supply of Advil.

A vague story is cobbled together around the increasingly mind-numbing special effects and convoluted action sequences. But by the end of the 2 1/2-hour-+ slog, it's hard to even remember where it began.
If you're prepared to sit through two and a half hours of noisy cack to see a grand total of three decent special effects sequences, then I can heartily recommend it.

If Transformers 3 was produced purely to be an expose of what you can do with CGI in the modern era, it'd get full marks. It's truly is the ultimate showreel for Industrial Light & Magic. But it's meant to be a film, and sadly it's not very good at that.
It's a lousy movie, but at least it's a lousy movie with a serviceable story, killer CGI and an action climax that goes on forever (at least an hour).

The effects and 3D have already received a lot of advanced praise; it sounds like I'm a spoil-sport but the CGI action has a glossy sheen that appears synthetic -- it's dazzling, but it feels, well, untrue, as in you experience it as an effect.

Even though the astonishing special effects and stunt work are a sight to behold, just remember this: Your eyes will be the only organ in your body that will receive any type of stimulation.
The Transformers threequel may be overlong, overloud and overly dumb, but the action - rendered in the most eye-popping, gob-smacking, jaw-dropping 3D since Avatar - is truly awesome.
Dark of the Moon is just as loud, dumb and illogical as you expect. But when those neat 3D action sequences kick in, none of that matters.

Michael Bay's third "Transformers" installment in four years is a rambling mess of bastardized news reel footage, over-stylized CGI talking toy jousts, and light-hearted scenes with the comedic timing of Dick Cheney's pacemaker.

Director Michael Bay's latest foray into endless, vapid dissonance is Transformers: Dark of the Moon. This time out we sit through 2 1/2 hours of CGI -- complete godawful inanity. The last hour is not equal to what animator Chuck Jones did in a minute.
Maybe the best-looking 3D movie I've seen this year.
Loud and long, this 3rd installment boasts a better plot and impressive CGI while maintaining its juvenile level of comedy - the target audience will likely love it.
In the hands of director Michael Bay, this battle is bound to be over the top, and the special effects amaze.
There's nothing too complex about the film (other than the parade of special effects and explosions), but it's mindless fun that works on its own level.

This is a movie that understands how to engage its audience - a spoonful of philosophy and a bucket of CGI.
