Attacks' only real virtue is its consistency: On every level, whether it's acting, humor, action or special effects, it is consistently disappointing.
It's fun in a primitive kind of way (no CGI tricks are involved) and directed by Simon West with more energy than the earlier film - which was directed by Stallone, seemingly under heavy sedation.

Bigger in scope than the original, the film's nonstop mayhem includes cartoonish battles, geysers of CGI blood and seemingly impossible stunts, with the geriatric gang of beloved icons placed centre stage for maximum thrills.
The special effects and trick photography are cleverly done (for its time). Also, the story is intelligently handled.
Notable for its relatively intelligent script, for some imaginatively amusing special effects, and for an existential streak which finally has our (tiny) hero pondering the meaning of existence.
Original and still superior version of the classic story. What is scary is that this film special effects in this film actually looks better than its expensive remake several decades later!

While Kong is, in most scenes, only an 18-inch studio model, the stop motion special effects are so intelligently accomplished and lovingly detailed that the animated gorilla often appears more expressive than the human actors.
The continuing success of King Kong is due not only to its spectacular special effects, but also to the exemplary economy with which the filmmakers handled the screenplay, filming and editing.
charming fantasy continues to hold up and is a treasure trove of special effects that continue to inspire
Willis O'Brien did the stop-action animation for this 1933 feature, which is richer in character than most of the human cast.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: An effective film, deploying its special effects well and never breaking the illusion that it is all happening as we see it.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: Reeves does a masterful job wedding the restricted perspective of Hud's lens with CGI glimpses of an already blasted cityscape. This is the gimmick's raw excitement phase -- we're hooked.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: Works as a showcase for impressively realistic-looking special effects, a realism that fails to extend to the scurrying humans whose fates are meant to invoke pity and fear but instead inspire yawns and contempt.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: The only thing surprising about the picture turns out to be how unsurprising it is. Also--despite massive special effects--how boring.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: The special effects are excellent, withjust enough being shown of the marauding "attacker," and its minions to keep you on the edge of your seat.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: Memorable neither for its special effects nor the gimmickry of the hand-held camera.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Monster movie', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Doomsday film', 'Sci-Fi Horror', 'Creature Film', 'Action/Adventure', 'Mystery', 'Archives and records', 'Monster', 'Disaster', 'Action']
review_content: The special effects are outstanding and the story is a throwback to the days when audiences were given only glimpses of the monster. Sometimes what you can't see or have difficulty seeing is much scarier than something in plain view.
The slapdash animation is matched in kind by the patched-together story.
Amateurish animation mars Christian animal tale about Jesus.
The film is a sloppy, discombobulated mess that mistakes loud skate punk music for character development and prosaic special effects for a narrative.
It feels like an after-school special gussied up with some fancy special effects, and watching its rote plot points connect is about as exciting as gazing at an egg timer for 93 minutes.
Fun action comedy with nifty special effects.
A pallid film framed at the start and finish by live action and mostly composed of cheap-looking animation.
Mediocre, really, this mixture of real actors and animation.

Rudimentary on every level, this long-gestating Universal pic based on the children's character is pitched toward the youngest of kids -- roughly ages zygote to 4 -- with direct-to-video quality animation, plotting and backgrounds.
Disney animation vet Matthew O'Callaghan pushes color and character over visual artistry, but George proves a big enough star to carry his first feature
With top-drawer voice talent and old-fashioned two-dimensional animation that echoes the simple colors and shapes of the books, Curious George is an unexpected delight.

Visually, the movie benefits from a charming animation style, a traditional 2-D approach layered with shadows and backlit halos. But it benefits most from George, still worming his way into people's hearts.
The skillful 2D-CGI animation hybrid starts out charmingly enough, with cute sight gags and general monkeying around, but...even kids may lose interest in the labored story.
The skillful 2D-CGI animation hybrid starts out charmingly enough, with cute sight gags and general monkeying around, but...even kids may lose interest in the labored story.
Enjoyable, brightly coloured and sharply written animation that will delight its target audience while leaving accompanying adults pleasantly surprised.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Wonderfully dark and moody children's Halloween tale that gently stirs all of the required elements of humour, musical charisma, children's imagination and amazing special effects in a successful simmering pot of entertainment.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: This brilliant combination of stop-motion animation, three-dimensional sets and superbly imaginative graphics, brings animation to new peaks.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Likely to appeal to grown-ups of all ages--while putting the fear of God into kids--it's a perfect antidote to standard festive fare and evidence of the rich and varied possibilities of stop-motion animation. In a word, wonderful.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: The Nightmare Before Christmas is a major step forward for both stop-motion animation, which is stunningly well used, and for Mr. Burton himself. He now moves from the level of extremely talented eccentric to that of Disney-style household word.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Awesome stop motion animation, brilliant fantasy story and great music. A must!

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: A triumph of art design and stop-motion animation.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: This hugely entertaining horror fable for all the family might suffer from pacing problems, but it's also a true original that still stands out from today's CGI-heavy crowd.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: A work of grand visual wit, clever songs, funny gags and genuine pathos, it is perhaps the greatest stop-motion animated film ever, a painstaking style of model animation that computers have all but completely done away with.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Pure enchantment, Tim Burton's The Nightmare Before Christmas creates a unique and wondrous world. This awesome movie is in a class by itself for its use of stop-action animation.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Visually a macabre knockout, this 75-minute fantasy boasts some of the wittiest, most vigorous stop-motion animation effects in the history of the process.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Disney's sophisticated stop-motion animation (an advanced version of techniques used to create Gumby) creates a truly breathtaking visual landscape.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Animation is a wonderful medium, but it's almost too compatible with Burton's uninhibited approach. When literally anything goes, even the most original idea can get lost in the creative shuffle.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: Adults, despite being wowed by the dazzling, geez-how'd-they-do-that animation, will find their attention wandering to Christmases past.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: I'm blown away by just the construction of the scenes, and by all of the effects that have been incorporated to make everything move fluidly; and there's also this charming imperfection to the animation that just makes it so gorgeous.

genres: ["Children's/Family", 'Stop motion', 'Creature Film', 'Musical', 'Animation', 'Christmas movie', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Animated Musical', 'Family Film']
review_content: The totality and tangibility of the world that Selick and his animators extract from Burton's lovely spidery drawings is one of the major achievements of animation history.

One of the best WWII action-adventures, with an all-star cast headed by Gregory Peck, Anthony Quinn, and David Niven, this Oscar-winner (in special effects) is stirringly directed by the vastly underestimated J. Lee Thompson
Heavy on laughable special effects and outrageously broad performances...
Spectacular stunts and special effects cannot save this fusion of Indian and Chinese culture from coming across as a movie with little originality or wit.
Very bad special effects mar this only-average s-f excursion. Only the giant rat-bat-whatever creature has any flair.
If your kid has never seen a 3D movie, this isn't a bad start, especially if they're younger. The look is great, but the movie is just bland.
Fly Me to the Moon is an awkward mix of proficient 3-D animation, detailed technical recreation and strained storytelling that stalls on takeoff.
Fly Me to the Moon is in 3D because, without the glasses-required effects, not even a three-year-old would sit through it.
The filmmakers show they are especially adept at pulling off some tricky animated 3D effects.
Dull dialogue, a dull story, and dull animation. What's left?
The idiotic story and low-rent animation will bore children to tears.

Adults used to animation that runs on two tracks -- the upfront stuff for the tykes and a witty subtext to entertain big people -- may grow bored with the kid-leaning sensibility of Fly Me to the Moon.
The animation is so stiff it makes South Park look like Walt Disney's Fantasia.
If only the first-ever animated 3-D movie had as great a story line as it does 3-D animation, we could have all gone to the movies this weekend and had a wonderful time.
The 3-D animation work in Fly Me to The Moon is brisk and sweet.
The superior effects in Fly Me to the Moon reflect the talents of its creator, director Ben Stassen, who has been doing 3D for 14 years, mostly for science centers and museums.
The animation is lazy at best, haphazard at worst and pretty much nondescript all the way through.
The vocal characterizations aren't the problem here; the script and the animation are the problems, and in feature animation, you can't arrange more significant problems than those.
Only the 3D process helps to dispel the impression that what you're seeing lacks wit and is completely generic in terms of characters and 'humor.'
The story is inoffensively wholesome, and there may be enough goofy antics to engage young, indiscriminate viewers, but the level of creativity in the animation is serviceable at best.
The 3-D effects are nice enough, but they can't make up for a dull story, stock characters (making them flies doesn't make them any more original) and cheap-looking animation.
Few would claim there are no flies on this one, but at least the outstanding 3D effects are some compensation for the dumbed-down inanity of everything else.
Without the special effects, this would be a routine and occasionally dull adventure, but the 3D animation is simply astonishing and the film is worth seeing for that alone.
Without the special effects, this would be a routine and occasionally dull adventure, but the 3D animation is simply astonishing and the film is worth seeing for that alone.
Without the special effects, this would be a routine and occasionally dull adventure, but the 3D animation is simply astonishing and the film is worth seeing for that alone.
This 3D animation about a trio of pesky houseflies hitching a ride on Apollo 11 will give you a buzz only if you've missed the last 15 years of superior animations.
This 3D animation about a trio of pesky houseflies hitching a ride on Apollo 11 will give you a buzz only if you've missed the last 15 years of superior animations.
If 3D is going to make a giant leap, it requires a more exciting movie than this.
This witless 3D animated feature tries its best but never achieves lift-off.
Believe the bad buzz on this houseflies-become-astronauts CG animation, which is lousy with lazy jokes and irritating characters.
G-rated, 3D animated adventure of three plucky young flies who hitch a ride on Apollo 11 plods rather than soars. And maggots with faces aren't cute.
One of the strangest misfires in recent animation history.
'Wreck-It Ralph' is a clutter of noise, eye-wearying animation, frenetic action and two-dimensional characters.
Wreck-It Ralph is an absolutely wonderful film, nothing short of a glorious, full-blown rebirth for Disney Animation Studios.

Built for fun...in its dazzlingly elaborate production design and kinetic 3D action...perfect casting...Who Framed Roger Rabbit-esque video-game-character cameos, and a cramming of clever comic touches...
The most inventive and entertaining family movie I've seen this year, packed with wickedly smart humor and joyful animation.
Disney Animation takes a page out of Pixar's well-worn playbook for this, a screwball farce with a novel setting and more edge than your average Disney 'toon.
Wreck-It Ralph is a major advancement for Walt Disney Animation Studios in all regards.

This A-grade animated Disney charmer hits the nail on the head...director Rich Moore has enormous faith in the ability of young audiences to absorb multiple story strands at once, a belief aided no end by the exquisite quality of the animation.
This cleverly-targeted family romp marks a step up both commercially and artistically for the non-Pixar side of Disney's animation offering.

This is a hugely enjoyable entry in the Walt Disney Animation Studios catalogue. It sits well alongside the likes of Tangled, balancing both anarchic humour and classic Disney sentimentality very well.
It's a CGI time-machine for those who misspent their youth developing RSIs on bleeping 8-bit arcade consoles.
The chubby 3D animation, smart-alecky product placement and potty humour all capped my enthusiasm about halfway to total delight.
The chubby 3D animation, smart-alecky product placement and potty humour all capped my enthusiasm about halfway to total delight.
Hyperactive day-glo fizzy-pop family animation with a heartfelt message about staying true to yourself lurking underneath all the visual fireworks.
Wreck-It Ralph is a highly original and exciting film that puts Disney Animation right up there with Pixar in terms of providing a story full of emotion, heart and energy.
Fizzy, colourful and intricately plotted, this 2012 pop meta-fiction from The Simpsons' Rich Moore does for vintage arcade games what Who Framed Roger Rabbit did for the Golden Age of Animation.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Buddy film', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Action Comedy', 'Action/Adventure', 'Western', 'Martial Arts Film', 'Comedy', 'Action', 'Chinese Movies']
review_content: Clearly, this whole enterprise is extremely silly and some of the cheapo special effects are not so special and have little effect. But the movie is still a wonderful guilty pleasure.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Buddy film', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Action Comedy', 'Action/Adventure', 'Western', 'Martial Arts Film', 'Comedy', 'Action', 'Chinese Movies']
review_content: Clearly, this whole enterprise is extremely silly and some of the cheapo special effects are not so special and have little effect. But the movie is still a wonderful guilty pleasure.

Between the witty screenplay, delightful visuals that jump back and forth between 3-D and 2-D animation, and a consistently game voice cast, this third serving never feels like a dull retread or a lazy cash grab.
While visually gorgeous and generally entertaining, this third installment of the DreamWorks Animation franchise is a comedown from the first two superb entries.
A vividly entertaining adventure story with beautiful animation and a solid way to continue the arc of the titular protagonist.
Kung Fu Panda 3 delivers a great message to young people, some of the most gorgeous animation out there, and action-comedy that will amuse those of all ages.
Kung Fu Panda 3 is often inspired as animation, and tired as everything else.
Black and white and fun all over, Kung Fu Panda 3 achieves best-of-franchise status with a story that goes deeper than typical kid fare, wrapped in beautifully crafted animation.
Lots of comedic fight scenes break up the story's more somber stretches, and the animation, especially in 3-D, is simply gorgeous.
The animation is still strong - there are some interesting and refreshingly uncuddly depictions of the spirit world from whence Kai springs - but, mainly, KFP3 is too much of a good thing.
With a star-studded voice cast (Black in the lead, with Rogen and Cross on backup) there's no shortage of humor. But the animation is the real standout in the film.
Endearing, action-jacked, and self-effacingly funny, Kung Fu Panda 3 simply reaffirms it has a Wuxi Finger Hold on the chop-socky, Taoist, slapstick kids-animation market.

It's sweet, irresistible stuff, but the animation is absolutely spectacular, blending influences from ancient Chinese and Japanese art with a glorious palette of colours to create something truly special.
The animation is gorgeous, too, drawing its inspiration from sources as richly diverse as ancient Chinese scrolls and the fantastical landscapes found on Roger Dean's prog-rock album covers.

A happy whirlwind of colour, 3D dazzle and Kung Fu madness, this third film in the panda franchise continues to blossom like its unlikely hero, who learns to become the best he can be, through his journey of self worth and belonging
We're treated to less of the same, and while that is disappointing, it doesn't deny this trilogy from being one of the best franchises to come out of DreamWorks Animation Studios.
This nearly-five-years-later follow-up to the second effort's again flat and strained, although the animation is even snazzier.
Kung Fu Panda is that rare film that actually benefits from the 3D process.
Both the writing and the animation are especially strong this time around, drawing in bigger themes while still keeping things both thrilling and very silly.

One of the most pleasing franchises in animation, Po and his stalwart companions mix Western and Eastern tropes together to create a pleasing amalgam with some of the industry's best animation, both traditional and modern.
A plot as patchy as a panda doesn't mar the enjoyment of this third look at the animated high-kicking bear and his fighting animal friends. The animation ... is super-smooth.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: I am a fan of both the books and films and it is sad to say goodbye to the boy wizard so many have grown up with. But at least he gets the send-off he deserves -- with a 3D blast of visual wizardry.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: As far as spectacle goes, this final chapter of the Harry Potter franchise has plenty of it with showy special effects and a rich and alluring density that once again overshadows the narrative

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: This installment clocks in as the shortest Harry Potter film yet, but it sacrifices little in terms of thrills and tears, and has some seriously cool special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: The final episode overwhelms with its CGI effects, yet somehow manages to be surprisingly moving in the way the epic Harry Potter story is brought to a satisfactory conclusion.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: Cinematographer Eduardo Serra underscores the sense of dread with a rich charcoal palette, and the outstanding CGI and 3D effects make the otherworldly threats more corporeal.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: Cinematographer Eduardo Serra underscores the sense of dread with a rich charcoal palette, and the outstanding CGI and 3D effects make the otherworldly threats more corporeal.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: I can merely pay illiterate, honest homage to the costumes, special effects and set designs, which are all fantastic. And to the actors, hamming and over-egging as if it is All Day Breakfast season on Mount Thespis.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: This splendid final HP film uses special effects to full advantage, thereby increasing the thrill of watching Harry and his friends try to defeat the evil Lord Voldemort.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: There's visual overstatement, stone-heavy exposition, self-seriousness (masquerading as maturity), CGI-laden plot (falling short of spectacle), and predictable action sequences.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: The danger is seething as both sides battle between extravagant set pieces and eye-catching special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2
review_content: I was impressed with the incredible amount of edge-of-your-seat action, the brilliant ways in which they worked the 3D F/X in, and just the way the whole thing came together.
Competent, watchable remake that improves on the special effects and running time but loses the moral complexity and the character work of the original.
About as unremarkable as a big budget special effects and car chase-filled movie can be.
A flatline affair from beginning to end, The Punisher is painfully dull, offering no characters, actions, scenes or special effects of note.
Basically special effects-free, The Punisher portrays violence with unflinching realism.
There's something to be said for the mere existence of a comic-book movie that isn't dependent on CGI effects to tell its story.

movie_name: The Man Who Fell to Earth
review_content: Though Roeg's special effects looked hokey even 35 years ago, some of the technological elements of the film have proven oddly prescient.
Visually dazzling fantasy is both a 3D landmark and a warm personal tribute by Martin Scorsese to early movie pioneer Georges Méliès.
One of the rare films where 3D is worth the money and those ugly glasses. However, that's far from the only thing to recommend about his family-friendly - heck, human-friendly - story.
Thoroughly enchanting. Transports us into a magical world of movies, yet looks forward in its embrace of dreams and imagination. The first truly artistic use of 3D I've seen.
Hugo and Scorsese have found a way to prove beyond a shadow of a doubt the usefulness of the 3D format.
Scorsese and his team have now set the 3D bar so high that filmmakers will have to create a whole other dimension ... just to keep up.
Martin Scorsese's love letter to filmmaking finally proves that 3D is a necessary aesthetic to storytelling if used correctly. I definitely shed a few nerd tears!

Scorsese uses 3D to submerge viewers into a glittering storybook world, but all of Hugo's beauty can't make up for the sidetracking of the tale of the orphaned boy living in the train station in favor of a film preservation PSA.
An infectious ode to the early days of cinema. Scorsese's use of 3D is inspired, although it might be more interesting for parents than their children.

Beautifully made and superbly acted, Hugo features terrific 3D effects and stands as a charming love letter to silent cinema, but it's let down by a weak central plot and the script never quite connects on an emotional level.
Beautifully filmed in 3D it, turns into an education for the viewer on a subject near and dear to director Martin Scorsese's heart.
Who knew? The director who put the rage in Raging Bull the fear in Cape Fear and the mean in Mean Streets could make a family-friendly, dazzling 3D film.
Never mind that the tone wavers and the pace is mostly plodding, the film champions all the right things and the beautifully crafted images (in 3D glory) leave a lasting impression
An exuberant and meticulous 3D spectacle by one of the greatest filmmakers of all time.
Scorsese's unlikely 3D family film takes an agreeably pragmatic stance, that we must embrace the past yet never deny progress.
Push has amazing special effects and production design, but that doesn't compensate for the messy, incoherent plot and lack of truly palpable Sci-fi thrills and excitement.
Some good special effects but the story cannibalizes its own predecessor.
An entertaining thriller in the tradition of 1970s B-action films, with an unknown cast, energetic special effects and great energy.
Attack the Block has a cast of nobodies, the cheesiest special effects this side of Velveeta, and it's the best sci-fi movie you'll see this summer.

The premise is outlandish, the special effects simple, and the cast largely unknown. But Cornish has kept his film short and sharp and given us characters we want to see survive. The result is a blast.
Mild peril, dated animation in tale of island survival.
A pretty s-f outing, good special effects, but slow at times.
A pretty s-f outing, good special effects, but slow at times.

Silent Running concentrates heavily on special effects, resulting in some stunning imagery. Dern gives an engaging, against-type performance, though the script is stretched out very thin to support a feature-length film.

Silent Running concentrates heavily on special effects, resulting in some stunning imagery. Dern gives an engaging, against-type performance, though the script is stretched out very thin to support a feature-length film.
Though Cameron can't resist using 3D in traditional style -- a deckhand throws out a rope that grazes your head -- he mostly uses it imaginatively.
Aside from his CGI ghostcraft unwittingly co-opting Pat O'Neill's last feature, Cameron is entirely predictable in a marines T-shirt, exhorting, 'Next stop, Titanic -- rock 'n' roll!'
...to be really appreciated [Ghosts of the Abyss] should be seen in its IMAX 3D presentation.
It's worth the risk of looking silly in the 3D glasses to join James Cameron on his trip to depths of the North Atlantic for a firsthand look at the great, tragic Titanic.
The film is an exhausting collection of airplane CGI Firefox-style and heroic slow-motion establishing shots with shutter-staggered sprints through minefields.
As an exercise in stunts, action and special effects, the film does well enough, but it lacks the strength of characters and story to make it better than average ...
You chuckle here and there, you enjoy the animation (given a bit more pep and computery dimension for the big screen), but the moment it takes off never comes.
You chuckle here and there, you enjoy the animation (given a bit more pep and computery dimension for the big screen), but the moment it takes off never comes.
The Simpsons Movie was expected to raise the bar for animated film -- especially 2-D animation. Unfortunately, it's just another example of what could have been.
A feature-length version of the show that has some snazzier animation but otherwise amounts to a decent oversized episode.
The pace is breakneck, and the animation -- though still primitive -- makes good use of the full width of the screen.
The Simpsons Movie was expected to raise the bar for animated film -- especially 2-D animation. Unfortunately, it's just another example of what could have been.
A feature-length version of the show that has some snazzier animation but otherwise amounts to a decent oversized episode.
The pace is breakneck, and the animation -- though still primitive -- makes good use of the full width of the screen.
'The Simpsons Movie' has a slightly sharper edge than the series and the animation is brighter and crisper yet true to the hand-drawn spirit of the show.
'The Simpsons Movie' has a slightly sharper edge than the series and the animation is brighter and crisper yet true to the hand-drawn spirit of the show.
This re-establishes The Simpsons as the jewel in the crown of American animation.
This re-establishes The Simpsons as the jewel in the crown of American animation.
Vaughn is marvelous dancing with the elves, but plot digressions that take much too long to resolve and mangled special effects are a distraction and a nuisance.
An engaging idea gets mostly lost amid underdeveloped characters, a pointless subplot and creepy CGI.

Director Courtney Solomon's script is a catalogue of the standard Exorcist-style special effects, hammered home by Caine Davidson's musical score, one of the most irritating and nerve-wracking assemblies of noise in movie history.
This is proof that it doesn't take lots of bloody gore, big special effects or jump-at-you moments to scare jaded audiences.
Innocuous and instantly forgettable stuff that seems downright tepid in comparison to what others have been doing with animation and kid-friendly offerings of recent. (Parental Review also Available)
This being the highly advanced 21st century, simple animation won't do, so we must suffer through mediocre, lifeless computer-generated animation of this treasured twosome.
Kudos to director Eric Brevig and his team of digital animation artists for a rendering of Yogi that, for all its wonderful detail, remains faithful to the lovable cartoon bear of yore.

Like a steady, throbbing ache that, after 75 minutes, you realize was your nerve endings' collective scream at your numbed-off brain to flee this awkward hybrid of animation and live-action. The humans are even more cartoonish than 'your a-ver-age bear.'

There's no real reason for this live action/animation hybrid version of the classic cartoon besides the fact that digital effects allowed them to do it. But at least it's rather undemanding good fun while it lasts.
Poor old Yogi has a rough time of it in this miserable 3D assault of humour-free live action and lumpy animation.
Poor old Yogi has a rough time of it in this miserable 3D assault of humour-free live action and lumpy animation.

Any potential retro-charm is quickly rubbed out by creepy CGI, a tired reality-TV conceit and failure to grasp that Yogi's appeal lies in his delivery and quick wit, not eye-stabbing 3D gimmicks or life-like depictions of picnic-basket heists.

Any potential retro-charm is quickly rubbed out by creepy CGI, a tired reality-TV conceit and failure to grasp that Yogi's appeal lies in his delivery and quick wit, not eye-stabbing 3D gimmicks or life-like depictions of picnic-basket heists.
There are some watchable 3D sequences in a boat on the rapids and a makeshift airplane, but it's pretty grim for anyone over six.
Even the most nostalgic and forgiving Yogi fan will likely find it hard to warm to the 21st-century, computer-generated, 3D make-over he's undergone here.
Small children with low levels of expectation are the target for this blandly unimaginative mix of live-action and 3D animation.
Small children with low levels of expectation are the target for this blandly unimaginative mix of live-action and 3D animation.
Trite characters, cheesy CGI in violent stand-alone sequel.
A stunning film laced with absorbing performances, jarring special effects, and atmospheric set design. It has been a long time since a film has evoked as many creepy, spine deep tingles as this one.

Alternately ludicrous, eerily plausible and just a tad overreaching, the film shares its finer points with shortcomings and comes up with an overall cinematic experience more ambitious than most big-budget special effects extravaganzas.
Criticisms of story and acting seem nitpicky in the face of the special effects, which are frankly awesome.

Despite an intriguing premise and a handful of exciting special effects scenes, this science fiction thriller lumbers along like an overweight leviathan, unable to see much past its own nose - let alone into the future.
A solid escapist cinematic experience enhanced by its chilling symbolism, filled with tension and thrills, fabulous special effects and a monumentally big scale ending.
Hugely enjoyable, surprisingly dark thriller with a strong premise, great performances and terrific special effects.
A clunky screenplay doesn't help matters, but the spectacularly shoddy special effects are the nail in the coffin for this doomsday scenario.
'Knowing' this film certainly isn't, but if special effects are your thing, you'll enjoy the ride.

It has nothing but the most simplistic of insights, it mistakes mood for suspense, and even the special effects don't break new ground. A disappointing offering from one of Australia's most talented genre directors.
The CGI is unconvincing, the big shock-and-awe finale is a throwback to the days of Deep Impact, and underneath it all is the nervous American insistence that there is life beyond the stars.
An earnest Cage lends some gravitas to a film of amazing coincidences and less than amazing special effects that sci-fi fans will embrace until something better comes along.
Unbreakable quickly descends into bad CGI set-ups and portentous, hysterical exchanges.

[Director Kang Je-kyu] engineers one long pummel session of elaborate CGI effects, shaky battle cinematography and trial-by-fire heroics, but the nonstop adversity lacks any real sense of danger. Or, for that matter, emotional punch.
Watching the film, I got caught up in the special effects and the neat stunts, and I observed with a certain satisfaction Bond's belated entry into a more modern world.
The special effects in GoldenEye make every other Bond film seem almost primitive.
Wolverine boasts some neat special effects, some decent acting and, best of all, it runs for less than two hours unlike some recent bloated, butt-numbingly long super-hero epics.
This is such a mess of poor editing, cheesy special effects and unconvincing production design that even the Sci-Fi Channel might have had some qualms if it had somehow been offered to them.
'Wolverine' exceeds all expectations! This fantasy adventure is action-packed with thrilling stunt work, dazzling special effects, airtight storytelling and memorable characters.
Bad story, worse script, and special effects from the 1990s.
Wolverine works as an Ultimate Fighting Championship with special effects.

Newbies to the series will perhaps enjoy the relentless explosions and CGI action of X-Men Origins: Wolverine but as a prequel to the X-Men films -- and as an adaptation of the comics -- it fails dismally.
It's woefully unimaginative, overdependent on CGI effects and wantonly wasteful of its big budget and talented cast.

Fans will appreciate this more than the casual filmgoer trapped in this high-tech junkyard of not-so-special effects, scarcely noticeable dialogue, incoherent plotting, inconsistent psychology and garbled motivations.
Explosive action, a decent plot, and some dazzling special effects, so begins the blockbuster season and Wolverine gets things off to a fairly good start.
Each CGI set piece erases distance, space, weight, gravity and wit. It's empty, soulless action -- visual noise.
while the film does feature plenty of action and special effects, it doesn't come close to being anywhere as good as either of the first two films in the X-Men franchise.
If you've never seen an X-Men film you will enjoy Wolverine. If you are familiar with the X-Men franchise then go for the action, special effects and Hugh Jackman.
Reported to be the one thing missing in-part from the leaked workprint, sadly many of the special effects in X-Men Origins: Wolverine are somewhat sub-standard.
Unfortunately, the special effects vary from impressive to embarrassing, and some additional trimming at the story level might have helped elevate the metallurgical rating to steel status.
Sweet and fun, mostly free from overbearing celebrity voices and, while the computer animation is unremarkable, it looks good enough to make the overall impression solid.
A totally charming story enhanced by beautiful CG animation.
Romero conjures moments of eeriness and dread throughout, keeping the lighting low and the special effects to a minimum, though there will be blood, fire, cannibalism and a great deal of death.
The cliche-ridden histrionics were already old-fashioned...fifty years ago. Now they seem positively moldy, and all the CGI dexterity in the world can't enliven them.
Excellent use of the latest special effects makes for a real thrill ride that demands to be viewed on a big screen.

Realized with a combination of vintage and replica aircraft, as well as elaborate CGI effects, the airborne sequences are duly awesome, if a tad monotonous. Ironically, the movie really takes off when it's on the ground.
The back and forth between real biplanes and the CGI variety is flawless, and that makes the dogfights look far more exiting than stuff spent in outer space or with super-duper stealth fighters.
Aafter a while -- there must be six major fights against unending numbers of German planes -- it feels like special effects run amok.
A pot pourri of special effects that forgot about dialogue, acting and even set design.

Universal's remake of its own 1930s classic is actually a lot of fun, its blend of low-rent Indiana Jones-style antics, impressive special effects and inevitably chaste romance scoring high in the risible escapist nonsense department.
A "B" movie wrapped in a winding cloth of "A" special effects.
'The Mummy' ingenuously combines adventure with parody, a hint of horror, the dynamic plasticity of animation and excellent use of the special effects. [Full Review in Spanish]
'The Mummy' ingenuously combines adventure with parody, a hint of horror, the dynamic plasticity of animation and excellent use of the special effects. [Full Review in Spanish]
Its dazzling special effects make its combatants flip and fly, spin and soar, all the while punching and kicking each other like jackhammers, only to leave viewers utterly unmoved.
This tedious hodgepodge of martial-arts mayhem, bogus mysticism and computer-generated special effects doesn't even pretend to have a plot.

The first sequel to 1995's highly successful Mortal Kombat, Mortal Kombat Annihilation adds little to the development of the saga except for a truckload of martial arts sequences and a whole mess of bigger and louder special effects.
Unfortunately, this catty black comedy is buried under an onslaught of unimaginative special effects.

Fleming's film begins promisingly as a black comedy a la Heathers, but then quickly succumbs to its machinery of special effects; this is yet another bad picture in a long list of Hollywood flops about witchcraft.
The 1970s-style special effects do little to distract us from an uneven script, direction and performances. Yet there's enough here for us to hope it'll come together.
Another great entry from the Batman animation team.
McG makes an impressive feature film debut by mixing the retro feel of that 70's show with James Bond-style action, Matrix-style special effects, and a healthy dose of girl power.
*Rarely has so much cinematic stuff -- star power, special effects, set design -- gone on in the service of something so evanescent and feathery.
Many entertaining characters, a rockin' space adventure, plenty of eye-catching animation.
Imaginative, ridiculously anachronistic and distinctly masculine, this is Disney's best traditional animation effort since The Emperor's New Groove.
Some of the computer animation is handsome, and various amusing sidekicks add much-needed levity to the otherwise bleak tale, but overall the film never rises above mediocrity.
If Treasure Planet falls short of Lion King's classic status, it still proves there is plenty of room in animation for movies that aren't geared exclusively to 8-year-olds.
Moody, involving and endlessly inventive, Treasure Planet lacks only the element of delight, of joyfulness that marks the very best animation has to offer.
A truly wonderful tale combined with stunning animation.
This is exactly what animation should be about, presenting us with a thrillingly imaginative adventure that is utterly liberated from trivialities like the laws of physics and possibility.
In visual fertility Treasure Planet rivals the top Japanese animations of recent vintage.
Though families will enjoy the classic story with a cosmic twist, the most valuable gem is the beautiful mix of hand-drawn and computer animation.
This might please the 8 year-olds, but more discerning fans of animation, and adventure are likely to be disappointed with how slack and tedious this latest Disney offering is.
One of the better efforts to come out of the Mouse House's traditional animation departments in recent years.
Half Star Wars and half Classics Illustrated, Disney's Treasure Planet is a total blast, filled with animation dazzle and imaginative storytelling.
Without the pizzazz of computer animation you can see how it will struggle to find its target audience.
This is Disney animation at its best: a witty and swashbuckling tale of adventure.
While Pixar can do no wrong with its cutting edge CGI originals, Disney is falling back on old formulas
Inspired visuals and fluid animation, even blown up on IMAX, weren't enough to prevent me from being bored out of my skull.
Outer-space pirate treasure hunt lots of fun; fab animation.

The addition of an insufferable robot named B.E.N. (Martin Short) cripples much of the film's momentum and renders many of the latter scenes unwatchable (a friend once dubbed B.E.N. "the Jar-Jar Binks of animation," and she was absolutely right).
One of Vincent Price most peculiar films, made in Italy, with poor dubbing of the Italian actors and cheesy special effects

That pervasive sense of the humanistic, along with judicious use of, but not overreliance on, special effects and some exceptionally clever staging of actors...should earn Ghost Town some fast and furious word of mouth.
Funny and heartwarming, this love letter to New York City's Upper East Side is refreshingly free of flashy special effects and paranormal gags.
There's a modicum of fun to be found in the blue-hued special effects, knockabout humour and decent voice cast.
This insipid, and sometimes awkward, blend of animation, computer generation and live action wastes a ton of talent and lacks a true sense of whimsy.
Young children should enjoy the special effects and slapstick but parents will mostly grimace and bear it.

Enjoyable sequel to the 2011 hit, enlivened by decent animation, strong comic performances, a terrific voice cast and a witty, nicely pitched script that ensures there is entertainment for both adults and children.
Once the early 3D novelty value is all but forgotten, it's clear these Smurfs don't have the staying power of Alvin And The Chipmunks.
'Smurfs 2' joins many other live action/animation mixes as an average outing for the smaller fry.
At this week's preview screening, a young girl who apparently was experiencing her first 3D movie complained: 'It's in my face!' Child, I feel your pain.
In this obnoxiously peppy 3D sequel, "smurf" is an all-purpose prefix that the anaemic script uses when words fail. Which is often.
Director George Miller obscures Updike's original version with senseless special effects.

Facing a tough challenge as a follow-up to the superlative Spidey 2, new segment is bigger (in budget), longer (139 minutes), awesome (in CGI), and darker (black is dominant color), featuring more villains than in the first two installments.

Facing a tough challenge as a follow-up to the superlative Spidey 2, new segment is bigger (in budget), longer (139 minutes), awesome (in CGI), and darker (black is dominant color), featuring more villains than in the first two installments.
The third adventure of the guy with arachnid superpowers tries gamely, is solidly entertaining and possesses dazzling special effects, but it falls short of the near-perfection of the Spidey sequel.
The third adventure of the guy with arachnid superpowers tries gamely, is solidly entertaining and possesses dazzling special effects, but it falls short of the near-perfection of the Spidey sequel.

A browbeating domino effect of more, more, more with special effects that make things easier to see but harder to care about. With great filmmaking power has come great filmmaking laziness that turned a good franchise into candy-colored crud.

A browbeating domino effect of more, more, more with special effects that make things easier to see but harder to care about. With great filmmaking power has come great filmmaking laziness that turned a good franchise into candy-colored crud.
Offering better action, unrivaled special effects, and yet another inner struggle for our main protagonist, "Spider-Man 3" is most certainly the must-see event of the summer.
Offering better action, unrivaled special effects, and yet another inner struggle for our main protagonist, "Spider-Man 3" is most certainly the must-see event of the summer.
Spiderman 3 is best described as a Mexican soap opera with mind-blowing special effects.
Spiderman 3 is best described as a Mexican soap opera with mind-blowing special effects.
A classic of early animation.
Paramount's uneven attempt to challenge Disney in the feature-length animation department.
It doesn't make for a masterpiece, but it can be compelling at points, especially for those interested in this era of animation.
With no plot to speak of, no character development whatsoever, no theme and precious little intrigue, what we have here is simply a pileup of effects. And not especially special effects.
This new round of toe-tapping musical numbers from the penguin population is shot in eye-poppingly gorgeous 3D and guarantees some very sweet holiday box office returns for Warner Bros.
It has less plot than an hour of Sesame Street, fewer jokes than a Republican presidential debate, and astonishing computer animation, in wholly unnecessary 3D.
The animation remains impressive, and there are some very funny moments, courtesy of the talented cast. But fans of the original will want to lower their expectations.

Aside from novel and smart uses of 3D effects, the new movie is largely a bore, all but sidelining Williams and straining to offset the monotony of a protracted rescue story with the sour misadventures of a pair of fussy krill.

It's not very good as a film, but there's no denying its stunning animation, particularly in the service of its two daffiest new characters Will (voice of Brad Pitt) and Bill the Krill (voice of Matt Damon), and its sheer lunacy can be invigorating.
While the film's 3D animation is pretty enough to look at in its large scale aspect, it does little to distract from a meandering story with very little substance.
While the film's 3D animation is pretty enough to look at in its large scale aspect, it does little to distract from a meandering story with very little substance.
Despite some amazing animation and cool song mash-ups, this flat-footed follow-up is as messy and overcrowded as, well, an island packed with poopy penguins.
Technically accomplished and otherwise uninspired sequel to the 2006 CGI hit about a dancing penguin in Antarctica.
Top grade animation and entertaining voice performances from its star packed cast saves Happy Feet Two from drowning in its bigger is better approach.
Does Monsters, Inc. have what it takes to scare the 'S' outta Shrek when it comes to digital animation supremacy? Visually, yes.
The animation has to take a back seat because what's happening emotionally is by its very nature more engaging.
Shrek is a scintilla funnier, Toy Story 2 a hair's breadth more poignant, but MI is every bit as imaginative and lovable as these other contemporary animation classics.
The Pixar computer animation is amazing, more than twice as complex as in Toy Story 2, and the vocals are superb...

Purely realist animation could turn as flat and empty as the worst salon painting of the 19th century, but the Pixar pixies are doing something fresh and fetching, somewhere between Maxfield Parrish and classic Warner Bros.
Another showcase for Pixar's ever-improving animation technology.
Its twists and turns are as unpredictable as they are delightful, and the quality of the animation simply staggering.
It's almost beyond the point to say that this new collaboration between animation behemoths Disney and Pixar is wildly entertaining; what else could it be?
Groundbreaking computer-animation house Pixar has created another wondrous world in Monsters, Inc.
Triumphantly reconfirms the geniuses at Pixar as the 800-pound gorillas of modern animation and the reigning kings of family entertainment.
I have no idea what the creative minds at Pixar Animation Studios do to keep themselves in touch with their inner kids, but if they could bottle it, the world would be a better place.
A smart script, great characters, gorgeous animation, wild colours, superb voice cast -- what's not to love?
With this combination of vocal talent, the colorful computer work, and sparkling script, Monsters, Inc. continues the proud tradition established by the Pixar/Disney animation cooperative.
As witty and inspired as the company's previous animations, this magical tale benefits from its setting, Monstropolis, where monsters of ecery shape and size reside.
Brighter and more exuberant than Shrek, this would be a worthy winner of the first animation Oscar.

Though "Monsters, Inc." relies more on spinning-plates plot than its Pixar peers, this romp retains the charm and heart of the animation juggernaut's forte - adding extra to ordinary hopes, in this case leaving great impressions on the kids we love.
It may be harder nowadays to dazzle audiences with fancy visual effects, but Monsters, Inc. 3D proves that smart, imaginative storytelling still does the trick every time.
Monsters, Inc. continues a positive 3D trend for the company, who appear to be selecting their upgraded titles wisely, choosing features that benefit from the additional depth.
There's really little reason to check out Monsters, Inc. 3D in... well, 3D, rather than going for a good old-fashioned 2D screening instead.
This didn't need 3D to work. It long ago passed the kids-wear-out-the-DVD-rewatching-it test.
A shrewdly timed reminder of Pixar's early, heady days, when the animation powerhouse could do no wrong.

[G]ood writing, great gags, superior animation, perfect casting, over the top energy and cuteness, and above-all - characters guaranteed to make Disney's coffers go "ch-ching" with holiday toy buying!
It's Bullock's first shot at a role in which she plays second fiddle neither to males nor special effects. And she turns out to be every bit as delightful as anyone might have expected.
Borrowing the handheld lensing and easy pace of a low-budget character piece, director Gareth Edwards, a CGI artist by trade, has created a dystopian landscape that's so naturalistic, it's uncanny.
The story is told with a naturalistic style and with the actors improvising with non-actor locals. In the end the film is really about people and not special effects.
Beautifully shot, superbly directed and featuring extremely impressive made-on-a-laptop special effects, this is an engaging, offbeat road movie with strong performances from its two leads.
It proves that you don't need a big budget and overblown special effects to pull off a clever alien movie.
For all James Cameron's trumpeting about a 3D revolution, this efficient little movie could turn out to be the real game-changer of the year.
Monsters asks greater questions of its audience than the usual special effects yawn-fests.

For the first time in ages, a film makes one grateful for special effects: Indeed, it feels as if this is the very story such innovations were invented to enhance. You do, you do, you DO believe in fairies!
Apparently, the filmmakers felt characterization would only get in the way of the special effects.
Even though the film employs up-to-date special effects..., its spirit may be truer to Barrie's ideal than any other film version.
An earnest and enjoyable entertainment that remains loyal to its source if not to those hoping for state-of-the-art special effects.
It's not colourful, it's not fun, it's just a gaudy mess of bad aesthetic choices and cruddy CGI.
The 3D in this film is spectacular. It adds such an incredible element to the movie that I will go as far as to say the film shouldn't be seen in 2D.
lots of gore, a too stingy sprinkling of humor, and horribly overdone, unnecessary 3D effects.
'Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter' is exactly what it sounds like: a CGI-heavy, eye-watering slice of B-movie cheese for the least discerning, most credulous appetites.
When 3D dust-motes and train-engine sparks are the most tempting things to look at, something has failed.
While the character development & screenplay are a complete mess, ALVH, at times, is an incredibly interesting movie [with] some brilliant CGI work & incredible choreography..
Ridiculous and revisionist, redeemed only by Bekmambetov's inventive, R-rated action sequences, particularly the CGI horse stampede.
Rip up the history books and don your 3D glasses for Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, a stupefyingly silly but exuberantly entertaining horror fantasy.

The acting, action and special effects are good enough, but the movie's two mismatched story halves just don't work together. It is like trying to paste the first half of 'Die Hard' onto the last half of '300.'
This adventurous, postmodern exercise works best as an advert for the talents of Yi (who also provides music and animation). Sneaker-clad indie kids should really lap it up.
Snipes kicks major butt with a stylish flair that keeps you watching, despite the indulgent violence, despite the routine CGI special effects that deliver mutations without magic.
Snipes kicks major butt with a stylish flair that keeps you watching, despite the indulgent violence, despite the routine CGI special effects that deliver mutations without magic.
This film seems interested only in wowing us with stunts, makeup, special effects and plot twists that we see coming for miles.
The only dread it inspires is in the possibility that its director prefers turning human flesh into CGI-enhanced mush over exploring genuinely frightening material.
Between action, gunplay, fights, chases, special effects, and offensive one-liners, Blade II pleases on all levels.

Gruseome violence, special effects, fast-moving action, and Del Torro's stylish cutting and framing can't conceal the blank space at the center of the screen, created by David Goyer's inept and uninvolving script.

In the end, that's all this film is: flames, flying bullets, and special effects. It could be worse, I suppose, but as long as people go into this film with their eyes open, there shouldn't be any surprises.
Featuring intense action, exceptional special effects, and a healthy sense of humor, it is the film Last Action Hero wanted--and failed--to be.

movie_name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
review_content: The scenery is beautiful, the special effects look wonderfully expensive, and the quips are vintage Harrison Ford.

movie_name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
review_content: Self-aware in the best possible way, Kingdom of the Crystal Skull cultivates a collective sense of nostalgia that carries it past mumbo-jumbo story developments and action scenes that could have used less CGI.

movie_name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
review_content: With moviegoers facing a grim season of pallid CGI battle-toons ... even the problematic adventures of one Indiana Jones can feel like a rich banquet in comparison.

movie_name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
review_content: Good special effects, an entertaining story and nostalgia... [Full review in Spanish]
There's enough special effects razzle-dazzle to distract the average ten-year-old, but the script by William Osborne and Michael McCullers is stilted and humorless -- a little camp might have helped.

Horror is the realization that things you don't know can hurt you. The Blair Witch Project brings horror back into theaters at a time when most 'horror' movies are displays of gory special effects or self-referential humor.
Unfortunately, Blair Witch is far from being an antidote to rampant special effects over-dependence.
Adds a few fresh twists to a genre that has too long relied only on special effects gimmickry.
The Blair Witch Project remains a welcome change from studio blockbusters, as it's more preoccupied with human behavior than with special effects.
It is a triumph of intelligence over special effects, guerrilla filmmaking over Hollywood spectacle.
McKean, who both directed and designed the film, employs an array of techniques -- cel animation, computer animation and puppetry -- in wild and witty variations.
Even the kids in the audience will feel a bit insulted by the dumbed-down dialogue and a bit cheated by the bargain-basement special effects.
Roughly what Romancing the Stone would have been like as a 1970s Disney flick had CGI been available, Nim's Island is strictly for the 8-and-under crowd.
It's a wondrous and warmhearted adventure story with some nifty special effects and some first-rate performances.
The whole film has tremendous visual style, and the frequent bursts of violence are delivered with a clever and often hilarious use of special effects.
Twilight works best when it ignores the superficial thrills of special effects and set pieces and chooses to examine the eminently sexier landscape of the characters' emotions.

Some will find it all too polite, but compared to rival blockbuster exercises in explosive CGI mayhem, its character-based index of longing and protectiveness at least provides a viable alternative moodscape.

It is not all top-notch stuff though. Some of the special effects are plain ropey but luckily the teen romance carries the movie. Naturally room is left at the end for the impending sequel. Something we're sure to get our teeth into...

Destined to be a massive hit with its target audience of teenage girls, Twilight nails its central romance and remains an enjoyably watchable thriller, despite the odd bit of dodgy dialogue and some amusingly rubbish special effects.
Kudos to the excellent Paul Giamatti as well as Craig Bierko, Paddy Considine, Bruce McGill and Canadian veterans Chuck Shamata (the priest) and Nicholas Campbell (the sports columnist).
Ghost' is too slow moving at times, and a few of its special effects look incongruously silly, particularly those showing what happens to ghosts not as virtuous as Sam.
a deft blending of comedy and suspense, with some impressive special effects that are incorporated into the film instead of being the center of it.
Ghost is a movie about corporate malfeasance and greed, aided by bloody awful early CGI and predicting the basic flippancy of Forrest Gump and American Beauty.
What it offers, apart from the overblown special effects that seem inescapable in American movies, is an unusual and effective combination of swooning, morbid romance and screwball comedy.
The special effects are a real treat, the love-beyond-the-grave theme is very touching and the ending is a wonderful piece of schmaltz.

movie_name: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer
review_content: The animation is wretched, and the whole thing is so sickly sweet as to be almost nauseating.

movie_name: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer
review_content: The animation is wretched, and the whole thing is so sickly sweet as to be almost nauseating.

movie_name: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer
review_content: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer is not an especially imaginative tale, and the animation is at times lifeless.

movie_name: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer
review_content: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer is not an especially imaginative tale, and the animation is at times lifeless.

movie_name: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer
review_content: An exemplar of the state of children animation from that era if I ever saw one. Not a compliment, that.

movie_name: Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer
review_content: An exemplar of the state of children animation from that era if I ever saw one. Not a compliment, that.

It's full of special effects that are big on smoke and noise, but short on logic and payoff. Scenes are sloppily edited, as if to imply that lower standards can acceptably be palmed off on kiddie audiences.
Mediocre. But for The Weinsteins in animation? That's an improvement.
The colorful animation can't compensate for a mediocre script that generally lacks depth, excitement and consistent laughs.
Aliens of all shapes and sizes provide amusing banter in this likeable, happy and colourful 3D animation in which planets are saved and family ties nurtured.
Aliens of all shapes and sizes provide amusing banter in this likeable, happy and colourful 3D animation in which planets are saved and family ties nurtured.
A painted-by-numbers 3D kid-flick enlivened mostly by Rob Corddry, who plays the fastidious, nerdy brother to Brendan Fraser's doomed Buzz Lightyear clone.
The animation is hardly out of this world, but a script polish from Stephen Fry and others means that there is a sprinkling of good gags to accompany the siblings' adventures.

Director Watkins and his leading man Radcliffe have both succeeded in making a truly haunting classic ghost story that is also an effective modern horror film without ever needing to rely on CGI or intrusive music cues.

review_content: Not top-notch Disney animation, but still OK.
