review_content: It feels older than contemporary Disney work due to flat, creaky animation. The story still has resonance for kids, though.

genres: ['Coming of age', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Historical fiction', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', "Children's Fantasy", 'Drama', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Family Film', 'Mythological Fantasy', 'Sword and sorcery films']
review_content: There is still some life in the characterizations, though the animation is turning stiff and flat.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: Overlong, but any film that can make Brad Pitt look homely deserves to sweep the special effects awards.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: The movie looks amazing. And for the first hour, when storytelling and special effects bond like lovers, it plays even better.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: I am not exaggerating when I say this is one of the best flicks to come out in years. It is perfect in every aspect of filmmaking, i.e. acting, directing, pacing, editing, make-up, set design, special effects.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: The literal Benjamin Button that Fincher and Pitt have created with special effects is bland and passive even in the years when you'd think a reverse-ager would be most conflicted, fatalistic, or wise.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: The A-list cheekbones, CGI wow factor and sensous cinematography can't save it. This is Hollywood at full bluster -- spectacular and sometimes iconic, but emotionally half baked.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: Enjoyable, engaging and beautifully made drama with stunning special effects and terrific performances from Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: Remove "curious" from the title and replace it with "twee and pointless", and you're close to it. What a incredible shaggy-puppy of a movie, a cobweb-construction patched together with CGI, prosthetics, gibberish and warm tears.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: Fincher treats Roth's script with a visual bravura and narrative gusto far beyond the usual capacities of the Hollywood mainstream. Benjamin Button is a poetic, virtuoso feat, as eloquent and rapturous as CGI-era cinema gets.

movie_name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
review_content: On the one hand, it is a masterful piece of craftsmanship, replete with outstanding cinematography, set design and special effects makeup work. On the other hand, it's slow-paced and overstuffed, not to mention
A mix of interviews, reality-TV style behind-the-scenes footage and 3D concert scenes, the movie is attractively, if conventionally, assembled.
Whether you are a fan of Katy Perry's music or not, Part of Me 3D offers a captivating glimpse into a superstar's life with fun and heart-rending honesty, that rarely feels contrived.
This frothy 3D concert doc often plays like a Perry ad campaign, assuring viewers that their "Teenage Dream" diva is a good, fun-loving person, and that, by God, she's doing fine.
Fun, revealing doc about one pop sensation who has truly earned her place in the sun, although the 3D is wholly unnecessary.
Enjoyable sequel that improves considerably on the original film thanks to some terrific special effects and strong performances...
At the very least, this new adventure has stronger CGI and 3D, but there's not enough improvement in production imagination to make this second chapter leap off the screen.
Big-budget 3D junk, but director Jonathan Liebesman has a flair for it, and most of the actors appear to be having a juicy good time.
While the special effects are sharper than in Clash of the Titans, the dialogue is equally uninspired.
From top-grade 3D to a multitude of monsters and a welcome influx of acting talent, this is pure popcorn pleasure.
You get an idea of who the major players are, and then they spend a modest amount of time shouting laughable dialogue at one another while being all but forced off the screen by special effects.
Yes the story is paint by the numbers and Worthington is well, you know, but this is a nice example of spectacle film making on a budget. Most of the large 3D set pieces work really well.
It's a rollicking ride with some of the best use of 3D that I've seen since Avatar.

The problem with a film that uses CGI as a substitute for good writing is that virtually every picture that comes along nowadays has impressive visual effects; this has leveled the playing field, to say the least.
Greek gods and demigods return in a spiffed-up adventure involving Hydras, Cyclops, and Kronos himself. Strong 3D effects help make this worth seeing.
...nothing but mindless special effects.
The father of the gods turned out to be a CGI-created, lava-spewing, mountain-sized creature with smudgy features and all the eloquence of a belch.
The good news is: "Wrath" is a much better film than "Clash" - lighter, more agile, with much better special effects and pretty decent 3-D.
Expect an action-stuffed 3D extravaganza with very little subtext to it ... you'll come away with a smile on your face but strained eyeballs and a queasiness in the belly.

Featuring strong performances by Neeson and Fiennes, "Wrath of the Titans" features some brilliant effects (the fire and ash monster that is Kronus) and, though still converted, much better 3D then the last film.
Paying the extra bucks to see this in 3D is a poor investment, as the effects are, once again, unimpressive.
All that eye strain from the first film's horrible 3D conversion has now been eradicated and replaced with extra boredom.
A better story, more humor, and a decent 3D conversion make the swordplay spectacle more tolerable. And hey, 2 Oscar winners play Greek gods!

Near-epic in preposterousness. So, swamped by CGI spectacle, wonder: what came first, overblown super-sneezes of action or the tissue-thin plot to wrap them in? Forget gods getting it on with humans; here, non-story meets quasi-show, begets a demi-star.
...all spectacle and little plot, all show and little characterization, all CGI and little story.
Wrath of the Titans doesn't exist to tell you a story, but instead to blow you away with the sheer awesomeness of its 3-D special effects.
...takes viewers back to a pre-CGI era when fantastic beasts and amazing worlds were created on screen using puppets and models.

movie_name: Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town
review_content: Filled with fun ideas and intricate wood-figure animation, Santa Claus might be the Rankin-Bass high-water mark.

movie_name: Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town
review_content: Filled with fun ideas and intricate wood-figure animation, Santa Claus might be the Rankin-Bass high-water mark.

movie_name: Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town
review_content: I know it's a classic but the too-bright colors and weird animation style just doesn't work for me.

movie_name: Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town
review_content: I know it's a classic but the too-bright colors and weird animation style just doesn't work for me.
Naim's script is intelligent, but not always easy to follow. It is an example of a fully adult science fiction film and one that does not require any special effects.

It's a keenly enjoyable celebration of teenage insecurity and - for hairy-handed teenage hordes - offers the first chance to see Amish breasts since Harrison Ford clocked Kelly McGillis in in Witness.

It's a keenly enjoyable celebration of teenage insecurity and - for hairy-handed teenage hordes - offers the first chance to see Amish breasts since Harrison Ford clocked Kelly McGillis in in Witness.
Men in Black has the right attitude toward movie technology: Get the most sophisticated special effects money can buy, and treat 'em like one of Ed Wood's paper-plate UFOs.

For once, the summer formula works like a charm: two superstars, a couple of quirky sidekicks, a slew of special effects, a mess o' smart-alecky remarks--yet there's still room for semi-believable characters and a sturdy story.
Great special effects, inventive alien designs and Smith and Jones's hip, hilarious double act make director Barry Sonnenfeld's Lethal Weapon-style buddy picture a fast-paced pleasure.
The plot, trifling as it is, doesn't much matter. What makes the movie such a hoot are the clever gags, imaginative special effects, and the snappy byplay between the well-matched Jones and Smith.
Men in Black is the wryest, sharpest, most entertaining special effects film in recent memory, a simultaneous participant and mocking parody of the more-bang-for-your-buck behemoth genre.
Men In Black deserves credit for supplementing its special effects with a breezy script and genuinely charismatic performances by Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones.
There was reason to believe that "Jaws 2" would be a mess. It isn't. It's better than most sequels. It's formula-ridden but slick, and the special effects work as intended.

movie_name: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
review_content: This 'collector's edition' will probably go down in film history as the definitive one unless, like me, you think the movie works best in its original version, wherein the special effects of adult delinquency are left unknown.

movie_name: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
review_content: ...a masterful motion picture all around...where the interactions of its characters are equally important as the wizardry of the special effects.

movie_name: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
review_content: What I could see of the special effects were wonderful, and they hold up over time, unlike many sci-fi movies. The landing scene at the end still fills you with wonder and amazement.

movie_name: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
review_content: The special effects are spectacular, John Williams's score is emotionally charged, nouvelle vague director Franois Truffaut makes an elegant UFO expert and it's impossible not to get caught up in the protracted climax.
The characters, attitudes, dialogue, plot crisis and special effects of The Losers are pretty much interchangeable with every other film version of a graphic novel.
The script is sharp and the action from multiple locations so gloriously over-the-top it doesn't matter whenever the special effects aren't up to much.
A calculated but very entertaining special effects extravaganza.
Take away the CGI mayhem and what emerges is a rather touching tale of second chances and innocence prematurely lost.
Great special effects and exciting adventure stuff. A bit of a slow buildup and unnecessarily dead parents.
The battle scenes soar, thanks to top-notch and thrilling special effects. Quieter scenes give characters added dimension, such as those that address one officer's drinking problem.
The battle scenes soar, thanks to top-notch and thrilling special effects. Quieter scenes give characters added dimension, such as those that address one officer's drinking problem.

Thankfully, much of Red Tails is spent in the skies, where fighter planes swoop and zoom in thrilling dogfights... George Lucas apparently gave up the key to his CGI kingdom, creating marvelously designed in-flight action and a sappy, snappy salute.

Thankfully, much of Red Tails is spent in the skies, where fighter planes swoop and zoom in thrilling dogfights... George Lucas apparently gave up the key to his CGI kingdom, creating marvelously designed in-flight action and a sappy, snappy salute.
Executive producer George Lucas brings a healthy dose of his Star Wars magic to the CGI of the spectacular aerial sequences.
Executive producer George Lucas brings a healthy dose of his Star Wars magic to the CGI of the spectacular aerial sequences.
Unprecedented special effects and sets perhaps the first great achievement of cinematic epic mythopoeia, and the forerunner to the likes of The Lord of the Rings.

[Anna May Wong] has no trouble stealing every scene she's in, and there's plenty of visual trickery here, sometimes including real apes, elephants, and tigers, to capture the imagination of even the most CGI-jaded viewers.
Propelled by the actor's acrobatic stunts and groundbreaking special effects, Thief of Bagdad is pure pleasure.
The movie finally is never very convincing. Even the special effects aren't great.
This is an inspirational sports drama stuffed full of Christian values and CGI that draws the eye in ways both good and bad.
This is an inspirational sports drama stuffed full of Christian values and CGI that draws the eye in ways both good and bad.
The film is not perfect - the narration is unnecessary, the surfing special effects look cheap and Carrie Underwood is unsteady in her cameo - but it's moving, anyway.
The film is not perfect - the narration is unnecessary, the surfing special effects look cheap and Carrie Underwood is unsteady in her cameo - but it's moving, anyway.

The brazenly cheap look to the special effects sends the film into MST3K territory, and it's certainly the most hilariously awful surprise attack by a shark since Samuel L. Jackson got devoured by one in Deep Blue Sea.

The brazenly cheap look to the special effects sends the film into MST3K territory, and it's certainly the most hilariously awful surprise attack by a shark since Samuel L. Jackson got devoured by one in Deep Blue Sea.
It's ultimately let down by some heavy-handed sentimentality, an over-abundance of Bible-bashing and some dodgy CGI sequences.
It's ultimately let down by some heavy-handed sentimentality, an over-abundance of Bible-bashing and some dodgy CGI sequences.
Overall, though the message is solid, it is too convoluted and graphic, and even more unfortunately, the music is uninspired and the animation is generic.
This movie represents a low point in Disney animation, occasionally resembling a high-budget Saturday morning cartoon.
Makes a strong argument in favor of traditional animation.
As welcome as a gentle breeze through the hibiscus, with animation that shows those CGI smarties that there are still a few things machines can't do.
As welcome as a gentle breeze through the hibiscus, with animation that shows those CGI smarties that there are still a few things machines can't do.

If "Lilo & Stitch" isn't the most edgy piece of Disney animation to hit the silver screen, then this first film to use a watercolor background since "Dumbo" certainly ranks as the most original in years.

Disney animation has always been based in the world of fairy tales, where evil breaks up families. In Lilo & Stitch, Disney for the first time speaks to the cultural phenomena of this generation, the healthy broken family.
Certainly the hippest of Disney's animation, "Lilo & Stitch" has more in common with "Edward Scissorhands" than "Snow White."
What's a bit disappointing is the hand-drawn animation, resembling the old Looney Tunes cartoons.
The movie's slightly offbeat tone and comic rhythms work well with the simple and bright animation techniques.
A half-hearted effort by Disney's traditional animation department.
Putting aside the Pixar computer animated offerings, this is the best Disney animation in nearly a decade.
A raucous comedy/adventure [and] easily one of the strangest products to ever emerge from the Disney animation pipeline.
Similar to most contemporary American feature-length animation, the film's overall structure is frayed.
Easily one of the strangest products to ever emerge from the Disney animation pipeline.
The BEST production supported by the animation studio during the first decade of the 21st century. [Full Review in Spanish]
Starring bright animation and the voices of Justin Long and Dawyne Johnson, Planet 51 follows a hilarious concept with weak execution and way too many references to better films.
... characters are as thin and unengaging as the animation is sleek and shiny.
An often amusing, harmless adventure with enough inoffensive humor and impressive CGI animation to make up for its lack of exhilarating moments and refreshing surprises.
An often amusing, harmless adventure with enough inoffensive humor and impressive CGI animation to make up for its lack of exhilarating moments and refreshing surprises.
It's cute, it's passable, the animation is fine--but the major problem with the film is its predictability.
A tale of human/alien friendship, Planet 51 seems worse than it is because it comes at the end of one of the best years in the history of animation.
After all the other animated CGI films this year, Planet 51 just feels like a rehash, and not nearly as charming as it wants to be.
...a mildly entertaining, visually well-crafted animation that can wait for rental.
Good fun if you can put up with the pastel colours and plasticky textures, which show that in modern fantasy animation all that pixellates isn't Pixar.
In terms of animation, Planet 51 is out of this world. Then there's the story and the characters, which are about as dull as a dirty penny.
The animation itself is beautiful to behold.

It's overlong and a times sluggish. The fights and battles, designed to give an epic fantasy feel to the movie, are grave miscalculations. And the overabundance of CGI often makes Noah look like a video game.
Stirring, spiritual, and thoughtful, with superb special effects and a genuine curiosity for the wonderful mysteries of faith.
To see such a profound meditation on man's relationship to God come from a movie full of prehistoric hoodies, pregnancy tests performed by magic leaf, and CGI rock people is gloriously insane.
Given its visual splendor and epic sweep, Noah might have been a terrific 3D movie, but that would have given the film's landscape two more dimensions than either the characters or the story.
In some ways, Noah resembles one of those Kirk Cameron movies about the apocalypse, only with a better cast and more dazzling special effects.
The CGI animals are spectacular, the battles less so and, though none of it really makes sense, neither, some might argue, does the Bible.
While technically impressive, Noah shines brighter when it shies away from CGI.
Once the film has blown it's CGI load, it turns into a kitchen sink drama, an episode of Eastenders as directed by Mike Leigh.
The strong suit of the film is not the animation, however, it is the story and the character development.
The strong suit of the film is not the animation, however, it is the story and the character development.
The deadly combo of leaden animation, sorry scriptwriting, and limp pacing throttle every attempt at humor.
The deadly combo of leaden animation, sorry scriptwriting, and limp pacing throttle every attempt at humor.
The plot, dialogue, and animation are no better than the low standards of Saturday morning television.
An appealing, contemporary piece of animation.
The plot, dialogue, and animation are no better than the low standards of Saturday morning television.
An appealing, contemporary piece of animation.
The animation is consistently excellent
Some of its segments are brilliant and breathtaking examples of animation. Unfortunately, as with the average music CD, for every great track there's usually a "filler" song.
The jokes in The In-Laws are pretty good. The special effects? Not so much.
It's wonderful watching Michael Douglas and Albert Brooks having so much fun. It's also great to see a summer movie that doesn't rely on special effects.
Oliver & Company is a funny, zestful, colorful cartoon, created with quality animation that blends well-rounded cel painting and smooth computer-generated drawings.
Surely one of Disney's weakest full-length animated features, Oliver and Company features terrible, badly dated songs and some shoddy, patchwork animation with precious few dazzling moments.
More notable for what it isn't than what it is, it's one of the gangly middle children of the Disney animation family, not quite sure how to fit in, or even if it's valued.
The animation is clumsy, the songs are forgettable, the attempts at late-80s relevance now come across as dated and slightly embarrassing.
The last gasp of Disney Animation's post-Walt malaise before the 1990s Disney renaissance … retains Dickens's seamy milieu, but not his morality-play tableau.
The computer-assisted animation is relatively stiff and inexpressive.
The animation is fairly unexciting though serviceable, and the overall mystification of class difference would probably have made Dickens shudder, but kids should find this tolerable enough.
The general quality of the animation and script would disappoint more sophisticated viewers.
Suffers from a rote storyline and flat animation.
The cartoon action will delight young children, while older ones, who usually reject animation as "kid stuff," will enjoy the rock songs and hip characters, especially the brash Tito.
A film packed with superb animation, songs and a nifty story line. And it's all set to a cadence of love, laced with some danger.
With its captivating characters, sprightly songs and zap-happy animation, Oliver & Company adds up to a tip-top frolic.
This picture never accumulates the sense of shared adventure that the first one did, and though the special effects are even better than before, they cannot be new twice.
The eye-popping special effects in The Matrix Reloaded -- possibly the coolest, boldest and most fluid ever put on screen -- should please even jaded moviegoers.
More special effects. More fight sequences. More chases. More stunts. More neo-philosophical babble. But more, in this case, adds up to less.
Perhaps because this story is slacker, it's more obvious the way the Wachowskis strain to keep us wowed -- not only in special effects and action scenes but also with dialogue and fashion, too.
When it comes to visuals, The Matrix Reloaded doesn't disappoint; in fact, the movie is probably the most realistic looking special effects feature ever made.

Special effects in Hollywood blockbusters often have the feel of compulsory piecework performed by bored technicians. The people who contribute the effects in Reloaded appear to be excited by them, and they want us to be excited.
The most astonishing special effects to come along this week.
The good news is that the excitement and special effects are amazing once again.
If you're in it for the action sequences and special effects, then The Matrix Reloaded is worth seeing on the big screen.
It is worth watching, if nothing else, for the great fight scenes, a great car chase and great special effects.
[D]azzling special effects, lots of action, and some mind bending philosophizing.
The Wachowskis manage to surprise and amaze with some stunning machine special effects and great scenes that truly dazzle the mind.
Special effects don't mean much unless we care about the characters who are surrounded by them, and in this movie the characters often seem to exist only to fill up the foregrounds.

Parents will no doubt have memories of this delightful film, which first aired in 1964, from their own childhoods. And you can't watch it without appreciating the simplicity of a pre-computer-animation world.
It has the courtesy to tie up everything with a nice little bow, + the nifty special effects climax of [the] serious wallop at the end. . .
It has the courtesy to tie up everything with a nice little bow, + the nifty special effects climax of [the] serious wallop at the end. . .

Verbinski makes a couple of inventive additions, and although the spine-chilling terror of the superior 1997 original is muted by the overuse of CGI, this is still a worthy substitute if you're not in the mood for subtitles.

Verbinski makes a couple of inventive additions, and although the spine-chilling terror of the superior 1997 original is muted by the overuse of CGI, this is still a worthy substitute if you're not in the mood for subtitles.

Resembles nothing so much as a dumbed-down, PG-13 version of Kill Bill, put together by a team tone-deaf to bad dialogue, atrocious acting, cheesy special effects and clumsily staged action sequences.
[With] dialogue as half-assed as its entry-level CGI effects, Elektra lacks thrills, narrative, emotion, believability, character development-and frankly-watchability.
The special effects are well realized and enough attention is paid to the character of Elektra to make her a formidable rival to any number of Wolverines.

With such canny scene-stealers as Gwynne, Smith, Pendleton, McGill and Chaykin filling out the cast, it is very hard for My Cousin Vinny to go wrong, and indeed, for the purpose of pleasant Saturday night entertainment, it does not.
For interplay and intrigue, Doubt weaves a tense, gun-free thriller where the only special effects are a light bulb and a wind machine.

Layered with all types of visual decoration to make the torrent of discussion play cinematically, and, though the device is now a familiar one, certain touches such as B&W animation lend a creepy and effective mood.

Layered with all types of visual decoration to make the torrent of discussion play cinematically, and, though the device is now a familiar one, certain touches such as B&W animation lend a creepy and effective mood.
It is also beautifully crafted, filled with slippery bits of black and white animation that graphically illustrate some of the points being made.
It is also beautifully crafted, filled with slippery bits of black and white animation that graphically illustrate some of the points being made.
Never Say Never is a legit documentary made for the fans and the haters. I dare anyone to watch this movie and tell me they weren't inspired. The 3D was fantastic!
Never Say Never is a 3D concert film to delight the shy 13-year-old with braces that lives in all of us, but after a while the movie starts to feel like lethal injection by bubblegum.
Director Chu keeps things moving briskly, even if the film is far too long. But the 3D is playfully deployed.

If you were wondering what the fuss is all about, check out this high energy 3D concert film which documents how Justin Bieber, the teen singing phenomenon, has rocketed to superstardom through social media.
Though billed as a 3D film, it only applies to the concert footage, though it's difficult to imagine any of his fans complaining.

movie_name: Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk
review_content: Grand Canyon is such fun to watch with its superb, 3D quality that it's impossible not to be more caught up, albeit temporarily, in the illusion of getting splashed than in the unsettling realities of the environmental crisis it describes.

movie_name: Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk
review_content: As entertainment, it can be heart-poundingly exciting. As education, it has some merit. But as a movie, Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk 3D is kind of a mess.
The schmaltz is laid on thick, but kids love this sort of stuff and, refreshingly, the dog bits are done the old-fashioned, fun way: with animal trainers rather than CGI.

But what really sets "A Goofy Movie" apart is the slam-bang sense of humor, with sight gags, physical humor and verbal banter that is perfectly timed. And timing is everything in movie comedy - whether it's live-action or animation.
The CGI alien is very well articulated, and Rogen is a virtuoso at mixing motormouthed rudeness with a hint of tenderness to take off the edge.
A tightly controlled low-budget chiller whose occasional moments of unexpected special effects are set up beautifully by long periods of suspense.
Dumb jokes, cheap special effects and Murphy's mugging add up to an eternity in 92 minutes.
There are still some things that magnificent prose can do that a movie, for all its stars and CGI, just can't. Director John Hillcoat's movie is, however, an admirable attempt.
Hillcoat wisely uses a low-key combination of location footage and CGIs to create a sad industrial wasteland that is more reminiscent of Tarkovsky's Stalker than Mad Max.
... it's too bad what could have been a beautifully crushing family drama was usurped by a massive amount of unnecessary special effects clouding the real story.
The ultimate in special effects movies ... Unfortunately, the story being told is not the best that Disney has presented as its annual animated masterpiece.

For each of its grotesque 84 minutes I stared at the screen depressed and appalled, realising I was watching something historic -- the moment when feature-length Disney animation became a dinosaur itself.
Compounding the problems is the weird confluence of genuine landscape photography with digital animation.

Though the enhanced location background shots are so-so, the character animation is amazing, with details of scales, fur, facial expressions (which you just have to grant the dinosaurs), baggy skin and wet bodies in rainstorms.
Offers $200 million in special effects and a script worth about 2 cents. Still, that won't bother the picture's target audience.
A must-see for anyone who wants to see the next stage in computer-generated animation.
This big-budget marvel raises the bar for the animation community, even if its script doesn't have the spark and sheer entertainment value of recent Disney cartoon features.
A visual breakthrough in realistic computer animation that should delight kids -- and adults, at least for the first half-hour.
Dinosaur cuts a bland, compliant figure, its narrative and characterizations subservient to splashy feats of CGI legerdemain.
If you look past the seamlessly realistic CGI, there's nothing at all memorable about the movie.
The simplest story since Fantasia - but the animation will knock your hair off. I was agape at what a bunch of 1s & zeros can do.
A skillful blend of old-fashioned Disney storytelling and newfangled computer animation makes for an effective and frequently spectacular summer family film.
The real reason to go to this film is the animation, which places these ultra-realistic, digitally created characters with "real," live-action backgrounds that have been digitally doctored.
Directors Ralph Zondag and Eric Leighton deserve high praise for their innovative blend of filmed settings and CGI wizardry.
A case of everything old feeling new again, for it is truly a refreshing and boundary-pushing entry in the world of feature animation.
A case of everything old feeling new again, for it is truly a refreshing and boundary-pushing entry in the world of feature animation.
Roadside Romeo might mark a big jump forward for Indian animation, but it has to find its own place in the sun and grow as a distinct genre than remaining content as an adjunct of Bollywood.
Roadside Romeo might mark a big jump forward for Indian animation, but it has to find its own place in the sun and grow as a distinct genre than remaining content as an adjunct of Bollywood.
Indian animation has finally come of age. Roadside Romeo, the first Walt Disney-Yashraj [Films] rollout is a barrel of fun.
Indian animation has finally come of age. Roadside Romeo, the first Walt Disney-Yashraj [Films] rollout is a barrel of fun.
Robin Williams and animation were born for one another, and in Aladdin they finally meet.
The fundamentals here go beyond first-rate: animation both gorgeous and thoughtful, several wonderful songs and a wealth of funny minor figures on the sidelines, practicing foolproof Disney tricks.
Grants all three wishes and some more besides with a brilliant turn from Williams' genie and some beautiful animation.
This hilariously hip and thoroughly gorgeous motion picture is nothing less than the crowning achievement -- so far -- of Disney's revitalized animation department.
Robin Williams's vocal performance as the Genie steals the show in this beautifully constructed Disney animation, his ad-libbing a perfect match for the wonderful visuals.
Behind the mask of animation, Williams has discovered a limitless stage for stand-up comedy.
The magical, the mystical, the mysterious -- all those powers that lurk within movies but are rarely tapped are unleashed in Disney's latest magnificent animation, Aladdin.
Maintains a bankable charm and innocence even when overdrawn on the special effects side.
This cheeky fable rests on the slender shoulders of Etel and McGibbon, and the lovely, natural performances Boyle elicits from them are the film's real miracle.
In the gospel according to Boyle, he sacrifices storytelling on the altar of eye-catching special effects. After deductions, Millions is only worth a few smiles.
Bring on the DDT. A silly giant-bug opus with cheap special effects.
Cheap special effects and nonexistent horror in a 'horror' flick make for one boring waste of celluloid.
Periodic moments of good special effects are separated by reels of dramatic banality as players flounder in flimsy dialog and under sluggish direction.
Kahn delivers an action pic whose CGI effects more closely resemble a video game than reality and whose organizing principle is the three-minute music video...
It's acceptable to use CGI to enhance the action, but this movie takes it over the line. When everything is artificial, it's impossible to create excitement or suspense.
Despite the cascade of wondrous special effects, massive battles between the kids and pirates and face-offs between Pan and Hook, the film doesn't truly take flight.
It's a lot of fun to watch - over two hours of thrills, spills, elaborate sets and special effects, all tied together by a pleasingly varied (and lighter than usual) musical score by John Williams.
Delivers thrilling action, witty dialogue and genuine emotion, thanks to a cleverly crafted script, state-of-the-art special effects, strong, likeable characters and note-perfect performances.
An outrageously entertaining, CGI-soaked tale of foreboding that transforms into a good-natured send-up of everything that proceeded it, replete with gags galore.
The epic action brought nerd tears to my eyes! Shane Black delivers a witty, action-packed flick with great twists. See it in 2D as the 3D conversion lacks great depth!
...the best of the Marvel films with its complex story, exciting action, great cast and special effects.
Beyond all the explosions and action set pieces and 3D wizardry, you can still hear a writer with a distinctive, entertaining voice.

movie_name: Honey, I Blew Up the Kid
review_content: The laughs run out early and the balance of the film relies on special effects to tickle the audience's funny bone.
The special effects are spectacular, and the final attacks on Zion are amazing -- too long, but amazing. But the emotional impact of this movie is zilch.
I did like this film a little more than Reloaded, if only because all of the hogwash psycho-babble is replaced by wicked CGI shoot-outs.
Worthy of theater viewing based only on the mind-blowing CGI which take effects to a new level. The story's no longer intriguing, just the action.
...the Wachowskis' blast of special effects and pointless plot complications...is such a failure that it threatens to retroactively sully the virtues of the first film.

The Wachowskis may have something in their theory that the world is simply a complex operating system humans are simply virtual programs.... Their dialogue feels written by a computer program, and for that matter acted by a collection of CGI figures.

Concerning the removal of a certain diabolical curse which keeps two lovers always together, yet always apart, Ladyhawke is a successful, unpretentious little film that uses strong characterization rather than special effects to achieve its goals.
Gillespie's Fright Night retains the cool but spooky factor of the first film, with a couple of 3D effects thrown in ... provides a fang full of fun.
Badly written, lethargically directed, smothering the few fun performances that could have saved it, Fright Night 3D sucks.
Finally - after a long dry spell - here's a vampire movie that doesn't suck. This makes it seem better than it is, as long as you don't squeeze your eyeballs in a 3D theater.
A few cool 3D effects are the only improvement Fright Night offers over the campy original.
Entertaining horror comedy remake with strong performances, an amusing script and some inventively used 3D effects, though it's never quite as scary or as funny as it ought to be.
A boring revamp, with dull 3D effects, insipid teenage protagonists and only sporadically scary outbursts of neck-biting, crucifix-wielding and staking through the heart.
It is entertaining, thanks to superior CGI effects and, most of all, Farrell's knowing and understated performance.
The original's homoerotic aspect has been dropped, the special effects are far more elaborate and the action infinitely more violent.
Fright Night 3D qualifies as a successful entry in a tricky genre - blending flip humour and emotional intensity in a way that feels true after its fashion to the facts of teenage life.
Can a 3D horror movie be a thing of beauty? In the case of this gorgeously shot remake, the answer is "Yes!"
Shot and presented in 3D, this is one film where 3d is not only appropriate, but works brilliantly.
Like so many of Disney's revampings (see Flubber), it's merely another disappointing attempt to revive the old chestnuts by larding them up with special effects.

This is not a story that cries out to be remade every 15-20 years. And, while the special effects and acting are getting better, the story isn't.
Modest and diverting, rough and bland, with some good (if not quite Bette Davis caliber) actors and so-so special effects.

I've seen Disney put better looking productions together for their cable television channel, so much of this looking so horrible and unfinished it makes the special effects of the previous efforts look like excerpts from The Matrix.

a decent and at times entertaining bit of kid-centric fantastical escapism that alternates its hectic chase sequences and special effects spectacle with comedy involving government conspiracies and a geeky sci-fi convention.

a decent and at times entertaining bit of kid-centric fantastical escapism that alternates its hectic chase sequences and special effects spectacle with comedy involving government conspiracies and a geeky sci-fi convention.
There are decent special effects, and Johnson can play it tough while also being a kid-friendly presence.
There are decent special effects, and Johnson can play it tough while also being a kid-friendly presence.
The hardware is played down this time and the result is character intensive movie that just so happens to have some of the best special effects of the season.
While the special effects may seem absurd when compared to all the CG images that inhabit most of today's blockbusters, this 1956 piece still focuses on a coherent storyline.
A huge, CGI-heavy popcorner that still feels personal. Come for the epic monster-on-mecha showdowns, stay for the likeable humans.

The squarest, clunkiest and certainly loudest movie of director Guillermo del Toro's career, a crushed-metal orgy that plays like an extended 3D episode of "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers" on very expensive acid.
Countless times audiences have seen mass destruction Hollywood style, but rarely do the characters match the strength of the special effects and Pacific Rim features the year's best.
What isn't to like about Pacific Rim? This bludgeoning 3D creature feature is a slick bit of movie mayhem.
Disappointing robots vs monsters blockbuster that features spectacular special effects but is let down by poor acting and a painfully dull script.

... the grace of movement established goes a long way in showing what is so wrong about the hyperkinetic animation employed in every Marvel Universe film. The Kaiju universe deserved and received more reverence than that ...
You could make another film for half the budget in the time it takes to roll the end credits for CGI imaging. There's stuff to look at, but doesn't anybody care that it doesn't make a word of sense?
Heavy handed, heavy jointed, lacquered with heavy use of 3D and bulked up by long stretches of heavy machines swinging around heavy globs of concentrated CGI.
Heavy handed, heavy jointed, lacquered with heavy use of 3D and bulked up by long stretches of heavy machines swinging around heavy globs of concentrated CGI.

Impressive CGI, but loud, long, inane and bland with many plot holes and tedious action sequences that are more exhausting and underwhelming than exhilarating. It fails to display the brilliance of filmmaker Guillermo del Toro.
There really is something different this time around, and it is not just the sophisticated special effects.
A pic made for those who can appreciate the sophisticated special effects over all else.
Guillermo del Toro delivers on the special effects but the plot is a little weak.
Pacific Rim is, as you might expect, a visual extravaganza brimming with lush colors, state-of-the-art CGI effects and the promised robots on monsters hard-core fights to the death.
Pacific Rim is what every summer blockbuster should be: loud, ridiculous fun, but with thought and effort behind all the special effects.
This movie's special effects, set design, actionsequence staging and swirling cinematography offset the weak story.
An A-list cast and director, a huge budget and endless special effects are employed in the service of what is essentially a B movie.
The special effects are terrific, but as the dialog and plot veer into 2001 and Close Encounters territory, Mission misses.
Never forgets that special effects and sheer spectacle mean nothing if there aren't relatable characters and an emotional thematic throughline to first and foremost care about.
Super 8 is a welcome dose of nostalgia, since we're reminded that CGI-heavy disaster flicks can still maintain essential ingredients like character and heart.

An underwhelming sci-fi adventure with nifty special effects and strong performances by its child actors, but it's weakened by a bland, uneven screenplay that lacks palpable thrills, suspense and internal logic.

An underwhelming sci-fi adventure with nifty special effects and strong performances by its child actors, but it's weakened by a bland, uneven screenplay that lacks palpable thrills, suspense and internal logic.
Despite the weaknesses in the story it is pretty compelling and it has good characters worth following. The special effects are good and the story upholds a fairly good moral standard too.

Super 8 is a hugely entertaining sci-fi thriller, thanks to a strong script, impressive special effects, pacey direction and terrific performances from its likeable young cast.

If Abrams can't sustain the magic, at least he's created some in the first place. And with its nostalgic period setting, stunning special effects and charming performances from the young leads, Super 8 is the best movie Spielberg never made.

Marred by some of the same problems as Harlin's version -- namely, weak supporting characters, unintentionally funny dialogue and poorly executed special effects.

The flick is still plagued by occasional tedious patches, bad special effects and silly dialogue (it seems no one caught those problems on either director's watch).
Inventive children's yarn with good special effects.
The didacticism is, for the most part, gracefully meshed with the storytelling, and the special effects never take over the show.
There are some decent special effects, but overall it's about what you'd expect from a movie inspired by a line of toys.

With Masters of the Universe -- the latest numbskull entertainment from the creators of Castle Greyskull -- He-Man makes the transition from animation to live action. Taking a live actor along for the ride might have helped.
The main problem with this thing (besides the direction and the writing and, oh what the heck, the special effects, the acting, and the score). . .
Miserable storytelling covered with bad special effects.
Miserable storytelling covered with bad special effects.

Cloud Atlas ... is most likely to suffer by its own technological hand, as today's CGI effects become dated relics, and with a finale that doesn't so much reward audiences as it does offer them relief that their trial of patience is over.
Ethnic mice + fascist cats in groundbreaking animation.
For all its state-of-the-art animation techniques, Spielberg's production remains resolutely conservative: visually it's virtually indistinguishable from Walt at his wimpiest.
There's nothing particularly special about An American Tail, save for Bluth's slick animation.
The story is moving, and the animation includes some powerful images, although some of the early scenes depicting the suffering of the mice in Russia may be too frightening for younger viewers.
The overall quality of the animation -- baroquely executed if rather conventionally conceived -- makes it worth a look
I love the music, the animation is beautiful throughout.
For animation fans, revisiting An American Tail is a worthy exercise, but it is also a somewhat perplexing one.
Through the use of quirky art work, animation, a barrage of facts and figures, + an incredibly dry wit, Spurlock shines a light on America's attitudes to weight gain.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Sword and Sandal', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Historical fiction', 'Epic', 'Action/Adventure', 'Period piece', 'Fantasy', 'War film', 'Historical Epic', 'Action']
review_content: The action sequences are handled well enough but the CGI isn't up to snuff in a tale that barely merits the retelling.

It's a tedious experience in almost every way: The acting is numbingly one-note, the CGI work is unconvincing and often downright shoddy, and the action is poorly staged and framed so close you can never tell for sure who is lopping off whose head.
Who cares about the laws of physics when there's a chance for some really cool and stylish acrobatics? That's what athlete-turned actors and special effects are for!
Although Megaton's CGI fight scenes are as chopped up and incomprehensible as the current norm, he mostly avoids the Queasy-Cam and uses a stable camera while only the action moves. How about that.
I say rent the original. It tells exactly the same story, with a better cast and with special effects that are as good or better.
A delightful throwback to a time when really good horror movies were more interested in the mystery than the special effects.
Sparse special effects are pretty hokey, and the plot is nothing new, rehashing as it does scores of sci-fi-slash-horror films over many years.
Shot on location in Iceland and unfortunately hobbled by a bit of third act CGI that compromises the rather compelling ecological message.
There are cheesy special effects and even cheesier gags, and the schmaltz eventually piles on neck-deep.
The special effects in this pic make Land of the Lost look like Jurassic Park.
A catastrophe of bad acting, ludicrous science and conspicuously cheap special effects that can't even follow its own internal logic from one scene to the next.

The profoundly unconvincing CGI work only makes the sorry screenplay and lackluster performances look worse.

A mix of live action and animation, the $45 million movie is as cunning as Wile E. Coyote and chipper as a flock of cartoon bluebirds.
A spectacular blend of live-action and animation.
The first blend of animation and live-action that seemed so natural we felt the characters were real. There's many a lad still harbouring a crush on Jessica Rabbit.

It's still a superb film, a rare big budget blockbuster that concentrates on a clever story, crisp performances, and brilliant jokes while using its groundbreaking special effects only as window dressing rather than as the main event.
The real stars are the animators, under British animation director Richard Williams, who pull off a technically amazing feat of having humans and Toons seem to be interacting with one another.

An ingenious blend of hand-drawn animation and live action, spliced with humour that's by turns madcap, surreal and violent, Roger Rabbit demonstrates that it's possible to push the technical boundaries while still cooking up decent characters and plots.
The feats performed by director Robert Zemeckis and director of animation Richard Williams are pretty amazing.
Directed by 'Robert Zemeckis, Who Framed Roger Rabbit is a murder mystery turned on its (very long rabbit) ears, and a spirited tribute to the magic of animation and laughter.
For all the money spent on The Scorpion King (roughly $60 million), mostly for CGI effects ... the movie lacks bite.
For all the money spent on The Scorpion King (roughly $60 million), mostly for CGI effects ... the movie lacks bite.
The April 2002 instalment of the American War for Independence, complete with loads of CGI and bushels of violence, but not a drop of human blood.
The April 2002 instalment of the American War for Independence, complete with loads of CGI and bushels of violence, but not a drop of human blood.
For a science-fiction yarn, it skims over the science and pours on the fiction. And as a special effects extravaganza, its effects just aren't very special.
The pedestrian script isn't as compelling as the special effects.
Despite its predictability, The Core offers a healthy serving of suspense and special effects.
A fine and good-natured cast paired with cheesy special effects make "The Core" one of those bad movies that attain a level of accidental entertainment.
A disaster film with a high calibre cast, atrocious, inane dialogue, unspectacular special effects and questionable science. But fun nonetheless.
The Core is really nothing more than a special effects show, but for the most part, they aren't exactly special.
'Look out! It's diamonds big as Cape Cod!' No, they're large black blobs that the CGI guys clearly didn't have time to fill in with vector graphics. No need for alarm.

movie_name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child
review_content: Fifth edition of the hit Nightmare series is a poorly constructed special effects showcase.

movie_name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child
review_content: Despite an impressive bag of special effects tricks, old Fred is starting to resemble one of those dead horses that studio execs insist on flogging.
With Pocahontas, the artists at Disney once again prove that when it comes to animation, no can hold a candle to them.
Taking advantage of the studio's breathtakingly intricate animation, directors Mike Gabriel and Eric Goldberg have breathed vitality into this, the fifth 'new wave' Disney animated picture.
Disney deserves praise for raising the ante on its ambitions in animation. Next time, though, a little less civics lesson and a little more heart.
A refreshing combination of old-fashioned animation and contemporary technology, Pocahontas is less about story and more about the artistic possibilities of color, detail and striking reality.
Australia is sloppy, way too long, has awful dialogue, some bad special effects and very annoying characters.
With "The Bourne Ultimatum", not only is it fast-paced, riveting, but it is probably the best action films to date that doesn't involved so much special effects.
The story unfolds simply, with respect for its young viewers and their view of the world. The animation is bright and colorful, with lively characters that will surely delight children.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Crime Fiction', 'Gangster Film', 'Crime Drama', 'Family Drama', 'Action/Adventure', 'Period piece', 'Drama', 'Film adaptation', 'Coming of age']
review_content: In a summer overrun with movies dominated by CGI aliens and super heroes, it revigorates the mind to see a feature that concentrates on people, a project in which the script and characters hold sway.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Crime Fiction', 'Gangster Film', 'Crime Drama', 'Family Drama', 'Action/Adventure', 'Period piece', 'Drama', 'Film adaptation', 'Coming of age']
review_content: In a summer overrun with movies dominated by CGI aliens and super heroes, it revigorates the mind to see a feature that concentrates on people, a project in which the script and characters hold sway.
What this raucous 3D animated fun house lacks in originality (think bastard child of The Incredibles and Despicable Me) it makes up for in visual and vocal wit.
...will appeal to little kids with its bright colors and animation, older kids will like the story and most adults will be entertained.
There's nothing wrong with animation aimed at adults, but this may be the first kids' movie that throws fewer bones to its supposed intended viewers than to their parents.
What it lacks in inventiveness, 'Megamind' makes up in wit, intelligence, and customarily gorgeous animation.
Megamind is a blast. Take your kids. Stay with them. There are plenty of laughs for everyone. Bring your asprin for the 3D headache.
Complain loudly about the 3D tide - but see and enjoy Megamind for its own considerable charms.
What begins as one witty, unstoppable blast eventually succumbs to a flat story elevated by its consistently terrific animation.

In this refreshing twist on a familiar format, director Tom McGrath combines flawless 3-D animation with a bevy of comedic talent to craft an entertaining adventure with plenty of smart, grown-up laughs.
Every animation studio has its strong suit, but none embraces formula with the zest of DreamWorks.
I am usually against 3D films but Dreamworks has found the right formula with Megamind and How To Train Your Dragon. Will Ferrell is back!
... DreamWorks Animation is carving itself out a niche for consistent high-concept zaniness.
Hugely enjoyable, brilliantly funny comedy with superb animation, terrific vocal performances and a witty script that's packed with great gags and a multitude of fan-pleasing superhero references.
Eyeball-opening 3D digimation with eyelid-closing plot.
Despite the terrific voice cast and eye-catching animation, this seems disappointingly formulaic and fails to offer real laughs.

It's a sassy comedy with a lot of one-liners, some of which apparently came from improvisation between Ferrell and Fey, both in good vocal form. The quality of animation is outstanding, as you would expect.
It does have the odd cheeky nod for the grown-ups -- and it is presented in inglorious 3D -- but it's also got a screenplay overflowing with charm, intelligence, wit and a real spark.
What happened to Alvin, the rodent counterpart of Dennis the Menace? Was he declawed in the translation to CGI?
The movie manages to charm us, solely because of the inherent cuteness of its CGI stars, the famous singing chipmunks.
CGI critters are silly -- but very kid-friendly.
Alvin and the Chipmunks goes in one eye and out the other, featuring a CGI Alvin, Simon and Theodore interacting with a human-ish world.
Arguably the most irritating novelty act in record history gets a CGI-updating...and the result is pretty annoying itself.
With such a thin plot, the CGI here is adequate yet underwhelming, and the same can be said for the gags

Trite family values, mediocre CGI and a shallow anti-exploitation message do little to fill the fun-gap. Still, hard to deny the buck-toothed buggers their one moment of glory: an a cappella take on 'Funkytown'.
This new movie nicely updates the chipmunks into the realm of CGI animation and seamlessly places them in the real world.
This new movie nicely updates the chipmunks into the realm of CGI animation and seamlessly places them in the real world.
Is this the point when Disney animation lost its charm?
The animation is -- as with all the early Disney's -- jaw-droppingly good.
It is a picture that will charm the young and tickle adults, since the old fairy tale has been transferred to the screen by a Disney who kept his tongue in his cheek throughout the film's animation.
It's interesting and very telling that in the credits the actors are named last. It's Wiseman's way of acknowledging his films are not about performances but special effects.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: Fantastic? Maybe that's a bit of an exaggeration. Thrilling, engaging and totally adequate are more fitting adjectives to the latest superhero special effects bonanza.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: I had a few laughs, I enjoyed the elaborate special effects, the characters are entertaining and unpretentious, and I got out of the theater in about 90 minutes.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: What we get in the end is a lightweight reworking of superhero boilerplate -- megalomania, high-stakes confrontation and obscene spending on special effects.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is an enjoyable sequel that delivers humour, likeable characters, great special effects and plenty of comic book-style action, though fans hoping for a glimpse of Galactus should prepare for disappointment.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: Rise of the Silver Surfer is impressively mounted and bursting with playful, spectacular special effects.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: Sure, the CGI work is all pro and the Silver Surfer effect is a cool visual but the dumb lines and forced chemistry just don't cut it.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: Once again, the action feels pedestrian, the special effects simply aren't that special and the acting is nearly nonexistent.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: 'Silver Surfer' features more eye-popping special effects than the first Fantastic 4 movie, but the story comes across like a Saturday morning kiddie cartoon.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: Impressive not because of anything that's said, but for the realization that you're watching the screen be dominated by Jessica Alba and a piece of CGI without ever once experiencing the urge to gnaw through your own shoulder.

movie_name: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
review_content: With the wedding ruined and the future of the world at stake, it's showtime. Suddenly, Tim Story goes CGI crazy delivering scene after scene of edge-of-your-seat action that will make your eyeballs bleed.
The demonic 3D grindhouse picture isn't nearly as subversive as it thinks.
It's hard to care when the CGI is so obvious and Cage's character so clearly invincible.
Sharp 3D lensing and low-octane camp humor help rev up Drive Angry.
It's all so tongue-in-cheek... serious horror fans probably won't get it, but those who love the grindhouse will be all over this flick, 3D glasses and all.
Drive Angry 3D is a hoot, as long as you down-shift your brain into neutral and submit to the endless barrage of obscenities and gratuitous violence.
With solid 3D action, Fichtner's quirky performance, and the ability to not take itself seriously, Drive Angry proves quite watchable... although I can't bring myself to call it good.

Drive Angry 3D is for a very narrow movie-going niche audience. An audience that has nostalgia for hard-R 70′s exploitation flicks - or those too young to have seen those and yearn for a balls to the wall, take no prisoners B-movie.

While serious-minded critics are still trying to figure out what 3D can do to enhance the cinematic experience, director Patrick Lussier is having a blast with the as-of-now gratuitously revived technology.
Never one to be shy about taking on board an outlandish role that requires a new hairdo, Cage now relishes his Drive Angry leap into the crazy world of the 18-rated 3D action thriller.
Drive Angry 3D delivered even more than it promised. It fulfilled the lunacy it purported to offer and went further.
Performances, especially from William Fichtner and Amber Heard, are great and the 3D is pretty solid, but that's about all I can say for Drive Angry 3D in terms of positive aspects of the film.
Drive Angry 3D is a film that unashamedly nails its balls to the wall from the outset and, as far as guilty pleasures go, it's one hell of a ride.
...succeeds solely as a showcase for some admittedly jaw-dropping special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: Gives Columbus the chance to indulge himself with fascinatingly realistic special effects and riveting action sequences.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: The special effects here will have you reclining in your seat, admiring the spectacle. Unfortunately, the film's pedestrian pacing won't get you on the edge of it.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: Another successful wild ride, thanks to a very entertaining source, a keen and fairly faithful adaptation, and top-notch special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: The best blend of human activity with computer animation since 'Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: Not only are the special effects and narrative flow much improved, and Daniel Radcliffe more emotionally assertive this time around as Harry, but the film conjures the magic of author J.K. Rowling's books.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: The special effects and CGI, uneven in Sorcerer's Stone, are all spit-shine and shoe-polish in Chamber of Secrets. There isn't one hair out of place.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: The special effects and CGI, uneven in Sorcerer's Stone, are all spit-shine and shoe-polish in Chamber of Secrets. There isn't one hair out of place.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: Despite terrific special effects and funnier gags, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets finds a way to make J.K. Rowling's marvelous series into a deadly bore.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: There's not much I can recommend about this new installment. It's magical, & the special effects are certainly better this time around. What I miss is the story. Without the story, a fantasy is nothing more than strange creatures & some creative escape.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: The special effects enchant all -- no matter what your age.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
review_content: Chamber Of Secrets is funnier and more exciting than the first Harry Potter movie, and adorned with some of the most stunning special effects ever.
It's all style, climax and special effects. The rules change with every scene.

What we have here is a film that tries too hard. All of which is a shame really because the special effects are very well done, especially a vertigo inducing shot of an enormous space station at the beginning.
This unwieldy amalgam of science fiction and horror, directed by Paul Anderson, douses almost every scene with glitzy special effects in a futile attempt to cover up a paucity of thought.
Despite a few nifty special effects, this sci-fi horror film, in which grisly things happen to a space crew after its members board an abandoned ship, is a boring and blood-soaked mess.
There is little to recommend in this nonsensical, repulsively gory outer-space yarn other than moody interiors and a few adequate special effects.

The sets are indeed terrific and the special effects quite remarkable, as the chill of the uncertain future is mixed with a steamy gothic past. But, to paraphrase Winston Churchill, never have so many done so much to such little purpose.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
review_content: Depth of character, cunning humor and hair-raising chills come shining through the visual blitzkrieg of special effects....Far and away the best Harry Potter movie yet.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
review_content: There are some pretty nifty scenes and special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
review_content: A marvel of special effects seamlessly hitched to a powerful coming-of-age story.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
review_content: The third Harry Potter movie is the first one that actually looks and feels like a movie, rather than a staged reading with special effects.

movie_name: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
review_content: A menagerie of menacing and morphing computer-generated special effects make the movie worthwhile.
The photography and editing are accomplished, and the filmmaker frequently resorts to animation and other tricks to make his subject more palatable.
Not only is the film an eye-opening, perfectly put together documentary, it also engages the audiences with spectacular animations and a gripping narrative.

Helped immeasurably by the voices of Phil Harris, Eva Gabor, Sterling Holloway, Scatman Crothers and others, + some outstanding animation, songs, sentiment, some excellent dialog and even a touch of psychedelia.
An enjoyable mix of fine animation, catchy songs, and outstanding voice characterizations.
The animation is masterful and the overall design is appealing.
An amazing cinematic feat of makeup and special effects.
Why didn't the producers save all the money they spent on these great sets and brilliant special effects for a script worthy of them?
The first 15 minutes of this picture had me rolling in the aisles. The careful animation of the frog-king rocks. Not so funny during middle chunk. Great pop-music choices!
sometimes slightly heavy-handed messages... are balanced out by stunningly beautiful, meticulously detailed animation and a healthy dose of the insouciant humor 'Shrek' fans have come to expect.
The imaginative leaps in the animation are dragged down by the deadweight storytelling.
The first 15 minutes of this picture had me rolling in the aisles. The careful animation of the frog-king rocks. Not so funny during middle chunk. Great pop-music choices!
sometimes slightly heavy-handed messages... are balanced out by stunningly beautiful, meticulously detailed animation and a healthy dose of the insouciant humor 'Shrek' fans have come to expect.
The imaginative leaps in the animation are dragged down by the deadweight storytelling.
...odd that the animation should grow ever more textured and subtle while the humor grows ever less so...
...odd that the animation should grow ever more textured and subtle while the humor grows ever less so...
Great animation and good jokes.
Great animation and good jokes.
Uninspired threequel, though the animation is better than ever and there's a steady stream of chuckles, even if it does lack the magic of the previous films.
Uninspired threequel, though the animation is better than ever and there's a steady stream of chuckles, even if it does lack the magic of the previous films.

In the end, Shrek the Third, like so many Hollywood animation movies today, neither trusts itself nor cares to create any new magic. If it were a child in a classroom, it would be the back-row smart arse, rather than the poetic dreamer.

In the end, Shrek the Third, like so many Hollywood animation movies today, neither trusts itself nor cares to create any new magic. If it were a child in a classroom, it would be the back-row smart arse, rather than the poetic dreamer.

The first two movies had heart, charm, wit, originality, parfait and, most unusually for an animation, characters you could properly care about. This, though, has very little of any of the above, and it breaks my heart.

Features clunky, outdated CGI, a script so flat it's practically Holland and rubbish character design.
Features clunky, outdated CGI, a script so flat it's practically Holland and rubbish character design.
The CGI is beyond ropey (we're talking 1995 computer game levels); the script reads as though it was half-heartedly written during a hangover and every single main character is obnoxious.

Director Terence Young never quite solves the pacing problems posed by filming underwater, but John Stears's Oscar-winning special effects more than compensate.
Lovely animation and an abundance of comic relief should keep the tots engaged but this is not exactly The Lion King.
The animation is vibrant and the voice cast impressive... So it's a great shame that the animators and actors are let down by the meandering plot and trite dialogue.

The land of Oz is as fantastical, magical, colourful and enchantingly beautiful as CGI can make it

The wizard may not be wonderful enough to warrant a film of his own but the sidekicks and special effects make Disney's much-anticipated prequel a solidly entertaining, if not quite magical, family adventure.
Sam Raimi's colourful Oz prequel is nicely acted, visually spectacular and makes terrific use of 3D ...
An oppressive, bloated bore, the latest argument that CGI kills the imaginations of talented filmmakers.
"Oz" suffers from a gluttonous use of CGI and an incredibly weak story, but the biggest problem is James Franco as the titular character.
The film's CGI'd talking monkey is more alive than Franco. And it totally looks fake.
If it's spectacle you're after, you'll want to see Oz The Great and Powerful, a visual delight for which 3D makes perfect sense.
The best 3D movie, period. So far, anyway.

...director Sam Raimi...gives Baum's world a 3D/CGI/origin story spin that has more life and imagination than it's seen in over 70 years, even if the modern technology used to achieve it is often less than satisfying.

CGI baboons, the wizard's CGI monkey companion and colorful but soulless CGI landscapes of Oz are no substitute for the absence of even one great song and characters who develop the greatest of friendships as they fight the greatest battle of their lives.
Imagine my surprise at feeling some of the same thrills while watching this 3D prequel as I do every time I see 'The Wizard of Oz,' one of filmdom's masterpieces.
The film has lots of computer-generated special effects but no magic.
An imaginative mix of live-action and CGI that pays homage to the iconic images and timeless sense of wonder in the classic The Wizard of Oz without being too deferential.
The film blends together impressive special effects, a story about teamwork and the redemption of a man who finally strives for greatness into an effective family film.

Disney spent more than $200 million on this special effects film, and while the pacing and the visuals captivate, it's really James Franco's performance as the Wizard and an abundance of allusions to the 1939 classic that make it fun.
trips the light fantastic ambling through idioms from classic westerns while piling on the CGI of nasty creatures from another world driving the action

Terrific special effects!
Special effects have slowly been replacing stunt work in the Bond films, which has resulted in the loss of that extra dimension of danger.
A decidedly mixed bag of campy humor, wild-eyed fantasy and high-tech special effects.
A triumph of special effects over story (and the effects are now totally dated).
A numbing combination of sloppy writing, vulgar art direction, high school acting, and bungled special effects.
The special ends on a joyous note, and the lo-fi charms of its non-professional voice cast and simple-yet-expressive animation retain a pleasantly transportive power.
The animation is simple and sweet and lovely and endearing.

review_content: To carry the film for as long as it does with virtually no dialogue... that's to me the magic of animation.
While all this action may captivate young children, the animation is not spectacular enough to dazzle adults.
Basically, The Transformers: The Movie features rancid animation techniques, a story that will bore anyone over age 10, and a few overpaid celebrities essaying the lead voices.
Did Transformers actually launch the celebrity-voiced animation craze 20 years ago? That may be the film's biggest legacy.
Far from a cheap spin-off, The Transformers: The Movie is an entertaining feature-length animation that's both handsome and well realised.

Just when you thought the movies had been given over to special effects departments and the high-tech fantasies that sustain them, along comes The Fugitive -- a good, old-fashioned drama with unsettling shivers of suspense.
This anemic vampire tale boasts an interesting premise but suffers from lethargic pacing and an overdose of splatter special effects.
There's very little personal dirt in Sarah Palin: You Betcha! that wouldn't be upstaged by Joe McGinniss' recent Palin tell-all.

review_content: Kingdom of Heaven makes Alexander look like Ben-Hur... It's just CNN with CGI.
