review_content: It's amazing how the homemade special effects of this comparatively low-budget picture are still effective today -- even more so than many computerized effects.
Stuart Gordon's "Dolls" features some neat special effects and makeup, but they're not nearly enough to make up for the film's lack of material and sluggish pacing.
The silly concept (killer dolls!) manages to work because [the special effects] are so solid.
Multiplicity is more concerned with its special effects of multiple characters than any satisfying conclusion to its provocative premise.

movie_name: Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life
review_content: When we're not offered dime-store CGI or cardboard Temple Settings, we're attacked by action sequences that waver between "stutter-step silly" and "slo-mo stupid".

movie_name: Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life
review_content: Croft's quest is to find Pandora's Box before a mad scientist can get there first, open it, and unleash a series of second-rate special effects upon an unsuspecting world.

movie_name: Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life
review_content: Uninvolving and formulaic, spiced up in the stretch with a couple of CGI (and looking every bit like it) Tree Hulk-type monsters.

movie_name: Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life
review_content: The preposterous plot line does give De Bont an excuse to send Jolie flying in a handful of heartstopping stunt sequences. But she's her own special effect, as protean, mercurial, and dangerous as any piece of wirework or CGI.
Chilling special effects highlight a rather gory production.
Light on its feet and continually amusing, this free-spirited show-biz version of Greek mythology ranks with the best of modern Disney animation.
Hercules has all the fun mythological stuff to hook the kids, cute baby Pegasus, familar myths, fun songs, and Disney's prerequisite BEAUTIFUL animation.
The animation is kinetic and witty; computer effects are integrated to good effect without overwhelming the hand-drawn figures.
One of the best of the modern Disney animation efforts to date.
If you're okay with standard slasher flicks and you enjoy grandiose special effects, then House of Wax might be worth a trip to the theater for you. If not, wait for the DVD.
Serra brings the universal fear of disfigurement an old fashioned treatment, with natural pacing and a lack of abrasive special effects (until the terrific looking climax.)
House of Wax aims low and hits the mark. It has all the gory bloodshed you could ask for and all the right special effects.
A deceptively slight film, imbuing into its simplistic animation style and sly humor an astounding level of philosophy

movie_name: Return of the Living Dead Part II
review_content: The movie's high points are its makeup and special effects. The movie's low points are almost everything else.

movie_name: Return of the Living Dead Part II
review_content: The movie's high points are its makeup and special effects. The movie's low points are almost everything else.
it's hard to justify the remake, er, "revisit," beyond the improvements in make-up special effects and computer-generated imagery
Yes, the apes are very, very cool. The costumes, the sets, the makeup, the stunts, the music and the special effects: cool, cool, cool.

genres: ['Science Fiction', 'Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Stop motion', 'Costume drama', 'Action/Adventure', 'Fantasy', 'Mythological Fantasy', 'Family Film']
review_content: Special effects, fantasy fans will love it...and that is the target audience.

genres: ['Science Fiction', 'Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Stop motion', 'Costume drama', 'Action/Adventure', 'Fantasy', 'Mythological Fantasy', 'Family Film']
review_content: Swords and silly special effects in this enjoyable adventure.

genres: ['Science Fiction', 'Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Stop motion', 'Costume drama', 'Action/Adventure', 'Fantasy', 'Mythological Fantasy', 'Family Film']
review_content: [Its] main raison d'etre is some first-rate "Dynamation" special effects from Ray Harryhausen.
A promising first act crumbles under the weight of the second and third act's reliance on CGI and horror movie silliness.

The location photography is impressive, the scenery is awesome, the re-enactment of the air crash is terrifying and uses convincing special effects. We care about the characters while we watch the movie. But at the end it all seems elusive.
The slapstick is funnier for the nifty CGI, and the script gets in some sly digs at racist cops and multitasking soccer moms.
Another gimmicky one-joke comedy from the Wayans brothers that may not use as much makeup as White Chicks but lots more special effects and is even more dreadful.
It took a century of innovation in the field of cinematic special effects, but finally the head of Marlon Wayans could be successfully grafted onto the body of a baby.
Chicken Run is the most delightful piece of feature length animation to debut this summer.
What makes Chicken Run so successful is the filmmakers' obvious love for clay animation.
Gets by on the elements of fun and frivolity common to all the Aardman animations.
What really makes it special, more than the impressive animation, is the endearing characters and involving plot.
The animation is executed with astonishing skill, considering every frame records minute changes made by hand in models of rubber and plasticene modeling clay. They even managed a spit-take!
Fab animation from Wallace and Gromit creator.
This wonderful visual treat is done in stop-action clay animation, a form which is both substantial and magical. It's as if the clay figures kids make have managed to take on a life of their own.

The finale and a scene set inside the pie-making machinery prove that the Rube Goldberg formula is infallible, and the puns -- another staple of crossover animation -- range from "fowl" to "poultry in motion."
The first feature film from England's Aardman Animation, and the first truly terrific film to be released by DreamWorks.
Run to Chicken Run. This clay-animation comedy is the most entertaining animal story since Babe.
The sly, sardonic flight of fancy known as Chicken Run is a delightful epic of fowl deeds, quests for freedom and poultry heroics from the off-kilter English cartoon house, Aardman Animation.
Chicken Run contains some gorgeous, destined-to-be-classic set pieces, and this is where the Aardman production team flex their animation muscles.

genres: ['Romantic comedy', 'Crime Fiction', 'Indie', 'Heist', 'Film adaptation', 'Action/Adventure', 'Thriller', 'Comedy', 'Crime Thriller', 'Drama', 'Romantic drama', 'Romance Film', 'Action']
review_content: From the first shot to the last, Mr. Clooney is in complete command of the screen in the assured manner of the biggest stars in the past, and he doesn't need a ton of special effects and digital enhancement to generate excitement.
The script by Thomas Moffett slickly satirizes the movie industry's fascination with vampires and special effects without being especially compelling or original.

Think of it as the anti-Pearl Harbor. Relying more on story and character than special effects, this moving adaptation of Louis de Bernires novel achieves everything that Michael Bay's empty spectacle could not.
Although filled with bright colors, the film's animation has a cheap two-dimensional look to it as if they did the same slapdash job expected for a kid's television show.
Although filled with bright colors, the film's animation has a cheap two-dimensional look to it as if they did the same slapdash job expected for a kid's television show.
The cast is good, but it's nothing they haven't done a million times; the same goes for the animation, music, and general production design.
The cast is good, but it's nothing they haven't done a million times; the same goes for the animation, music, and general production design.
Intermittently snappy and featuring slicker animation than its TV incarnation, this popular children's cartoon may satisfy its youngest fans, but it'll be a big snoozefest for the rest of the family.
Intermittently snappy and featuring slicker animation than its TV incarnation, this popular children's cartoon may satisfy its youngest fans, but it'll be a big snoozefest for the rest of the family.
The result is several steps above the clunky, offputting animation of the series' early episodes.
The result is several steps above the clunky, offputting animation of the series' early episodes.
Classic Disney animation, classic story. A wonderful film for childrena and adults as well.
True Disney classic animation with great score.
The vintage animation is brilliant, and Disney has done a wonderful job with the transfer to DVD.
A wonderful blend of timeless romance, wholesome adventure, and breathtaking animation.
I just love hand drawn animation, it really brings to life all the characters in a very expressive way. The imperfections doing it by hand give everything a rougher edge but more heart.

While Lady and the Tramp may not rank as one of Disney's greatest animated works, it still makes for a charming experience thanks to its memorable and entertaining characters, gorgeous animation, and a beautiful score.
Shot on ugly digital video with Troma-grade special effects, campy humor and frighteningly bad acting, Zombie Strippers should provide many laughs for stoners watching it on video.
The action can be bloody, but is mostly routine. Ultimately, the film's most eye-catching special effects are reserved for bikini waxes and implants.

A much-needed respite from summer's big, noisy, special effects adventures, Hairspray is old-fashioned fun, wearing its retro like a badge of honor; the "coolest" thing about this uplifting musical is how mainstream it is.
Adam Shankman's Hairspray is a great big sloppy kiss of entertainment for audiences weary of explosions, CGI effects and sequels, sequels, sequels.

movie_name: Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure
review_content: This time, Disney created a "world." From the magical opening sequence that shows fairies helping animals prepare for winter and ripening corn, you know you're in for some stunning animation.

movie_name: Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure
review_content: Featuring beautiful nature animation and possessing a passable plot, if nothing else, Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure opens up a world beyond the Never Land everyone seemingly knows.

Marvel's new deal with Madhouse Studio bodes well for the future. The Japanese animation giant...has the chops to produce spectacular, dynamic, colorful, stylish animation (or, rather, anime) that's an evolutionary leap for Marvel on the small screen.

Marvel Animation at its very best, and is sure to entertain fans of both characters. The voice cast are exceptional through-out, the animation is top-notch, and there's just the right mix of action and humour to keep you entertained from start to finish.

genres: ['Silent film', 'Sword and Sandal', 'Adventure', 'World cinema', 'Costume Adventure', 'Epic', 'Black-and-white', 'Drama', 'War film', 'Historical Epic', 'Indie']
review_content: The exotic drama, suspense, and daring stunts on display in Pastrone's film of "12,000 shots" is every bit, if not more effective, than that of modern filmmakers whose use of green-screen CGI is frequently used more as a crutch than a meaningful storyte
There is a lot to become enchanted with - even if it looks as though most every character were a product of computer animation.
Begins with a bubble-gum bang, but leaves viewers gobstopped in the detached, thinly plotted half-pleasures of watching CGI mechanisms implode in a rainbow of fruit flavors.
Burton's modernized take ... benefits from improved special effects and the unhinged brilliance of his repeat collaborator, Johnny Depp.
Beautiful art direction, creative special effects and great performances make the movie just as sweet as any Wonka treat.
Corny beyond belief, but a welcome relief from a summer filled with CGI, 3-D and sequels. The two leads are enormously charming.
Larry Crowne will probably appeal mostly to baby boomers desperately searching for something other than big blow-up movies (Transformers 4) or yet another 3D disaster.
A blast of fresh, anarchic, mischievous fun to a mainstream movie culture beholden to gimmicky special effects, belated sequels and diluted family films.
A kick-ass action flick that feels more like 3D than most of the recent films actually employing the technology yet it also manages to comment on the violent action it creates and celebrates.

America could probably use a good laugh just about now, what with all the problems plaguing this society. But the exploitation of children even if they are actors and the special effects are occasionally awesome, is way beyond just not cool.
Kick-Ass actually qualifies as a character-driven movie and not a film dominated by its special effects.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: Interminable, with more plot lines than pirates, this is a mix of theatrical bravura, magical special effects and tedium... a journey on a tempestuous ocean with mountainous highs and fathomless lows. I was confused, enthralled, dazzled and bored.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: The finale ends up going on so long that by the time the 'important' events occur at the end I couldn't find it within myself to care anymore. I had been swashed, buckled and CGIed into apathy.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: It drifts along in its own sort of doldrums, two minutes of not terribly exciting story followed by ten minutes of special effects, some of which are dandy, most of which demonstrate the textbook definition of overkill.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: [Depp's] shtick is funny, but the players are all upstaged by the astonishing special effects, superior to those of earlier installments in creating a wondrous and menacing world.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: It's beautifully shot, with lots of colorful characters, many astonishing special effects (though some approach a numbing quality), and much humor. The secret to enjoying the Pirate trilogy is to view them as operatic comedies.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: Ho, ho, ho and my bum is very sore! I kept humming that to myself following nearly three hours of visual abuse. Overwhelmed by its bloated script, confusing plot and never-ending battle sequences, I admittedly was nevertheless awed by the special effects

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: Incredible special effects and astonishing set pieces fill the screen in 'At World's End,' but it's Captain Jack Sparrow who steals the show again.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: Here, death has little sadness and no permanence; it's as if the characters, being part of a mostly CGI world, are destined to exist forever in digital limbo, like deleted e-mails.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: Buoyed by luck, comedy and state-of-the-art special effects, it has not only survived the journey intact, it's also washed down its decks, ready for a whole new cycle of movies to begin.

movie_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
review_content: A few laughs, some fantastic CGI and a great cameo from Keith Richards aside, this is turgid and tiresome.
The result features special effects that will make your jaw drop.
It's an epic experience, three solid hours of high-flying entertainment and special effects wizardry
The popcorn movie of the millennium, setting a new standard for special effects wizardry.
CGI spectacle that smacks of self-importance and showbiz hustle P.T. Barnum style.
Although far too long at three hours (the original was only 100 minutes), with far too many special effects-driven fight scenes involving horrible monsters, it's still a smashing love story.
With a superb cast, terrific special effects and stunning action sequences, this is one of the best films of the year - thrilling, awe-inspiring and genuinely moving.
I watched the last hour of the film with a knot in my stomach, the result of a combination of the love story and the brilliant special effects.
An average race-car movie with a few cool scenes and blatant special effects.
Special effects lap the field, while the plot is in the pits.
[A] tournee of mediocre special effects.

Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types - few prettier than its lead, Joseph Gordon-Levitt - and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon.

Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types - few prettier than its lead, Joseph Gordon-Levitt - and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon.
Shocker is more over-the-top goofy than scary, but it's a good deal of fun and the special effects hold up pretty well after a quarter century.
Shocker is more over-the-top goofy than scary, but it's a good deal of fun and the special effects hold up pretty well after a quarter century.
A spooky, funny, weirdly heartwarming fable that -- were it not for the glimpses of non-CGIed geriatric bits -- might actually be suitable for kids of all ages.
A spooky, funny, weirdly heartwarming fable that -- were it not for the glimpses of non-CGIed geriatric bits -- might actually be suitable for kids of all ages.

[There is] very obvious, and somewhat jarring use of some very underwhelming CGI effects in a number of key scenes. However, the tremendous performances and the film's unique tone more than make up for this technical misjudgement.

[There is] very obvious, and somewhat jarring use of some very underwhelming CGI effects in a number of key scenes. However, the tremendous performances and the film's unique tone more than make up for this technical misjudgement.
There are some intriguing special effects in the movie, but a limp script and unconvincing performances don't help. Worse of all, it isn't scary. I only jumped once during the entire film.
Shoddy 3D and flashy editing distract from the admittedly great dancing, but little else offers a particular reason to watch it.
Shoddy 3D and flashy editing distract from the admittedly great dancing, but little else offers a particular reason to watch it.
An eye-popping and vibrant coming together of super-sexy salsa and spectacular, stylish street dance makes for a fun and entertaining bit of 3D cinema.
An eye-popping and vibrant coming together of super-sexy salsa and spectacular, stylish street dance makes for a fun and entertaining bit of 3D cinema.
The 3D is moderately imaginative...
The 3D is moderately imaginative...
This is a zanily inventive piece of work, with delightful special effects, which set the style for a long series of live-action Disney films.

With a surprisingly mature screenplay by animation writer Dan Fogelman (Tangled, Cars) and top flight direction from Glenn Ficarra and John Requa Crazy, Stupid, Love cuts to the heart of the matters of the heart.
Del Toro has traded the subtlety for special effects that aren't.
Portions of the movie capture the spirit of the clever source material, yet it eventually becomes another generic action flick bogged down by the weight of its CGI effects.
OK, the CGI stuff is getting better. But it still looks like CGI stuff.
Worth seeing because of its groundbreaking animation style.
I found it to be beyond words; a combination of film, groundbreaking computer animation, and a difficult and profane script that produces a sublime interpretation of existence.
Animation serves the dialogue in this movie as it served the music in "Fantasia..." The monologues themselves are like jazz improvisations, wildly playful...
Even without the animation, Waking Life remains a living, breathing entity, full of real thought, conversation and ideas.
An indisputable landmark of animation from its first scene onward.
Digital video + digital animation + ancient questions = A visionary, stunning examination of the big picture.
The novelty of the much-lauded animation style wears off about halfway through, with the end result a film that's more interminable than anything else.
A true independent film that uses animation techniques to their utmost.

Form and content fit perfectly: even if the highbrow babbling gets a bit much, the hypnotic animation means that there is always something to watch, like characters suddenly dissolving into smoke or spectacles expanding.
A brilliant film that provokes thought, idea, and conversations within the audience through its surreal animation and incredibly profound conversations.
Waking Life looks stunning... Animation, thesis, questions!
It is a dream -or rather a series of waking dreams that slip into one another like those Russian dolls. It also takes computer animation in a new direction.

Linklater and his animation collaborators have clearly had a lot of fun, morphing characters into their own conversational subjects, destabilizing their environs, throwing the material world into question.
This is a sexual drama not for the squeamish or for the easily offended, but for those looking for adult entertainment and not the usual summer CGI whiz-bang this one fits the bill and then some.
Bakshi's version, using animation and live-action tracings, is uniformly excellent, sticking closely to the original text and visually echoing many of Tolkien's own drawings.
... in retrospect it feels like an elegant, appropriately sized adaptation - with some beautiful animation work.

What most people remember is the mix of the live-action tracing within the traditional animation and just how effectively creepy it managed to be, but for the time this did a pretty good job of adapting the dense novels.

Full of epic effects and breathtaking battles the film reflects Bakshi's ingenuity, with photographic imagery and light show effects expanding the limits of the palette used in previous animation features.
The best part of Titan A.E. is the animation.
This engaging, technically magnificent piece of computer-age animation delivers the mix of punch and pathos that modern moviegoers have come to expect from action yarns.
An ill-conceived and overambitious animation blowout.
The result is an impressive array of themes, stories and sequences that use both computer imagery and, often, hand-painted animation to an effect that's better than many live-action films.
Rich blending of traditional cel animation and computer generated artwork.
The film is an industrial design marvel full of impressionistic, painterly backdrops and cool CGI effects.
... flat characters, flat animation, a bland rock soundtrack ... Titan A.E. might as well be Titanic A.E. (as in, the ship that sunk, not the movie that scored.)
It's too great of a fluid, exciting animation epic to be forgotten or lambasted.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Family Film', 'Action', 'Sword and sorcery films']
review_content: ...it serves a purpose in reminding us that even today's animation can't compare to the brilliance that hand-drawn animation offers its audience.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Family Film', 'Action', 'Sword and sorcery films']
review_content: Middle road Disney animation, unmemorable.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Family Film', 'Action', 'Sword and sorcery films']
review_content: A glorious return to the days at Disney when animation was full and detail was everything.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Costume drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Family Film', 'Action', 'Sword and sorcery films']
review_content: Technically brilliant though short on narrative, "The Black Cauldron" is a painless, old-fashioned way to take out the kids, and a triumph for the animation department at the Disney studio, where it has been in development for almost a dozen years.

Essentially postmodern and deconstructivist, what could have been a mishmash of animation and live action, fantasy and realism, CG effects and handdrawn segments, under Lima's inspired helm becomes a unified entertainment suitable for kids and adults.

This charmer of a film runs a little long and is heavy on the CGI dragon. The real special effect is Adams, who sings the Alan Menken and Stephen Schwartz songs with brio, complementing her vivacious performance.

Enchantment only goes so far in Disney's Enchanted, a sometimes clever, other times grating mix of live action and animation that plays tricks with levels of movie reality as the world of fairy-tale animation invades contemporary New York.
Enchanted is worth seeing for Adams, and children will adore the slapstick performers, including a prominently featured CGI chipmunk.
Once upon a time, the Disney studios showed off a clever way to blend animation and live action.

Kicking off as a traditional 2-D animation before transforming into live animation when we hit the Big Apple, the film's title doesn't quite describe the film's likely effect on adults, but girls aged six-12 are sure to love it.

Disney's self-mocking combination of animation and live-action is not without its charm, but so slim is the satire that the result comes dangerously close to resembling a cheap imitation by a moderately talented wannabe.
As close as you can get to a family-friendly, live-action satire of Disney animation, made all the better since Disney itself made the film.
Disney's Enchantedis a fun homage to all the Walt Disney Animation Studios classics.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: This doesn't depend on the special effects even though the special effects are first rate.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: It's briskly directed for much of the way, though with no great individuality, by Andrew Adamson, a film-maker previously noted for his work in animation.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: There's no hideous beast or CGI landscape rendered here that can compare with what lurks in the mind of even the dullest, least imaginative child.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: For Narnia fans and for those who dig the mixture of animation and human beings.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: The film works on just about every level. Narnia has grandeur, imagination, mostly believable special effects, a war-of-the-world battle, heart and teary-eyed heartbreak.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: It's a ripping yarn, full of narrow escapes, talking animals, marvelous sights and magical happenings that lead up to an epic battle between good and evil. The extensive CGI work is well used and the children are exceptionally well cast.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: Adamson knows how to give talking creatures heart, the special effects work but aren't overwhelming, and the basis is a classic for a reason. Try it on for size; you won't be disappointed.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: The film fares better when it gives itself over to pageantry and action -- which come in copious quantities -- and to the pantheon of gorgeously rendered, hyper-realistic CGI beasties.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: I know it's bizarre to say CGI beavers have more life to them than the humans who interact with the computerized creations, but it's true. The whole movie feels flat.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: The special effects are phenomenal, looking amazingly authentic.

movie_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review_content: All the CGI in the world can't distract you from the idea that it's all a little bit silly, a children's story that works better on the page.
Part live action, part animation, Bedtime Stories is relentlessly silly, kept buoyant by Sandler's zany cheer.
I've seen better special effects in Troma releases...
Stop-action animation, blue-screen work, matte backgrounds, and a rollicking fantasy story make this one for the ages.
In spite of its obvious flaws (inferior animations), Jack the Giant Killer is movie magic that's rife with rich fantasy and winsome playfulness.
If I've ever seen a movie that better produced riveting drama on a low budget with no exaggeration of character or CGI effects, I can't remember it.

The kids are cute, Allen is affable and charming, and Chevy Chase shows flashes of his old brilliance, but mostly it's a little kid movie with bad CGI effects and nary a moment of real jeopardy or emotion.
The story is muddled and slovenly, and the execution is unbelievably cheap-looking, with special effects that are miles beyond cheesy.
Heist is the kind of caper movie that was made before special effects replaced wit, construction and intelligence.
Great special effects, iconic hairdos, and a lame script, make The Blob a forgettable remake of the classic alien feature. [Full review in Spanish].
Above average special effects together with Lorre's creepy performance make The Beast with Five Fingers well worth watching.
A taut, genuinely scary psychodrama which gave vent to Lorre's weird mannerisms and produced some marvelous special effects created by director Florey.

movie_name: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep
review_content: The story is clever and heartwarming enough for the film to work on some level for adults and children (although it skews younger). Plus, the CGI work is competently done.

movie_name: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep
review_content: A tepid, CGI-enhanced family movie that should delight 6-year-olds with a lap full of popcorn.

movie_name: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep
review_content: ...a bit too calculated and reliant on special effects.

movie_name: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep
review_content: Despite the drama, there is nothing in The Water Horse that will frighten young children. The cast is good, and the special effects are even better.

movie_name: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep
review_content: Pleasingly evokes the days when Roddy McDowall frolicked with Flicka and Lassie, [but] it must be said that a CGI pet is not quite so easy to love as a flesh-and-blood performer, animal or human.

Some impressive Terminator-type special effects, various plot holes, kung-fu derring-do and action as well as some wooden acting by the muscles from Brussels make for Saturday matinee entertainment, but little else.

movie_name: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel
review_content: A frenetic but undeniably funny follow-up that offers twice the number of singing-and-dancing rodents in another seamless blend of CGI and live-action elements.

movie_name: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel
review_content: Perfunctorily cute, the only selling points of this squeakuel are its seamless mix of CGI and live-action, and that it goes by in a flash.

movie_name: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel
review_content: Blending CGI and live action, this "squeakquel" to the witless 2007 kids' film proves just how dangerous such technology is when placed in the wrong hands.
Unlike Woo's Face/Off or Broken Arrow, there are no stunts, special effects or kinetic moments in Paycheck that really blow you away.
This could have been a terrific movie. Unfortunately, Paramount and Director John Woo (who was responsible for the lamentable Windtalkers), ruined it by prolific special effects.
It's nice to know that there's a director out there who still knows how to use marquee stars and to blow stuff up real good, without resorting to CGI fakery.
It's shallow and kind of dumb, and the animation is routine, and the story isn't much, and the stakes are a lot higher these days in the featurelength animation game.

genres: ['War film', 'Period piece', 'Drama', 'Film adaptation', 'Romantic drama', 'Romance Film', 'Chinese Movies']
review_content: The Painted Veil recalls an earlier era of film direction, when movies moved rather than manipulated and craft superseded special effects.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: Studiously harmless, Disney's long-in-development film rendition pasteurizes the book's renegade verve with typical means: special effects and gooey romance.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: Featherlight spoof loaded with grand CGI visuals...amusing, gentle satire... [but] never attains a real zaniness

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: For the most part, this big-screen re-telling of Adams' inaugural book plays it safe, offers some solid performances and nice special effects, and provides some chuckles along the way.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: The major problem is that the subtle, quirky humor of Douglas Adams' novel doesn't translate well to a big, expensive, special effects-laden production.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: A lively blend of epic silliness and very droll British humor, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is that rare sci-fi comedy where the special effects complement, rather than overwhelm, the story and characters.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: Like the novel, the film version is quirky and original using Adams' ideas and characters with top-notch special effects to create an organic science fiction adventure.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: Despite the perfect cast, fantastic book animations, & superb production design, this latest adaptation of Douglas Adams' novel is just not very enjoyable.

movie_name: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review_content: For all its huge sets, high-tech glitz, and CGI effects, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy fails to capture the deadpan drollness of the Adams novels
There may be a few questions from the kids on the ride home, but this is an otherwise harmless and mostly forgettable entry into the bulging 3-D animation marketplace.

It's always hard not to think of classic Disney as the standard for a film like this. Using that yardstick, Crest Animation/Lionsgate's Alpha and Omega is far from an emotionally rich, fulfilling experience.
[W]oefully misbegotten... [T]he CGI animation -- pointlessly rendered in 3D -- is plastic and cheap.
[W]oefully misbegotten... [T]he CGI animation -- pointlessly rendered in 3D -- is plastic and cheap.
[W]oefully misbegotten... [T]he CGI animation -- pointlessly rendered in 3D -- is plastic and cheap.
A routine of shenanigans and sleepy dramatics, realized through blocky, rigid animation that doesn't feel very special standing in the shadows of industry giants.
Alpha and Omega, an unambitious 3-D animation about a couple of young wolves in love, isn't so much howlingly bad as it is howlingly boring.
The 3D allows for bold, deep shots that swoop over cliffs and waterfalls, but can't distract from the wolves' clotted fur, which looks a decade behind the textures Pixar created for Toy Story 3.
Alpha and Omega is one of those rarities in the modern era of Hollywood animation: bad.
Lionsgate's entree into 3-D animation ignores the characters' animalistic appeal and, instead, rewrites wolf culture in a lifeless romp.
Its all pretty bland, with uninvolving characters, unfunny comedic relief and weak computer graphics (made even worse by unnecessary 3D effects).
Though predictable and routine, Alpha and Omega will be enjoyed by youngsters under eight regardless of whether they see the 3D version.
Aimed squarely at the very young, this cute animation still feels far too rushed to spend any significant time on.
The animation, coupled with a jarring use of 3D, makes for a visually unspectacular film that feels very similar to others that have come before it.

review_content: All those CGI snakes can be quite shudder-inducing. But there is also something cheerfully ridiculous in the way the film switches to rubber snakes for hand-to-hand combat.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Natural horror films', 'Horror', 'Action/Adventure', 'Horror Comedy', 'Comedy', 'Action Thrillers', 'Action', 'Airplanes and airports']
review_content: All those CGI snakes can be quite shudder-inducing. But there is also something cheerfully ridiculous in the way the film switches to rubber snakes for hand-to-hand combat.
The animation is poor.
These people are responsible for lots of those bad, bland '80s Disney features like The Fox and the Hound. Now, their generic, cheap, animation style has murdered another beautiful E.B. White novel.
The animation is unimaginative and uninspiring.
May hold the attention of the very young, but despite marginal attempts at Disney-style cleverness, the simplistic writing, flat animation and sloppy direction will leave adults bored.
Passable animation for the younger members of the family, but the movie never finds its own voice.
An innocuous family feature that's too little/too late in the fast-moving world of feature animation.
Features charmless songs, junky animation, hambone voice talent.
Christmas is definitely cancelled in this over-acted, over-here movie. Presumably the tinsel was CGI'd in to complement the season of its release.
Christmas is definitely cancelled in this over-acted, over-here movie. Presumably the tinsel was CGI'd in to complement the season of its release.

The film boasts some of the more revolting special effects ever conceived. There isn't really any acting to speak of, although Jigsaw and Loony Bin Jim get to chew people and scenery; the dialogue is pretty much what you'd expect.

The film boasts some of the more revolting special effects ever conceived. There isn't really any acting to speak of, although Jigsaw and Loony Bin Jim get to chew people and scenery; the dialogue is pretty much what you'd expect.
A movie doesn't need CGI dragons to be exciting. But it does need real characters and conflict -- it needs to be a real story. Here, that story always is just beyond our grasp.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: Although there is an admirable attempt to stay true to the higher aspirations of the high-class source material, the new effort is undermined by the need to fashion itself as a crowd-pleasing blockbuster, loaded with exciting special effects.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: The whole thing finally crashes and burns in an orgy of noisy and uninspired special effects that stands as a lunkheaded rebuke to the restraint displayed by the original film

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: If all you ask from a movie is cool CGI effects, The Day the Earth Stood Still is for you. Look for any more than that and you'll be sorely disappointed.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: It's ickily atmospheric, tactile, old-school special effects movie-making.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: a pale shadow of the classic, piling on special effects and grafting original elements onto a dopey and sub-par thriller that bogs down in its own self-righteousness

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: If you want to see all the cool special effects in this remake, watch the trailer. If you want the extreme environmentalist agenda that goes with them, buy a ticket.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: It's a decent enough stab at being what the old movie was to its time, following the same basic plot, full of respectful references to its model, updated with a gallery of fairly imaginative special effects.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: This was supposed to be the winter season's big special effects picture. So why does it make Al Gore's PowerPoint presentation look like Spider-Man 2 by comparison?

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: This Day has a big special effects budget but has little sense and even less soul.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: Not only is it 20th Century Fox's first 'carbon neutral' production but its Earth-destroying special effects have less impact than a fart in a thunderstorm.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: Add to that some unimpressive CGI and a bizarrely abrupt ending and you have the day your buttocks went to sleep, your brain melted and your will to live evaporated.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: The flick is a very plain Jane version of a disaster film with mediocre special effects, no character depth whatsoever and is just a complete waste of money.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: Impossible, we can handle, but the eschewal of all internal logic starts to feel like an insult, the cinematography is dismal, and the cocktail of lazy CGI and po-faced, sub-Al-Gore environment lecture leaves you light-headed with tedium.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: The movie's last quarter gets clogged up with special effects, including what looks like a gigantic swarm of locusts that eat through whole juggernauts. Whether this eco-warning will have a morally improving effect on audiences is uncertain.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: The special effects in 1951 were hokey fun. Here, in the first half of the movie anyway, they are hokey but they aren't fun.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: What, in 1951, was a scary Cold War-era warning about the misuse of atomic energy has now become a vague and infantile pro-green special-effects showcase (even the CGI is unimaginative and looks like a swirly, soft-focus nightmare) with one entire suspens

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: The special effects are spectacular enough here, and there are a few droll lines, but the net result is almost instantly forgettable.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: It's all just two hours of pure monotony with CGI not even up to par in what should be considered a remake featuring state of the art effects.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: The Day the Earth Stood Still is a great study in all the things that can go wrong with a movie. The plot's all haywire and the casting's rotten and the dialogue's stupid and the camerawork's ugly and the CGI sucks.

movie_name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
review_content: If you look past the fairly cool special effects you're going to see a film at war with itself.

Unnecessary remake that replicates rather than originates, neither truly scary nor even mildly disturbing. Surprisingly poor special effects and the neutering of a big plot point negate any potential.
The performances are faultless, but clumsy CGI removes the delicateness that had us so in love with the original.
The all-CGI, cartoon-inspired game F/X are undeniably cool in three dimensions...but Rodriguez aims lamentably low in almost every other aspect of the movie
The all-CGI, cartoon-inspired game F/X are undeniably cool in three dimensions...but Rodriguez aims lamentably low in almost every other aspect of the movie
The special effects may be in 3-D, but the story is flat, and there is very little of the quirky humor of the first two.
The special effects may be in 3-D, but the story is flat, and there is very little of the quirky humor of the first two.
Spy Kids 3D races from set piece to set piece, but the combination of speed, clutter and clatter make the movie a little too forgettable.
Spy Kids 3D races from set piece to set piece, but the combination of speed, clutter and clatter make the movie a little too forgettable.
With 3D glasses on or off, it doesn't measure up to its predecessors.
With 3D glasses on or off, it doesn't measure up to its predecessors.
Where Rodriguez falls short... is in relying on the computer generated special effects to make up for problems in the script.
Where Rodriguez falls short... is in relying on the computer generated special effects to make up for problems in the script.
The 3D stuff works really well.
The 3D stuff works really well.
Terminator 3 moves at not-quite-breakneck speed, and the shape-shifting, metal-melting special effects aren't exactly spectacular.
Director Jonathan Mostow doesn't try to incorporate the high-wire special effects now in vogue, and T3's impressive gravity-bound set pieces seem refreshingly rooted in reality.
Jonathan Mostow stays true to the '80s popcorn actioner opus here both in storytelling and style, yet his updated special effects add a subtly modern element to the pic.
Ice Age is a fun new addition to the growing list of CG Animation films.
Ice Age is a welcome addition to the growing list of quality CGI-based animated features, even if it is not as long on knee-slappers as it should be.
The animation in 'Ice Age' is definitely cool, but in terms of story and characterization it's rather mushy, a prehistoric retread of 'Monsters, Inc.'
"Ice Age" yields to the temptation of conventional animation standards, but it does so with a clean style and authentic humor.
... crackles with slick, eye-catching animation and off-the-wall humor.
The animation is clean, efficient and clever -- certainly on a par with other recent computer-generated sagas
What sets Ice Age apart from similar family fare are a witty script and the all-digital animation that is so fresh to the eyes.
This is one of 20th Century Fox's first ventures into the world of animation, in partnership with Blue Sky Productions, and they've hit a home run.
... there's enough cool fun here to warm the hearts of animation enthusiasts of all ages.
It has taken 20th Century Fox a while to land on the animation scoreboard. Now it has. Ice Age is the coolest animation in town.
The creative animation work may not look as fully 'rendered' as Pixar's industry standard, but it uses lighting effects and innovative backgrounds to an equally impressive degree.
No evolutionary leap forward in the world of computer-generated animation, just another palatable, familiar children's diversion in shiny new form.
A clever and beautifully designed computer-animated feature that often measures up to the standards set by last year's two CGI blockbusters, Shrek and Monsters, Inc.
Yet another marvelously funny digital-animation feature.
Far from the over-polished sheen of recent CGI features... the [animation's] basic line-structures are stylistically reminiscent of cave drawings.
Far from the over-polished sheen of recent CGI features... the [animation's] basic line-structures are stylistically reminiscent of cave drawings.
A thoroughly mediocre entry in the world of computer animation that does nothing to push the envelope technologically or creatively.

review_content: This fun flick has tongue firmly planted in cheek, a trove of Elton John songs, an excellent voice cast, and nifty animation.

review_content: Tolerable but forgettable, Gnomeo & Juliet is a halfway clever idea executed with minimal effort and ingenuity. It continuously reaches for the lowest-hanging fruit -- in its jokes, in its animation style and its brazen, narrow appeal to tykes.

review_content: A kitsch and colourful animation whose one-joke concept has its fun moments but only works in a limited, one-dimensional way

review_content: A fun, disposable animation designed for short attention spans and lovers of garden ornaments.

genres: ['Adventure', "Children's/Family", 'Family Drama', 'Animation', 'Fantasy', 'Comedy', 'Drama', 'Adventure Comedy', 'Romance Film', 'Fantasy Comedy', 'Family Film', "Children's Fantasy"]
review_content: What would have saved it, if it had been saved, is the design and animation.
Solid storytelling, clever humor and incredible craftsmanship and animation skills puts ParaNorman a few steps above the normal kid-friendly fare.
[While ParaNorman] takes stop-motion animation to an entirely new level...on [the] surface [it's] a beautiful piece of work that's [actually] rotten at its core.
Unlike the polished universe of Pixar's "Brave" or countless other recent CGI efforts, "ParaNorman" maintains a delicate, handcrafted look that underscores its ideas.
The story may be thin, but the project, a feat of stop-motion animation, is made with generous care by the same impressive LAIKA studio artists who conjured up the gorgeous Coraline.
[VIDEO ESSAY] Fans of Aardman's handcrafted style of animation will find much to enjoy in this wonderfully stylized stop-motion comedy-horror-thriller...
... if you're any kind of animation or graphic art fiend or even mild enthusiast, the visuals are sure to stagger you. ParaNorman is an extrasensory delight for sure.
Beautifully rendered in 3-D stop-motion animation, the film combines ghoulishness and hilarity in a way that suggests Evil Dead 2 for the Nickelodeon set.
Animation is stunning...voice cast wouldn't need to be stellar if the writing were better. Instead, film climaxes with a lengthy sermon on the psychology of bullying. Whee!
"ParaNorman" has plenty of rambunctious thrills to give the kiddies goosebumps, while older connoisseurs of stop-motion animation will appreciate the Laika studio's inventive visuals.
It's not just Pixar that kicks ass in animation. There's magic in ParaNorman, a small miracle in stop-motion 3D from the wizards at Laika.
It's not just Pixar that kicks ass in animation. There's magic in ParaNorman, a small miracle in stop-motion 3D from the wizards at Laika.
ParaNorman, blessed with otherworldly animation, can't escape the demons of story.

Laika, the animation outfit behind 2009's marvelous stop-motion adaptation of Neil Gaiman's Coraline, scores another one for the dark side with this endearingly sweet and spooky-ookie ode to the living, the dead, and the in-between.
This swell stop-motion animation operates on a wavelength similar to that of Laika's debut feature, Coraline, with assured character comedy counterbalanced by a solemn sense of macabre wonder.
Any misgivings about the plot are eased by the handcrafted visuals. Catch it in 3D if you can.
Though the narrative is slender, the stop-motion animation is impressive and the concept of a small-town hero original.

[T]he animation is divine. Highly detailed, purposefully designed, imaginatively executed, it is more vivid that reality itself, delighting in imperfections and sight-gags while also attaining heights of pure terror and from the most unexpected sources
Gleefully twisted fairytale about a small medium with large problems. If only the script were as deeply textured as the beautiful stop-motion animation.
I admire its character and production design, which achieve the kind of look that sets stop-motion animation apart from CGI.
I admire its character and production design, which achieve the kind of look that sets stop-motion animation apart from CGI.
From a visual standpoint, ParaNorman has set the bar for stop-action animation.
Employs stop-motion animation to provide hand-crafted appeal to the clever and surprisingly scary story of a Massachusetts town whose witch-hunting past catches up with it on its 300th anniversary.
A colorfully macabre stop-motion animation comedy that embraces the sociopolitical allegories of George A. Romero's zombie pictures and reworks them into a feature-length episode of "Scooby-Doo."
Visually vibrant animation and terrific use of 3-D.

If it stumbles a bit, it's during an ending where the movie over-explains its themes, but that ending is also surprisingly emotional - and the multimedia animation technique and subtle use of 3D are pretty remarkable.

If it stumbles a bit, it's during an ending where the movie over-explains its themes, but that ending is also surprisingly emotional - and the multimedia animation technique and subtle use of 3D are pretty remarkable.
ParaNorman is created with stop-motion animation rather than computer animation, and so it has a much warmer more organic feel... It's almost as if the textures and tone make the story spookier.
Good stop action animation but the storyline and characters all have a been there done that feel.
Incredible animation unfortunately paired with a preachy, recycled story and unpleasant character design.
Gorgeous animation and inspired set design help patch over a lacklustre script.
Unequivocally original with breathtaking stop-motion animation (stay to the end of the credits for a very brief demo of Norman's creation), "ParaNorman" is easily the best animated film of the year.
It's rather gross in parts and a bit scary, but kids aged about eight and up will love its dark, ingenious humour and impressive stop-motion animation.
A few decent gags are not enough to keep this 3D stop-motion film alive.
ParaNorman confirms that Laika is an animation studio worth watching out for. As with Coraline, they've crafted a film that truly respects its young audience
The inner horror fan is accessed via the child inside in this quirky stop-motion animation treat
Bristling with energy, here's a delectable 3D film that's inventive, funny, devilishly ghoulish, loaded with splendid effects and a heartfelt story at its core
Funny, frightening, exciting and extremely thoughtful about the nature of the conflict at the core of the film, ParaNorman is a standout feature animation.

ParaNorman demonstrates - as did films such as Coraline, The Corpse Bride, Wallace & Gromit and The Nightmare Before Christmas - that stop-motion animation has a texture and warmth that can't (yet!) be replicated by computer.
The only thing animated about it is the animation, which is so spectacular that you begrudge the script for not being equally inspired.
My favorite part about this movie aside from the animation is this message... [that] even if we feel justified in our anger if we allow hate to take over our lives then then we become what we hate.
The special effects are cheap and not at all impressive. For a series that relies heavily on sword fighting, it too is surprisingly second-rate.
As slimy and as grotesque as some of its special effects become, The Fly is a far superior horror film to the top-grossing film in America of late, Aliens.
Daddy Day Camp, a comedy for no ages, has an amazing amount of CGI -- Cuba Gooding Incompetence.
Despite the impressive special effects, even without the silly reprehensible political slant, this movie is so ridiculous with so many laughable scenes, that it could almost pass as a comedy.
All the action scenes, as with many modern Hollywood blockbusters, are seemingly edited with a Cuisinart, or that the copious CGI would barely pass muster in one of those Asylum DTV quickies.
The special effects are scary-hairy enough to satisfy the midsummer "I wish to go to the moon" impulse.
Visually arresting and emotionally rich, Mars Needs Moms is another animated triumph from a rejuvenated Disney Animation.
The skill level of this motion capture animation is getting better all the time. So Mars is accomplished at every level. But the three most important things in movies are story, story, story.
Instead of breathing life into cartoonist Berkeley Breathed's cheeky kids morality tale, the movie - with all its 3-D motion capture animation flash - flatlines.
The 3D IMAX visuals do impress, but the subtext - that if you behave well, the Martians will zap your mother's brain - is a little out of this world.
The animation, special effects and sound effects are top drawer. This family-friendly entertainment package comes with a lasting side benefit.
The animation, special effects and sound effects are top drawer. This family-friendly entertainment package comes with a lasting side benefit.

The biggest problem, however, remains the animation style itself. Zemeckis' motion capture technology just isn't fit to depict human movement. Worse, it can't showcase a human eyeball to save its life.

The motion-capture animation technique has come a long way since Robert Zemeckis (a producer on this film) introduced it in The Polar Express, but what's missing too often is the human element, especially during all the rambunctious activity on Mars.
A flat, uninvolving, and annoying sci-fi and 3D animated film
If Breathed's style could have been applied to the animation, this offbeat story would have a better chance at success. Instead, we're left with a kids' movie that leaves audiences cold.
Don't be put off by the title. Wells harnesses 3D mo-cap wizardry for a children's adventure that balances storytelling and sci-fi.
Motion-capture animation takes a giant step backwards with this unappealing outer-space adventure.

What really sells this fabulous, kid-friendly 3D adventure to anybody over eight (no offense, kids) is its astonishing visuals, which uses motion-capture technology to a degree that surpasses what we saw in Avatar.
Here is a movie that seems at war with the notion that animation can inspire or invigorate.
What comes to mind immediately with a mere mention of this Greek myth are Ray Harryhausen's special effects, especially those swashbuckling skeletons
It mostly comes alive through the imaginative special effects by Ray Harryhausen, the maven of stop-motion animation.
It mostly comes alive through the imaginative special effects by Ray Harryhausen, the maven of stop-motion animation.
A stop-motion animation masterwork.
One of Ray Harryhausen's finest moments, the remarkable special effects are still pretty impressive even in today's CG-shaped world.
The Gone With The Wind of stop-frame animation.
Great old-fashioned fun, spiced with imaginative Ray Harryhausen's special effects.
Though a worthy addition to the series of fantasy films adorned with Harryhausen's animation, the characters and creatures don't make the list of his most iconic concoctions.
More interested in special effects than in dramatic flare.

Director Tarsem Singh Dhandwar slathers things with eyecatching visuals - luscious CGI effects, vertiginous camera angles, a treacly amber glow - and keeps every frame watchable, however foolish and stilted the utterances emerging from people's mouths.
On pause, I imagine Immortals would mesmerize and intrigue, but in motion, accompanied by a thunderous score, muddy 3D and bland theatrics, it fizzles out.
A mash-up of ancient myth and CGI that often looks very impressive, but doesn't make a lot of sense.
It's a murky, addled affair, the CGI effects are third-rate and the violence makes it unsuitable for young audiences.
Immortals looks gorgeous. The CGI is rendered with imaginative care and a real sense of wonder and danger in underscoring the action. It is the real star
Overall, Immortals is a pretty decent popcorn flick. Will it stand the test of time? Probably not, but the provocative special effects will leave a lasting impression on the audience.
Immortals is an affectionate homage to those mythical epics from old school Hollywood, but perhaps the film's producers should have included earplugs alongside the 3D glasses.

movie_name: Mickey, Donald, Goofy: The Three Musketeers
review_content: The animation has a Saturday morning look to it, with an overall brighter, yellower cast, and the film feels like a cartoon short that's been put on the rack and stretched until it qualified as a "full-length feature."

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Film adaptation', 'Coming of age', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Drama', 'Fantasy', 'Family Film', 'Action']
review_content: We've reached the point in fantasy films at which the CGI-creatures are a lot more interesting and believable than the humans.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Film adaptation', 'Coming of age', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Drama', 'Fantasy', 'Family Film', 'Action']
review_content: Any hint of narrative complexity or character development is wiped out by the film's slavishly straightforward storyline, and its special effects that might be state-of-the-art but never show anything we haven't seen before.

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Film adaptation', 'Coming of age', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Drama', 'Fantasy', 'Family Film', 'Action']
review_content: The special effects are the tail wagging the dragon in this sword-and-sorcery fantasy, which may put a spell on kids, despite a dull hero and skimpy storyline.
An old-fashioned Disney fairy tale gussied up in 3D for the holidays.
I actually believe in Walt Disney Animation once again.
With "Tangled," a delightfully fresh spin on "Rapunzel," the entertainment powerhouse delivers its first classic-caliber computer animation outside the Pixar family.

Clebrates the studio's classic storytelling history while serving up an exciting modern adventure, full of heart and humor, beautiful computer-generated animation, lots of twists -- and yes, a princess.
The team at Disney has taken a deep breath and tried to be all things to all animation-loving people. There are some hiccups along the way, but by the end there is success.
While it is a diverting Disney animation -- the studio's 50th -- it lacks the emotional undercurrents of a movie from the studio's Pixar division.
Tangled is fine, and it may lure some people into the theater with its digital look and 3D gimmick, but it's probably not going to be anyone's favorite.
Disney's spirited re-telling of Rapunzel in 3D animation turns out to be a dazzler.
Disney's spirited re-telling of Rapunzel in 3D animation turns out to be a dazzler.
The animation is so superb, it's a joy to behold.
It may be CGI, but it looks hand drawn. It's absolutely gorgeous...and who knew Zachary Levi could sing?

The heart of Disney animation lies in song and spectacle, and while none of the musical compositions here are quite at the level of "The Little Mermaid" or "Beauty and the Beast," they are good enough...
Tangled is a serviceable kids' picture and marks a milestone in the history of Disney animation, but it's splitting hairs to characterize it beyond that.

This is a testament to the power of 3D when mastered--and not rushed. "Tangled" is animation at its best and it's this season's biggest surprise--it treats its audience with intelligence while giving them a jolt of fun.

Utterly charming, visually sumptuous and often witty, this new 3D musical rendition of the old fairy tale...will delight youngsters and teens while holding the attention of the more hair-challenged among audiences.

Not quite Disney at its very best, but a fast-moving, witty, heartfelt animated CG 'toon that sees the Mouse House leaping into the new era of animation with some style.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Too many frantic CGI critters ruin this spy movie with pets.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Like all unimaginative filmmakers that don't know what to do with 3D technology, director Brad Peyton subordinates all action in the movie to the tech he's working with.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: This chatty 3D spy spoof is as hard-pressed for laughs as Marmaduke, once you get past the novelty of "Hey, the dogs and cats are TALKING."

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Having real animals speak through the hideous magic of CGI is inherently creepy, and it's depressing to hear kitty and doggy thoughts come out so banal and jokey.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Other than a few reasonably inspired in-jokes that will fly way over the head of the target audience and will only appeal to adults who will have no desire to attend, this 3D CGI-heavy epic is an unmitigated disaster.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Other than a few reasonably inspired in-jokes that will fly way over the head of the target audience and will only appeal to adults who will have no desire to attend, this 3D CGI-heavy epic is an unmitigated disaster.

review_content: We should be getting Hollywood level special effects, not rejects from Build-A-Bear.

review_content: The 3D conversion is awful. The special effects are awful. The acting is awful. The movie is awful. Stay away from this movie.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Starts well but quickly wears out its welcome, thanks to increasingly unfunny gags, irritating characters, occasionally dodgy 3D effects and constant, tedious dialogue.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: The script suggests it was developed on the hoof; the CGI is low grade stuff; and the human performances are loathsome.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Not even an exceedingly cute beagle in a roll-neck pullover and spectacles can rescue this charmless live-action and 3D animated kids' caper.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: The story is dumb, the jokes are dumber, the special effects are shoddy and the 3-D is headache-inducing.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: Passes the way a pet lover hopes euthanasia goes for their beloved feline or canine-a blur of motion, moments drifting by in a numbing fog, then the blissful end, free of pain at last. A forgettable, clunky CGI tinkertoy.

movie_name: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
review_content: This uncalled-for sequel to the mediocre 2001 talking-pets affair Cats & Dogs is all needless noise and second-rate CGI gunk, and never, ever funny in any sense of the word.
