The strong special effects can't overcome the story's sour focus on pain and hopelessness.
The strong special effects can't overcome the story's sour focus on pain and hopelessness.
Sanctum has on its + side stunning settings and excellent use of the 3D process [but] that dimensionality doesn't go very far with the characters.
Sanctum has on its + side stunning settings and excellent use of the 3D process [but] that dimensionality doesn't go very far with the characters.
The film's raison d'tre is a series of shock effects involving creepy kids, dogs with upside-down heads and a CGI-powered geriatric variant on Linda Blair's crab walk.
Despite some gruesome special effects, the telling of this story is so prosaic and predictable that genuine thrills are in very short supply.
People have been screaming for years about the imminent death of 2-D animation, and Brother Bear is the kind of movie that may make you want to hurry the process along.
While the hand-drawn animation is visually appealing, the story is completely predictable and Phil Collins's music lacks the impact of his Oscar-winning Tarzan tunes.
definitely a second tier animation effort by Disney Studios
The painted backgrounds are pretty, but the animation is sketchy and flat-looking; the characters cast no shadows and don't seem to weigh anything.
Good story, solid animation, catchy songs, a beautiful score by Mark Mancina and big laughs to not bore the adults. Sounds like the perfect definition of a family film to me.
The good news is that this is mostly good old-fashioned hand-drawn Disney animation. The bad news is that it relies too much on old-fashioned formula, hackneyed plot and cookie-cutter characters.
Disney's latest attempt to hold the line for traditional animation is a formulaic enough effort, but it still comes through with the moralistic goods when it needs to.
Proves hand-drawn animation can dazzle as much the computerized kind.
The hand-drawn animation is alternately static and inconsistent, and the story may be too downbeat for younger kids, who are most assuredly the target audience.
Brother Bear should please most kids, but its formulaic story and predictable animation prove Disney needs to try a little harder next time.
Disney animation's attempts to recover from the collapse of its renaissance have come to an end not with a bang, or even a growl, but with a whimper.
"Brother Bear" eschews computer animation in favor of the traditional, hand-painted, 2-D variety. As such, it's almost a museum piece.
Another watchable, old-fashioned, uninspired Disney animation.
While the animation itself (from the same team as Mulan) is charming and at times beautiful, the script is banal and uninspired.
After Shrek the Third's flatulence jokes, the return of that Seinfeldian wit brings animation up a level.
Instead of gently skewering the conventions of contemporary animation, it simply follows them to a T
Does Bee survive the hype? Not quite, but it is semi-charming and reasonably clever in that facile Dreamworks Animation kind of way.
This well-meaning but comically limp offering from DreamWorks Animation inspires boredom more than anything.
A welcome diversion from DreamWorks Animation's increasingly trying Shrek series.
It has enough buzzing wit and eye-popping animation to win over the kids -- and probably more than a few parents, too.
The depth of talent in the cast and gag writing shines through, but it's only just enough to take your mind off of the flat animation.
Amusing comedy with likeable characters, colourful animation and several great gags, though the script isn't as focussed as it should have been.
Sadly the animation fails to bee-dazzle - often looking a bit flat. Overall, it has to be a Bee-+.
The animation is fine, the plot accessible enough for youngsters and it clocks in at a snappy hour and a half.
Bright, sunny and almost instantly forgettable, even Jerry Seinfeld can't stop Bee Movie from boldly going where far too many CGI animations have gone before.
Bright, sunny and almost instantly forgettable, even Jerry Seinfeld can't stop Bee Movie from boldly going where far too many CGI animations have gone before.
Anyone smarter than a fifth grader will get a kick out the ingenuity, stellar animation, and relentless higher level humor (what, no poop jokes?) of a film that will reward multiple viewings.

Dreamworks Animation is not Pixar, no matter how hard it tries. Dreamworks' animated films lack the sort of effortless charm, animated grace and satirical wit that Pixar seems to generate instinctively.

Commendably faithful, stylishly directed reboot of the 2000AD character with impressive special effects, striking production design work, a suitably gritty, stripped down script and a trio of terrific performances from Urban, Thirlby and Headey.
Heralds new and exciting times for cinema splatter, primarily down to its canny realisation that slow motion and 3D are a match made in horror heaven.
The script isn't much, but the action is inventively bloody and the 3D visuals are dazzling.

Dredd 3D isn't revelatory, nor does it redefine any of the genres it splashes among as it goes its merry, bloody way, but as goofy-gory self-satire high-tech low-morality future-cop epics go, it's charmingly diabolical.
Despite admirable intentions and assured performances, Dredd 3D suffers from a structurally flawed script that fails to engage and repetitive fight sequences that fail to excite.
Dredd 3D constantly impresses on a visual level, with a gritty style more akin to cult hits like District 9 or 28 Days Later than to standard Hollywood comic-book blockbusters.
Dredd 3D is remarkably unoriginal and visually rancid. The lack of social satire coupled with the brutal violence makes for a hollow experience.

I loved this film because it reminded me of watching an old school action film with the special effects of today. Movies like RoboCop or The Crow, I like that tone a lot and so to me I had a ball with it.
Even if the similarity to The Raid: Redemption is pure coincidence, Dredd 3D suffers greatly by comparison, as it fails to muster even half of the thrills of its predecessor.
While not for the squeamish, Dredd 3D is an effectively gritty B movie accentuated by stylish visuals and irreverent humor.
A killer take on the character, full of great 3D and slow-motion effects that enhance a stellar performance from Karl Urban.
Dredd 3D is, at its core, a bloody spectacle and little more.
It feels like a throwback to a time when action movies were simply movies with action in them, and didn't have to rely on relentless CGI setpieces to hold viewers' attention.
A dystopian sci-fi action thriller shot in 3D and 50 shades of gray, this adaptation of the bleakly satirical comic-book series plays its story of future justice at gunpoint straight and dull.
Overall, Dredd 3D isn't as rich or as deep as The Dark Knight Rises or The Avengers, but it's good, solid comic book fun.
Whether by design or otherwise, Dredd seems better-suited to a 2D home video presentation than to the 3D silver screen.
The stunningly violent Dredd 3D strips out pretense of satire, a crucial element of the British comic.
"Dredd" is non-stop action + excellent 3D effects peppering an above-average story.
A tremendously entertaining film that consistently pushes the limits of 3D creativity in a way to seem like the images are leaping straight from the comic book panels.
Clocking in at a pacey 96 minutes, Dredd 3D will satisfy fans as well as serve as a great introduction for newcomers to the character.
The Judge has spoken. A directed verdict for First Degree Action-Packed Thrills!! Dredd 3D is a "dreddfully" delicious delight.

movie_name: Now You See Him, Now You Don't
review_content: Benefiting from some fine special effects, this fast-moving comedy ought to please any family.
Featuring a truly awful screenplay and more overbaked CGI detritus than you can shake a claw at, IG2 is a loud and garish and oppressively off-putting experience.
The once revolutionary special effects not merely pales in comparison to many of today's offerings, but looks downright silly.

A landmark of 1960s sci-fi remains compelling entertainment despite dated special effects, deliberate pacing, and indifferent dialogue and acting, thanks in part to the genuine wonder it brings to its premise.
Call this one big-time guilty pleasure. Special effects are dynamite, concept just as good.
Their voyage through the body's bloodstream past assorted organs was created by inventive special effects that make this one of the more visually interesting science fiction films of its era.
The lavish production, boasting some brilliant special effects and superior creative efforts, is an entertaining, enlightening excursion through inner space -- the body of a man.
This special effects extravaganza from 1966 has proved surprisingly enduring, despite a technical quality crude by contemporary standards; perhaps it's the screwball poetry of the plot.
Fascinating still, but suffers from lack of more sophisticated special effects. Still...imagine Raquel Welch moving around inside.

Hotel Transylvania is a chief offender when it comes to the issues plaguing mainstream animation today and in a number of ways is a significant step back for Sony Pictures Animation after their hit Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs.
The animation by Sony Pictures Animation is not particularly dazzling, even in 3-D, and with Adam Sandler heavily involved, you know there will be the requisite bathroom humor
Even the animation is ugly.
Hotel Transylvania doesn't raise the bar for animation or comedy but it's fun, and nice for once to have a different reason to say "boo" after an Adam Sandler flick.
An animation that never drags itself out of mediocrity despite the best efforts of gifted animator Tartakovsky.
High-value animation gets wrapped around a slapdash story more suited to a Saturday morning cartoon in Adam Sandler's Hotel Transylvania, sunk by broad, lazy storytelling.
Monstrously entertaining, frequently hilarious comedy with lively, fast-paced animation, appealing characters, a witty script and terrific voice performances from a superb comic cast.
There is not much originality here, particularly not a daughter wanting to escape an overprotective parent - Brave and Tangled did this much better - and the 3D hardly registers.
Sandler's second venture into animation is almost as unfunny as his horrendous Eight Crazy Nights, ten years ago.
It's no classic but the animation is lively and inventive with some terrifically realised ghouls and the story moves fast.

Eye-catching animation and non-stop jokes make this animated monster movie a lot more fun than we expect. It's packed with gross-out gags that will keep kids laughing, + clever character-based humour for the grown-ups.

Hotel Transylvania might be useful as a primer to introduce young film fans to some classic screen creatures, but it falls way behind the standard set by wittier animations from the likes of Pixar and Aardman.

This is a perfectly O.K. animated film. The animation is really quite good. The characters are interesting, but the predictable story isn't very compelling. It is a slightly above average animated feature.
Much of this slick and sprightly CGI feature is sufficiently funny to amuse even the most resolutely unreligious parents who escort their little ones to megaplex screenings.

The animation is competent, and some of the gags are quite funny, but Jonah ... never shakes the oppressive, morally superior good-for-you quality that almost automatically accompanies didactic entertainment.
The movie is a blast of educational energy, as bouncy animation and catchy songs escort you through the entire 85 minutes.
Bouncy animation and catchy songs keep the film from tasting too much like spinach.
Its three leads are all engaging and well written, and its attention to detail enhances the film in ways big budget special effects can't.
The acting and special effects are particularly painful to watch.
Outstanding special effects.
If you're tired of car chases, disasters and special effects, check out a movie about some oddball people. You'll be glad you did.
If you're tired of car chases, disasters and special effects, check out a movie about some oddball people. You'll be glad you did.

Richard Linklater wraps novelist Philip K. Dick's paranoid, prescient nightmare of addiction and identity lost down the rabbit hole in the same rotoscoped animation that helped produce the blissed-out groove of his Waking Life.

[A] real-world movie that's essentially been spray-painted, Scanner has turned its back on one of animation's greatest strengths: the playful elasticity that allows characters to stretch and soar in impossible ways.

Richard Linklater wraps novelist Philip K. Dick's paranoid, prescient nightmare of addiction and identity lost down the rabbit hole in the same rotoscoped animation that helped produce the blissed-out groove of his Waking Life.

[A] real-world movie that's essentially been spray-painted, Scanner has turned its back on one of animation's greatest strengths: the playful elasticity that allows characters to stretch and soar in impossible ways.
As Dick's vision matches up with our times, so does director Richard Linklater's animation technique match the story's material. A Scanner Darkly is a joyful wedding of medium and message.
As Dick's vision matches up with our times, so does director Richard Linklater's animation technique match the story's material. A Scanner Darkly is a joyful wedding of medium and message.
Linklater's willingness to experiment ... is laudable. But I'm not sure he's reinventing animation here, or even adequately serving that older-than-children animation audience.
Linklater's willingness to experiment ... is laudable. But I'm not sure he's reinventing animation here, or even adequately serving that older-than-children animation audience.
You've never seen anything like this before due to some simply astonishing animation.
You've never seen anything like this before due to some simply astonishing animation.
Possibly one of the strangest movies ever made, "A Scanner Darkly" is worth seeing if only for the eye-bending animation.
Possibly one of the strangest movies ever made, "A Scanner Darkly" is worth seeing if only for the eye-bending animation.
A futuristic morality tale using rotoscope animation to enhance the trip effect, offering visual stimulation but not enough satisfying engagement.
A futuristic morality tale using rotoscope animation to enhance the trip effect, offering visual stimulation but not enough satisfying engagement.
I think this is a film that would have been more effective as live action, rather than animation.
I think this is a film that would have been more effective as live action, rather than animation.
a trippy movie that doesn't make it easy for the audience to follow. The story is complex and confusing and theanimation keeps the viewer from entering the tale emotionally or intellectually.
a trippy movie that doesn't make it easy for the audience to follow. The story is complex and confusing and theanimation keeps the viewer from entering the tale emotionally or intellectually.
A Scanner Darkly is capable of inducing euphoria if viewers focus on one element of splendor--the acting, concept, dialogue or animation--per viewing.
A Scanner Darkly is capable of inducing euphoria if viewers focus on one element of splendor--the acting, concept, dialogue or animation--per viewing.
The message is clear and the animation creates a world unlike any other in film, making A Scanner Darkly an easy addition to the must-see list of 2006.
The message is clear and the animation creates a world unlike any other in film, making A Scanner Darkly an easy addition to the must-see list of 2006.
It's an inspired way to use, and kid, Jordan's image while at the same time updating Bugs Bunny & Company to doing battle in the multizillion-dollar animation sweepstakes.
It's an inspired way to use, and kid, Jordan's image while at the same time updating Bugs Bunny & Company to doing battle in the multizillion-dollar animation sweepstakes.
Pitiful live-action/animation mix proves only that MJ can't act and that Coca Cola can peddle its advertising to children in the form of a 90-minute sham.
Pitiful live-action/animation mix proves only that MJ can't act and that Coca Cola can peddle its advertising to children in the form of a 90-minute sham.
This film was made very quickly by animation standards, and the haste shows.
This film was made very quickly by animation standards, and the haste shows.
Visually, it's a mess: the attempts to blend 2- and 3-D animation with live-action and computer-generated images produce scenes that are fuzzier than the storyline.
Visually, it's a mess: the attempts to blend 2- and 3-D animation with live-action and computer-generated images produce scenes that are fuzzier than the storyline.
Space Jam [whisks] Michael Jordan to Toontown for a make-or-break game with Bugs Bunny and the other Looney Tunes. Exuberantly mixing live action and animation, it's a high-energy dream teaming.
Space Jam [whisks] Michael Jordan to Toontown for a make-or-break game with Bugs Bunny and the other Looney Tunes. Exuberantly mixing live action and animation, it's a high-energy dream teaming.
Live-action/animation mix is good fun for kids.
Live-action/animation mix is good fun for kids.
Space Jam is a seamless marvel as Jordan slams and jams in the Looney Tune world. Animation co-directors Bruce Smith and Tony Cervone have orchestrated a dazzingly visual treat.
Space Jam is a seamless marvel as Jordan slams and jams in the Looney Tune world. Animation co-directors Bruce Smith and Tony Cervone have orchestrated a dazzingly visual treat.
The animation is eye-popping. And the co-mingling of 'toons and people is dazzling.
The animation is eye-popping. And the co-mingling of 'toons and people is dazzling.

movie_name: DuckTales the Movie: Treasure of the Lost Lamp
review_content: The animation is just a cut above standard TV quality, but the voices are all good, especially comedian Rip Taylor as the genie.
It sets a pace, keeps it up for the whole time, and gives us a sense of danger and excitement, + a taste of life that special effects can't give us.

movie_name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 2: Freddy's Revenge
review_content: Episodic treatment is punched up by an imaginative series of special effects.
In continuing his trend of campy dialogue and cliched special effects, [McG] has made a romantic comedy involving dueling spies that even a monkey could figure out.

movie_name: The Fall of the Roman Empire
genres: ['Sword and Sandal', 'Historical fiction', 'Epic', 'Period piece', 'Drama', 'War film', 'Historical Epic']
review_content: From back in the day when epic meant upwards of 10,000 extras, gargantuan sets, and 122-piece orchestras...in other words, CGI is for wimps.
The film feels second-rate in every sense, from the quality of its animation to its C-list voice cast.
Despite the more aerodynamic setting, this Cars 3D offshoot emerges as an uninspired retread.

Many will enter theaters thinking this is a Pixar film, with the raised expectations that accompany that mistake. But even cynical animation fans will see there's quality here. After a little turbulence, "Planes" comes in for a nice landing.
A 3D animated family film about stepping into your dream and becoming all you were meant to be.
The corporate manipulation remains the same. However, Planes does possess the fluid animation "Cars" lacked, taking to the sky with a slick presentation of aerial balletics and cartoon antics.
At its best, Planes soars above anything Disney Animation Stuios have produced in recent years on a computer, and when it's not quite that high, it remains an singularly child-friendly affair.
A palatable but whateverish 3D children's comedy about a lowly single-prop plane from the Midwest who dreams of flying around the world in an international race.
The story is routine and the animation rarely inspired, which makes it feel as if nobody cared enough to make the film soar.
Reach for the stars is the theme of this Disney 3D animation and while it's cute in part, it lacks the throttle of Pixar's Cars franchise
Reach for the stars is the theme of this Disney 3D animation and while it's cute in part, it lacks the throttle of Pixar's Cars franchise
Much of the animation looks very ordinary and at times cheap, with the dull scenery another missed opportunity in a film chocked full of them.
The Mouse still rules the world of animation. But if he looks over his shoulder, he'll see a Fox gaining on him.
A promising launch for Fox's new animation studio, which has declared war on Disney.
Bluth and Goldman have created a quality animation work, with some individual scenes bordering on the extraordinary, that does a solid job in telling the mythical adventure.
Bluth has rediscovered the ingredients of quality mainstream animation...
There is much for tots to enjoy: decent songs, an amusing script and some surprisingly imaginative animation.
This enchanting fairy-tale, the first release from Fox Animation Studios, is pure family entertainment.
Cute animation and a nice turn from Angela Landsbury carry it through the dull-as-dishwater live action scenes.
grand, under rated Disney special effects filled musical.
Oscar-winning special effects and animation sequences by Ward Kimball make this musical fantasy a perennial favorite.
Oscar-winning special effects and animation sequences by Ward Kimball make this musical fantasy a perennial favorite.
Angela Lansbury shows off her singing, dancing and comic skills -- which I think even overshadow the film's Oscar-winning special effects.
The fantasy is earthbound, the score by Richard and Robert Sherman (who also wrote music and lyrics for Mary Poppins) is forgettable, the special effects lackadaisical.
Animation is neatly mixed with live action, and Lansbury, engaging as ever, heads a capable cast.
With its visual gimmickry, attention-seeking camerawork, and in-your-face special effects, Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance spends so much time trying to be badass that it forgets to be good.
The filmmakers deliver some gorgeous landscape shots of Asia Minor and leverage the 3D perspective to good effect, but the time between such moments of relief can seem like an eternity of movie hell.
Memorable mainly for its cheesy CGI fakery.
Cheesy CGI that is either intentional or just plain awful.
It's a mash-up of blah buddy comedy and gross-out CGI monster splatter, with nary a laugh to be had.
The special effects and outrageous camera angles rule Knock Off to the point where the audience doesn't have a clue as to what's happening any more.
The plot is as incomprehensible as the dubbing, and many of the special effects are neither special nor effective.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review_content: Visually, Grant Major's production design and the CGI effects are amazing.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review_content: A perfect blend of action and fantasy, of special effects and thoughtful storytelling, and, in a time when the two seem anything but mutually exclusive, blockbuster juggernaut and arthouse darling.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review_content: The production design is a marvel, and the special effects are dazzling.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review_content: The special effects are stunning.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review_content: Middle-earth is a real world from the first reel on, thanks to incredible special effects woven seamlessly with great storytelling.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review_content: The sets and special effects are near flawless.
Most pleasantly, the movie doesn't overdo its special effects. Weta Digital bring Jess and Leslie's imaginations to life slowly and in to-scale fashion.

This is Csupo's feature directorial debut, but as creator, producer, and writer of Rugrats and The Wild Thornberrys, among several other series, he's had a long career in animation, and he handles the CGI setpieces masterfully.

This is Csupo's feature directorial debut, but as creator, producer, and writer of Rugrats and The Wild Thornberrys, among several other series, he's had a long career in animation, and he handles the CGI setpieces masterfully.
Beloved kids' novel makes it to the big-screen unscathed, with very real childhood relationships, surreal special effects and a big weepie ending.
The movie contains surprisingly little CGI, instead focusing on the kids, their unique bond and the powerful life lessons that come as a result of their adventures.
Follows in lock-step with the book and populates its titular fantasyland with CGI creatures... neither idea was very good.

The makers go easy on the special effects and the picture has a tragic dimension that young children will find upsetting. But if they watch it in the right spirit, and the right company, it could prove emotionally enlarging.

The film, though, takes us to a world in which imagination comes to life, with lavish CGI special effects giving the magic of Terabithia a palpable presence it never had in the book, even in Jess and Leslie's imaginations.

The film, though, takes us to a world in which imagination comes to life, with lavish CGI special effects giving the magic of Terabithia a palpable presence it never had in the book, even in Jess and Leslie's imaginations.
The special effects suggest a Narnia-like romp, but the movie has a darker, more sorrowful landscape to explore and it does so brilliantly, with true nuance and heartfelt sincerity.

movie_name: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World
review_content: The special effects and battle scenes are extraordinary.

movie_name: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World
review_content: Peter Weir makes the Surprise a world to explore, not a splashy CGI simulation. Like a human body, the boat stays afloat through complex processes. A knockout mix of organic elegance, reflective drama and aggressive action on par with Sir David Lean.

Brilliant puppy wrangling, seamlessly blended with special effects, and a witty and sophisticated performance by Glenn Close as dazzlingly costumed Cruella DeVil more than compensate for spottier moments.
Limp performances and ludicrous special effects remove this study of reality from any sense of it.
In the Mouth of Madness features some notable special effects and maintains some of its unsettling atmosphere thanks to its subversive, cerebral ideas.
This is one of those self- referential horror movies that gets buried alive in an avalanche of clever special effects and an incredible imploding plot.
A pint-sized delight, combining high-quality (but traditional-looking) animation, a sweet story and an excellent batch of Carly Simon songs.
It's a cute film that continues the tradition of the Winnie the Pooh series with simple stories and simple animation.
Piglet's Big Movie is what might be called second-rank Disney animation [but it] works, the kids will like it, and it provides a little escape from the news.
Rodriguez puts his money into the predictable place - special effects - and you wonder where the imagination went.

Someone, somewhere gave the keys to the kingdom to director Brian Levant, whose leaden ways with screen comedy are amplified in this unfunny, hyperactive translation of a property that's best served through animation.
It is probably more than a little reductive to say that this movie is The Lost Weekend with highly superior special effects. But there's something to that, honestly.

Denzel Washington's boldest, against-type role since Training Day... a tightly wound production, Zemeckis' first live-action work since Cast Away and, after admirably failing to make motion-capture animation the next big thing, one of his finest.
Here, after the truly alarming crash sequence, there are no special effects, just deft and committed film-making, letting us see steadily in long takes.

review_content: Does it really matter that the sun that rises in the film is a 'real' sun as opposed to a CGI sun?

genres: ['LGBT', 'Historical fiction', 'Adventure', 'British Empire Film', 'Costume drama', 'Roadshow theatrical release', 'Epic', 'Action/Adventure', 'Drama', 'War film', 'Biographical film', 'Action']
review_content: No special effects are front and center here, simply the way a master creator of images pulls us into a dramatic story of great psychological complexity.
I never got into this. Very slow, dated special effects, and obvious exploration of the paranoia theme.
The strong cast brings the somewhat underwritten characters to vivid life, and the elaborate special effects (designed by then 22-year-old Rob Bottin) set a high standard for films that followed.

The special effects can't hope to be as creepy to our seen-it-all eyes as they were to the film's first viewers, but we can still enjoy the monster's unique weirdness, and the story is a rock-solid yarn.
John Carpenter's The Thing boasts outstanding special effects, skilled direction and cinematography, and a tension-filled story, making for one of the legendary director's most cherished works.
Carpenter uses Bottin's effects to release the tension... which lets them hit all that much harder. But he didn't need special effects to find the real horror in the scenario.
In the midst of all the special effects, it is ultimately about the psychological impact of a high stress situation.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: It is almost as if Lucas took recognizable characters from myth and legend and then emptied them of meaning so as not to distract his audience from his spectacular sets, monsters and special effects.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: It is almost as if Lucas took recognizable characters from myth and legend and then emptied them of meaning so as not to distract his audience from his spectacular sets, monsters and special effects.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: Gloriously directed by George Lucas, this mind-bending space fantasy incorporates Flash Gordon, 2001, Planet of the Apes and 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea and tops them with enough ingenious special effects.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: Gloriously directed by George Lucas, this mind-bending space fantasy incorporates Flash Gordon, 2001, Planet of the Apes and 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea and tops them with enough ingenious special effects.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: The special effects wizardry seen in Star Wars is put in aid of a pure 1930s space opera pulp story . . .

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: The special effects wizardry seen in Star Wars is put in aid of a pure 1930s space opera pulp story . . .

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: This friendliness is the key emotion in this clean, clever, entertaining movie by a gifted and developing artist. It's a feeling that crackles in the sensational special effects.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: This friendliness is the key emotion in this clean, clever, entertaining movie by a gifted and developing artist. It's a feeling that crackles in the sensational special effects.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: Endlessly imitated but never rivalled, this opening instalment of George Lucas's original space trilogy dresses up the timeless tale of good versus evil with ground-breaking special effects and a dazzling array of intergalactic characters.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: Endlessly imitated but never rivalled, this opening instalment of George Lucas's original space trilogy dresses up the timeless tale of good versus evil with ground-breaking special effects and a dazzling array of intergalactic characters.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: George Lucas's science fiction adventure is an exhilarating update of Flash Gordon, very much in the same half-jokey, half-earnest mood, but backed by special effects that, for once, really work and are intelligently integrated with the story.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: George Lucas's science fiction adventure is an exhilarating update of Flash Gordon, very much in the same half-jokey, half-earnest mood, but backed by special effects that, for once, really work and are intelligently integrated with the story.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: The special effects and technical achievement are the greatest ever. Lucas and company have created an unusual and diverse universe and put it before our eyes.Not once is there a feeling of unnaturalness or fakery.

movie_name: Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope
review_content: The special effects and technical achievement are the greatest ever. Lucas and company have created an unusual and diverse universe and put it before our eyes.Not once is there a feeling of unnaturalness or fakery.

The special effects and many scenes of weightlessness look as good or better than in the original, while the Oscar-winning sound and James Horner's rousing score make good use of the hefty audio system.
For a 'space movie', both the special effects and photography are surprisingly pedestrian. Where it scores is in subtly restating traditional notions of male heroism.
The special effects are as spectacular as anything in Star Trek, but Howard shows wise restraint in not inflating the drama and tension inherent in the true story.
Peopled by leaden or hackneyed characters...The Stuff is further burdened by special effects of the most pedestrian kind.
Peopled by leaden or hackneyed characters...The Stuff is further burdened by special effects of the most pedestrian kind.

For children, the movie will play like a storybook come to life. Adults, at first, will marvel at the special effects and puppetry. But ultimately, they'll be won over by the nuances of a story that finds a fresh way to deliver a timeless message.

genres: ['Thriller', 'Science Fiction', 'Horror', 'Gothic Film', 'Creature Film', 'Drama', 'Japanese Movies', 'Romance Film', 'Costume Horror']
review_content: For all its attention to detail and special effects, this version lacks the pathos and tragedy in the complex and ambivalent relationship between the father-creator and his creature-monster; De Niro is misguided by director Branagh.
Even though the animation is still sharp, the writing is flat.
The dialogue is kid-level funny and the animation often has the manic energy of Alice in Wonderland.
...there's a droll and engaging heart under all that CGI marzipan.
The special effects are too obvious at times, and in trying to impart an eccentric vibe, Helm relies too heavily on kooky camera angles.
If there were as many great ideas in the story as there are in the art and CGI special effects departments, this fantasy tale of wonder might have been a hit.
If there were as many great ideas in the story as there are in the art and CGI special effects departments, this fantasy tale of wonder might have been a hit.
The trailers make the movie look like the ickiest kind of whimsy, accompanied by obstreperous special effects, but the film itself is gasp-worthy.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review_content: Special effects are first rate with the Gollum sequences virtually flawless.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review_content: The third part of Peter Jackson's epic trilogy delivers everything we have been led to expect: stunning battle sequences, glorious scenery, jaw-dropping special effects and wonderful performances.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review_content: A dreamy marriage of myth and special effects, of great literature and popcorn entertainment.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review_content: Return of the King is such a crowning achievement, such a visionary use of all the tools of special effects, such a pure spectacle, that it can be enjoyed even by those who have not seen the first two films.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review_content: By this point, Jackson has proven himself a master at wielding both a huge story line and cast, not to mention overseeing special effects that must make George Lucas take pause.

movie_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review_content: For 2004 [the special effects] look great.
There aren't enough expensive special effects in the world to make up for a good story. They had one with Machine, but chose to screw with it.
The Time Machine is a loopy love story with good special effects but a storyline that's logically incomprehensible.

The movie obviously seeks to re-create the excitement of such '50s flicks as Jules Verne's '20,000 Leagues Under the Sea' and the George Pal version of H.G. Wells' 'The Time Machine.' But its storytelling prowess and special effects are both listless.
Overall, the special effects are impressive, especially the time machine itself ...
A charmingly old-fashioned adventure yarn,...but spruced up with state-of-the-art special effects...an affectionately realized updating of the old tale.
Isn't a complete home run, but...is that rare special effects-laden feature that actually uses its brain and has something worthwhile to say.
How come getting the CGI right is so damned important, but the filmmakers go Ed Wood when it comes to the continuity of the sun in the sky?
... a listless, plodding, mumble of a film that gets so bogged down in special effects that it never comes close to capturing the adventurous spirit of the classic H.G. Wells story.
little to recommend it beyond ... special effects technology.
A disappointing new adaptation of H.G. Wells' sci-fi classic The Time Machine joins the growing list of dreary films to emphasize special effects at the expense of story.
The Time Machine is stupid -- too stupid for the impressive special effects or the competently directed action sequences to wash away the bitter taste.

Bears resemblance to, and shares the weaknesses of, too many recent action-fantasy extravaganzas in which special effects overpower cogent story-telling and visual clarity during the big action sequences.
A great sense of adventure, good-looking special effects, and enough plot holes to sink the movie
Little of the novel's social commentary permeates the film's 96 minutes, which proves to be nothing more than a mindless array of cheesy special effects, enough to triple coat an extra large pizza.
A zippy 96 minutes of mediocre special effects, hoary dialogue, fluxing accents, and -- worst of all -- silly-looking Morlocks.
It's passable big-budget trash, with a few diverting moments and a refreshing clarity in the design of the sets and special effects.
Modern take on H.G. Wells's sci-fi classic has great special effects but isn't especially affecting.

While this remake of the H.G. Wells' classic novel and 1960 film is indeed a stunning achievement in special effects, his great- grandson and director Simon Wells really needs to go back a year and get the sadly lacking script rewritten.
The movie has some good songs and some lively animation, but what bothered me was that most of the interaction between characters was on the level of violence.
The movie has some good songs and some lively animation, but what bothered me was that most of the interaction between characters was on the level of violence.
One of feature animation's greatest fiascoes.
One of feature animation's greatest fiascoes.
The special effects feel rather synthetic for a big-time summer blockbuster. When the smoke finally clears Hancock emerges as just another routine riff on the superhero genre
Smart enough to use the CGI madness in service to the story, rather than just ending and scene or conflict with a big effecty showdown. (I'm looking at you, Transformers!)
Style takes precedence over substance, special effects over smart scripting, and jumpy scares over solid theatrics.
In an era of senseless action and lobotomized scripts that rely too heavily on special effects, even the modest food for thought offered by 'The Butterfly Effect' is welcome.
Some chill-inducing special effects, but the movie never evolves into the tightly wound thriller it delights in threatening to be.
When your big climactic set-piece finally arrives and consists of nothing more than some CGI cargo crates toppling over, that's a pretty tell-tale sign that no one's trying very hard.
Let down by a disappointing script, dodgy dialogue, poor CGI effects, panicky editing and a subplot that's both morally reprehensible and entirely out of place.
It's all shot and edited in a cut-to-ribbons, unsatisfying, no-stakes CGI way.
A frenetic, over-the-top combination of live action and crude animation that explores the seedy world of New York's Lower East Side in the early 1970s.
The quality of the animation is cornflake packet standard, the script -- one or two minor moments excepted -- a disaster.

Heavy Traffic may be a bit dated in terms of its distinct '70s tone, but that doesn't make it any less fascinating. If you're a fan of the animation genre, this certainly qualifies as essential viewing.

The animation is gorgeous but makes the characters feel cold, and the plot is perhaps too labyrinthine even for this twisty genre. An interesting and gloriously designed effort rather than a must-see.

The animation is gorgeous but makes the characters feel cold, and the plot is perhaps too labyrinthine even for this twisty genre. An interesting and gloriously designed effort rather than a must-see.
The rotoscope animation is visually stunning but the story is just a straightforward sci-fi thriller with good guys, bad guys...and a corporate-controlled world.
The rotoscope animation is visually stunning but the story is just a straightforward sci-fi thriller with good guys, bad guys...and a corporate-controlled world.
...suffers from an unpleasant and relentlessly distracting animation style that ultimately renders its few positive attributes moot.
...suffers from an unpleasant and relentlessly distracting animation style that ultimately renders its few positive attributes moot.
Ultimately saved by the strong performances, taut atmosphere, and awe inspiring animation...
Ultimately saved by the strong performances, taut atmosphere, and awe inspiring animation...

genres: ['Fantasy Adventure', 'Adventure', 'Costume drama', 'Action/Adventure', 'Fantasy', 'Sword and sorcery', 'Action', 'Sword and sorcery films']
review_content: The special effects haven't improved and the sincerity of the adventures have swung too far in the opposite direction, resulting in a sequel that is just as flawed.
Some heaped praise on 007's most recent adventure Die Another Day but the CGI free thrills which The Transporter offers are right up there with it.

After dipping its toes into pure CG animation for Arthur Christmas, Aardman integrates its feted old-school stop-motion technique with top-drawer visual effects to create the irrepressibly amusing The Pirates! Band of Misfits.
Plasticine pirates wreak havoc on the high seas in a gloriously silly caper from Aardman's Animations.
Beautiful animation from Aardman and brimming with swashbuckling gags and delicious moments.

A funny, thoroughly enjoyable and oddly subversive film: at a time when CGI reigns in family films and Elizabeth Windsor celebrates a jubilee, here's a film where puppets battle a fiendish regal villain.
Forget the rum; it's the fun that's running dry in Aardman Animation's The Pirates! Band of Misfits.
A script that consistently finds fresh outlets for its running gags makes for a sufficiently rollicking pleasure cruise from Britain's Aardman Animations...

Exactly how much wind is left in the sails of pirate movies after Capt. Jack Sparrow is an issue. There are only so many ways to buckle a swash, or shiver timbers. When Veggie Tales beats you to an idea for animation, you know rough waters lie ahead.
Another deliriously silly stop-motion animation delight from Aardman, filled with giddy pleasures and witty details.
Aardman's first stop-motion feature in 3D doesn't overdo the now-ubiquitous special effects, but the added dimension refreshes the studio's signature chases without dampening its endearing drollery.
Aardman's first stop-motion feature in 3D doesn't overdo the now-ubiquitous special effects, but the added dimension refreshes the studio's signature chases without dampening its endearing drollery.

Pirates are right up there with vampires, werewolves and people saying "LOL" out loud on the list of Played-Out Pop Culture Phenomena, but leave it to Aardman Animation to find the remaining reservoirs of fun in a bunch of seafaring scalawags.
Young and old alike love a good pirate yarn and the stop-motion specialists at Aardman Animations deliver the goods.
Never mind the awkward title. The Pirates! Band Of Misfits is as energetic and fearlessly goofy as anything bearing the stamp of Aardman Animation.
The wonderful folks at Aardman have created another deliriously silly stop-motion animation delight, filled with giddy pleasures and so many witty details flying by that you wish for a pause button.
A first-class Aardman Animations comedy.
It's got great vocal talent and well-done animation, but it proves once again that the story is the key ingredient.
This is a good Aardman Animations feature, from a studio that's proved itself capable of being better than good.
A movie with wooden performances, a color-by-numbers screenplay, and some mighty cool but hardly revolutionary special effects.
It was so bad that had it not been for wanting to see all the special effects, I would have been ready to walk out.

The movie is wall-to-wall with special effects, and they're all convincing, although it's impossible for me to explain how Bill and Jo escape serious injury while staring right up into the Suck Zone of the Finger of God.
While the special effects are clearly the star of this masterwork, the storyline itself, although predictable, is crisp and full of heart.
